lorna doone romance of exmoor by r d blackmore preface work be called 'romance ' because incident character time scenery be alike romantic in shaping old tale writer dare desire to claim for dignity cumber with difficulty of historic novel yet think that outline be filled in more carefully situation however simple more warmly coloured quickened than reader must expect to find in what be called 'legend know that son of exmoor chancing on volume can not fail to bring to mind nurse tale of childhood savage deed of outlaw doones in depth of bagworthy forest beauty of hapless maid brought up in midst of plain john ridd herculean power memory too congenial food exploit of tom faggus march content element of education ii important item iii warpath of doones iv very rash visit v illegal settlement vi necessary practice vii hard be to climb viii boy girl ix there be place like home x brave rescue rough ride xi tom deserves supper xii man justly popular xiii master huckaback come in xiv motion end in mull xv master huckaback fails of warrant xvi lorna grows formidable xvii john be clearly bewitched xviii witchery lead to witchcraft xix dangerous interview xx lorna begin story xxi lorna end story xxii long spring month xxiii royal invitation xxiv safe pas for king messenger xxv great man attends to business xxvi john be drained cast aside xxvii home again at last xxviii john have hope of lorna xxix reaping lead to revelling xxx annie get best of xxxi john fry errand xxxii feeding of pig xxxiii early morning calling two negative make affirmative xxxv ruth be not like lorna xxxvi john return to business xxxvii very desperate venture xxxviii good turn for jeremy xxxix troubled state foolish joke xl two fool together xli cold comfort xlii great winter xliii not too soon xliv brought home at last xlv change long needed xlvi squire faggus make lucky hit xlvii jeremy in danger xlviii man must defend xlix maiden sentinel be best l merry meeting sad one li visit from counsellor lii way to make cream rise liii jeremy find out something liv mutual discomfiture lv getting into chancery lvi john becomes too popular lvii lorna know nurse lviii master huckaback secret lix lorna gone away lx annie luckier than john lxi therefore seek comfort lxii king must not be prayed for lxiii john be worsted by woman lxiv slaughter in marsh lxv falling among lamb lxvi suitable devotion lxvii lorna still be lorna lxviii john be john no longer lxix not to be put up with lxx compelled to volunteer lxxi long account settled lxxii counsellor carver lxxiii how to get out of chancery lxxiv driven beyond endurance lxxv life lorna come again chapter element of education if anybody care to read simple tale told simply john ridd of parish of oare in county of somerset yeoman churchwarden have seen have share in doings of neighborhood will try to set down in order god sparing life memory who light upon book must bear in mind not only that write for clearing of parish from ill fame calumny also thing will trow appear too often in to wit be nothing more than plain unlettered man not read in foreign language a gentleman might be gifted with long word even in mine own tongue save what may have won from bible master william shakespeare whom in face of common opinion do value highly in short be ignoramus pretty well for yeoman father being of good substance at least a reckon in exmoor seized in own right from many generation of one that best largest of three farm into parish be divided rather cultured part thereof john ridd elder churchwarden overseer being great admirer of learning well able to write name sent only son to be schooled at tiverton in county of devon for chief boast of ancient town next to woollen staple be worthy grammar school largest in west of england founded handsomely endowed in year by master peter blundell of same place clothier here by time be twelve year old have risen into upper school must make bold with eutropius caesar by aid of english version a much a six line of ovid even said that might before manhood rise almost to third form being of perservering nature albeit by full consent of except mother thick headed must have be a now perceive ambition beyond farmer son for there be one form above that made of masterful scholar entitled rightly beonitors ' so came to pas by grace of god be called away from learning whilst sitting at desk of junior first in upper school beginning greek verb greek word eldest grandson make bold to say that never must have learned greek word ten page further on being must manage with plenty of stripe to help know that hath more head than though never will have such body be thankful to have stopped betimes with meek wholesome head piece if doubt of having be there because now know so little go see name ridd ' graven on very form forsooth from time be strong enough to open knife to spell name began to grave in oak first of block whereon sate then of desk in front of according a be promoted from one to other of there grandson read now at present time of writing hath fought boy for scoffing at 'john ridd name done again in 'winkeys mischievous cheerful device in took great pleasure be manner of 'winkey here set down lest child of mine grandchild dare to make one on premise if doe will know mark at once score well upon scholar obtains by prayer price handful of saltpetre then with knife wherewith must rather be trying to mend pen what doe do scoop hole where desk be three inch thick hole must be left with middle exalted circumfere dug more deeply then let fill with saltpetre save little space in midst where bos of wood be upon bos will be better if splinter of timber rise upward stick end of candle of tallow be tail ' a called kindled burning smoothly anon a read by light lesson lifting eye now then may be fire of candle lay hold of petre with spluttering noise leaping then must pupil seize pen regardless of nib stir bravely will see glow a of burning mountain rich smoke spark going merrily will cease if stir wisely there be good store of petre until wood be devoured through like sinking of well shaft now well may go with head of boy intent upon primer who betides to sit thereunder above thing have good care to exercise art before master stride up to desk in early gray of morning other custom le worthy abide in school of blundell such a singeing of nightcap though have pleasant savour refreshing to think of may not stop to note unless be that goodly one at incoming of flood school house stand beside stream not very large called lowman flow into broad river of exe about mile below lowman stream although be not fond of brawl violence in manner of lynn yet be wont to flood into mighty head of water when storm of rain provoke most of when little co mate called taunton brook where have plucked very best cress ever man put salt on come foaming down like great roan horse rear at leap of hedgerow then be gray stone wall of blundell on side encompassed vale be spread over with looping water be hard thing for day boy to get home to supper in time old cop porter so called because hath copper boot to keep wet from stomach nose of copper also in right of other water place be to stand at gate attending to flood board grooved into one so to watch torrent rise not be washed away if please god may help long ere flood hath attained height while be only waxing certain boy of deputy will watch at stoop of drain hole be apt to look outside wall when cop be taking cordial in very front of gate just without archway where ground be paved most handsomely may see in copy letter done great pb of white pebble now be custom law when invading water fluxing along wall from below road bridge pouring sharply across meadow from cut called ditch have seen come way upon very instant when waxing element lip though be single pebble of founder letter be in license of boy soever small undoctrined to rush into great school room where score of master sit heavily scream at top of voice then with yell boy leap up break away from standing toss cap to black beamed roof haply very book after great boy vex more small one small boy stick up to great one one with hard go to see gain of water tribulation of cop be prone to kick day boy out with word of scanty compliment then master look at one having class to look to boy being more left to watch in manner put mouth up with spirited bang close book make invitation one to other for pipe foreign cordial recommending chance of time comfort away from cold water lo be dwelling on little thing pigeon egg of infancy forgetting bitter heavy life gone over since then if be hard man very close one god know have have lack of rubbing pounding to make stone of yet can not somehow believe that ought to hate one to live far asunder block mouth of little den a do wild beast of wood hairy outrangs now brought over with chain upon let matter be a will be beyond to unfold mayhap of grandson grandson know be that wheat be better than when began to sow chapter ii important item now cause of leaving tiverton school way of be a follows on th day of november in year of lord very day when be twelve year old have spent substance in sweetmeat with made treat to little boy till large boy ran in took came out of school at five o'clock a rule be upon tuesday according to custom drove day boy in brave rout down causeway from school porch even to gate where cop have dwelling duty little recked helped le that be founder citizen haply own grand nephew for left direct descendant did much inquire what lineage be for have long be fixed among who be of house chamber that same day boy be 'caddes a have discovered to call because paid groat for schooling brought own common with in consumption of must help for fare in hall fed appetite while ate victual allowed freely to talk to nevertheless must not feel when victual be gone that boy required kicking from premise of blundell of be shopkeeper son young grocer fellmongers poulterer to credit seemed to know how righteous be to kick others be of high family a need be in devon carew bouchiers bastard of must turn sometimes strike boy kicked to do justice even knew that must be kicked for not paying after 'charity boy be gone a in contumely called 'if break bag on head ' said one 'how will feed thence to morrow after old cop with clang of iron have jammed double gate in under scruff stone archway whereupon be latin verse done in brass of small quality of who be not hungry cared not for supper bell having sucked much parliament dump at only charge not that ever bore much wealth because have be thrifting for time of birth be leaning quite at dusk against iron bar of gate six may be seven of small boy not conspicuous in closing of daylight fog came at eventide else cop must have rated up green for be churly to little boy when wife have taken money there be plenty of room for of for gate will hold nine boy close packed unless be fed rankly whereof be little danger now be looking out on road wishing must get there hoping moreover to see good string of pack horse come by with trooper to protect for day boy have brought word that intending way to town have lain that morning at sampford peveril must be in ere nightfall because mr faggus be after now mr faggus be first cousin honour to family being northmolton man of great renown on highway from barum town even to london therefore of course hoped that must catch packman boy be asking opinion a of oracle about certain boy leaning up against must not allow elbow room struck very sadly in stomach part though own be full of parliament felt so unkindly that smote straightway in face without tarrying to consider weighing question duly upon put head down presented so vehemently at middle of waistcoat that for minute more breath seemed dropped a be from pocket life seemed to stop from great want of ease before came to myself again have be settled for that must move to 'ironing box ' a triangle of turf be called where two causeway coming from school porch hall porch meet fight be mainly celebrated only must wait until convoy of horse have passed then make ring by candlelight other boy must like suddenly there came round post where letter of founder be not from way of taunton from side of lowman bridge very small string of horse only two indeed counting for one pony red faced man on bigger nag ye worshipful master said being feared of gateway e tull whur jan ridd be ' be ee fai jan ridd ' answered sharp little chap making game of john fry language 'zhow un up then say john fry poking whip through bar at 'zhow un up putt un aowt ' other little chap pointed at began to hallo knew what be about 'oh john john ' cried 'what be use of coming now peggy over moor too so cruel cold for holiday begin till wednesday fortnight john to think of not knowing that ' john fry leaned forward in saddle turned eye away from then there be noise in throat like snail crawling on window pane knaws that wull enough maister jan reckon oare man knaw that without go to skoo ull like doth moother have kept arl apple up old betty toorned black puddens none dare set trap for blagbird arl for thee lad bit of now for thee ' checked suddenly frightened knew that john fry way so well 'and father father oh how be father ' pushed boy right left a said 'john be up in town always used to come for leave nobody else to do ' will be at crooked post tother zide o ' telling house cood lave 'ouze by raison of chirstmas bakkon comin on zome o ' cider welted ' 'telling house on moor be rude cot where shepherd meet to 'tell sheep at end of pasturing season looked at nag ear a said being up to john fry way knew that be lie heart fell like lump of lead leaned back on stay of gate longed more to fight anybody sort of dull power hung over like cloud of brooding tempest feared to be told anything did not even care to stroke nose of pony peggy although pushed in through rail where square of broader lattice be sniffed at began to crop gently after finger life dy business must be attended to principal business of good christian be beyond controversy to fight with one 'come up jack ' said one of boy lifting under chin hit hit know ' 'pay debt before go ' said monitor striding up to after hearing how honour lay must go through with ' 'fight for sake of junior first cried little fellow in ear clever one head of class who have mocked john fry knew about aorist tried to make know never went more than three place up then be accident came down after dinner boy be urgent round to fight though stomach be not up for being very slow of wit be not chargeable on looked from one to other of seeking cure for not be afraid of fighting for now have be three year at blundell foughten time fight at least once week till boy began to know only that load on heart be not sprightly a of hay field be very sad thing to dwell on even now in time of wisdom doubt be fond thing to imagine motherly to insist upon boy can do without fighting unless be very good boy afraid of one 'nay ' said with back against wrought iron stay of gate be socketed into cop house front ' will not fight thee now robin snell wait till come back again ' 'take coward blow jack ridd then cried half dozen little boy shoving bob snell forward to do because knew well enough having striven with ere now proved to be master knew say that without great change must never accept that contumely took little heed of looking in dull wonderment at john fry smiler blunderbuss peggy john fry be scratching head must see getting blue in face by light from cop parlour window going to fro upon smiler a if be hard set with time be looking briskly from eye to fist be clenching methought tried to wink at in covert manner then peggy whisked tail behall fight john ' said at last must have not come john ' 'chraist will be done zim thee have better faight jan ' answered in whisper through gridiron of gate 'there be dale of faighting avore thee best wai to begin gude taime laike wull geatman latt in to zee a thee hast vair plai lad ' looked doubtfully down at colour of cowskin boot mire upon horse for slough be exceedingly mucky peggy indeed sorrel pony being lighter of weight be not crusted much over shoulder smiler youngest sledder have be well in over withers none must have deemed piebald save of red mire black mire great blunderbuss moreover be choked with dollop of slough cake john fry sad coloured sunday hat be indued with plume of marish weed saw while be dismounting heavily wearily lifting leg from saddle cloth a if with sore crick in back by time question of fighting be gone quite out of discretion for sundry of elder boy grave reverend signor who have taken no small pleasure in teaching hand to fight to ward to parry to feign counter to lunge in manner of sword play weaker child to drop on one knee when cunning of fence might baffle onset great master of art who must far liefer see little one practise than engage six seven of came running down rounded causeway having heard that there have arisen ' snug little mill ' at gate now whether word hath origin in greek term meaning conflict a best read boy asseverated whether be nothing more than figure of similitude from beating arm of mill such a have seen in county where be waterbrooks folk make bread with wind be not for man devoid of scholarship to determine enough that who made ring intituled scene beill while who must be thumped inside tried to rejoice in pleasantry till turned upon stomach moreover felt upon now certain responsibility dutiful need to maintain in presence of john fry manliness of ridd family honour of exmoor hitherto none have worsted although in three year of schooling have fought more than threescore battle bedewed with blood plant of grass towards middle of ironing box success owed at first to skill of own until came to know better for up to twenty thirty fight struck a nature guided wiser than father long leg in heat of lanthorn have conquered partly through native strength exmoor toughness in still more must not see when have gotten bellyful now be like to have more for heart be down to begin with then robert snell be bigger boy than have ever encountered a thick in skull hard in brain a even must claim to be have never told mother word about frequent striving because be soft hearted have told by father because have not seen therefore beholding still innocent looking child with fair curl on forehead store of bad language john fry thought be very first fight ever have befallen so when let at gate 'with message to headmaster a one of monitor told cop peggy smiler be tied to railing till must be through business john come up to with tear in eye say 'doo thee goo for to do jan doo thee do for gude now told that now be much too late to cry off so said 'the lord be with thee jan turn thy thumb knuckle inwards be not very large piece of ground in angle of causeway quite big enough to fight upon especially for christian who loved to be cheek by jowl at great boy stood in circle around being gifted with strong privilege little boy have leave to lie flat look through leg of great boy while be yet preparing candle hissed in fog cloud old phoebe of more than fourscore year whose room be over hall porch came hobbling out a always did to mar joy of conflict one ever heeded did expect evil be that two senior boy must always lose first round of fight by having to lead home again marvel how robin snell felt very likely thought nothing of always having be boy of hectoring unruly sort felt heart go up down a boy came round to strip greatly fearing to be beaten blew hot upon knuckle then pulled off little cut jerkin laid down on head cap over waistcoat boy be proud to take care of thomas hooper be name remember how looked at mother have made that little cut jerkin in quiet winter evening taken pride to loop up in fashionable way be loth to soil with blood good filberds be in pocket then up to came robin snell mayor of exeter thrice since stood very square looking at lacked not long to look at round waist have kerchief busking up small clothes on foot light pumpkin shoe upper raiment off danced about in way that made head swim on shoulder stood inch over being muddled with much doubt about john fry errand be only stripped of jerkin waistcoat not comfortable to begin 'come now shake hand cried big boy jumping in joy of spectacle third former nearly six foot high hand little devil keep pluck up show good sport lord love better man of ' robin took by hand gazed at disdainfully then smote painfully in face ere must get fence up 'whutt be 'bout lad cried john fry un again jan wull e well done then jan boy ' for have replied to robin now with weight cadence of penthemimeral caesura thing name of know must never make head tail of strife began in serious style boy looking on be not cheated although must not collect shout when blow be ringing upon be great loss for john fry told afterwards oath went up like furnace fire to paid heed hap being in thick of swinging devoid of judgment know be came to corner when round be over with very hard pump in chest great desire to fall away 'time be up ' cried head monitor ere ever got breath again when fain must have lingered awhile on knee of boy held john fry have come up boy be laughing because wanted stable lanthorn threatened to tell mother 'time be up ' cried boy more headlong than head monitor 'if count three before come of thee thwacked thou art must go to woman felt hard upon began to count one too three before 'three be out of mouth be facing foe with hand up breath going rough hot resolved to wait turn of for have found seat on knee of boy sage skilled to tutor who knew how much end very often differs from beginning rare ripe scholar be now hath routed up german in matter of criticism sure clever boy men have most love towards stupid one off bob ' cried big boy noticed especially because thought unkind of after eating of toffee a have that afternoon 'finish off neck crop deserves for sticking up to man like ' be not so to be finished off though feeling in knuckle now a if be blueness sense of chilblain nothing held except leg be good to help so bout round if please be foughten warily by with gentle recollection of what tutor clever boy have told resolve to earn praise before came back to knee again never think in life sounded sweeter word in ear except when love loved than when second backer who have made part of doings now must have wept to see beaten said 'famously done jack famously only keep wind up jack will go right through ' meanwhile john fry be prowling about asking boy what thought of whether be like to be killed because of mother trouble finding now that have foughten three score fight already came up to woefully in quickness of breathing while sat on knee of second with piece of spongious coralline to ease of bloodshed say in ear a if be clapping spur into horse thee knack under jan never coom naigh hexmoor more with that be up with simmering buzzed in heavy brain light came through eyeplaces at once set fist again heart stuck to like cobbler wax robin snell must kill must conquer robin snell so went in again with courage up bob came smiling for victory hated for smiling let at with left hand gave right between eye blinked be not pleased with feared not spared not neither spared breath came again heart stood cool eye struck fire no longer only knew must die sooner than shame birthplace how rest of be know not only that have end of helped to put robin in bed chapter iii war path of doones from tiverton town to town of oare be very long painful road in good truth traveller must make way a saying be for way be still unmade at least on side of dulverton although there be le danger now than in time of schooling for now good horse may go there without much cost of leaping when be boy spur must fail when needed most by reason of slough cake be to credit of age advance upon fatherly way now have laid down rod fagot even stump oak here there so that man in good daylight need not sink if be quite sober there be nothing have striven at more than doing duty way warden over exmoor in day when came from school good time be too full of warmth fine hearth comfort now be dying out be sad sorry business to find where lay highway be taking now to mark off with fence on side at least when town be handy to seems of high pretence sort of landmark channel for robber though well enough near london where have earned race course left town of two ford say be meaning of very early in morning after lying one day to rest a be demanded by nag sore of foot foundered for part too be glad to rest having ache over very heavy bruise lodged at sign of white horse inn in street called gold street opposite where soul be of john joan greenway set up in gold letter because must take homeward way at cockcrow of morning though still john fry be dry with of reason of coming only told lie about father must not keep agreeable hoped for best a boy will especially after victory thought perhaps father have sent for because have good harvest rat be bad in corn chamber be high noon before be got to dulverton day near to town river exe big brother barle have union mother have uncle living there be not to visit house time at be somewhat astonished since need must stop for at least two hour to bait horse thorough well before coming to black bogway bog be very good in frost except where hot spring rise a yet there have be no frost year save just enough to make blackbird look big in morning in hearty black frost look small until snow fall over road from bampton to dulverton have not be very delicate yet nothing to complain of much deeper indeed than hock of horse except in rotten place day be inclined to be mild foggy nag sweated freely peggy carrying little weight for wardrobe be upon smiler john fry grumbling always must easily keep in front a far a may hear laugh john have be rather bitter with methought be mark of ill taste at coming home for holiday yet made allowance for john because have never be at school never must have chance to eat fry upon condition of spelling therefore rode on thinking that be hard set like saw for dinner must soften after work yet at most hungry time when mind be far gone upon bacon certes seemed to check look at a if be sorry for little thing coming over great now at dulverton dined upon rarest choicest victual that ever did taste even now at time of life to think of give appetite a once awhile to think of first love make love goodness hot mutton pasty be thing have often heard of from very wealthy boy men who made dessert of dinner to hear talk of made lip smack rib come inwards now john fry strode into hostel with air grace of short legged man shouted a loud a if be calling sheep upon exmoor mooton pasty for twoo trarv'lers at number vaive in vaive minnits dish un up in tin with grahvy zame a hardered last tuesday ' of course did not come in five minute yet in ten twenty that made better when came to real presence smell of be enough to make empty man thank god for room there be inside fifty year have passed quicker than taste of gravy be manner of good boy to be careless of apparel take pride in adornment good lack if see boy make to do about fit of crumpler creasing of breech desire to be shod for comeliness rather than for use can not becape mark that god took thought to make girl of not so when grow older court regard of maiden then may bravery pas from inside to outside of bigger fool be even then than father be before god forbid man to be fool to love be loved a have be else must have prevented when mutton pasty be done peggy smiler have dined well also out went to wash at pump being lover of soap water at risk except of dinner john fry who cared very little to wash save sabbath day in own soap who have kept from pump by threatening loss of dish out came in satisfied manner with piece of quill in hand to lean against door post listen to horse feeding have teeth ready for supper then lady maid came out sun be on face turned round to go back again put better face upon gave trip hitched dress looked at sun full body lest hostler must laugh that be losing complexion with long italian glass in finger very daintily came up to pump in middle of yard where be running water off head shoulder arm of breast even though have glimpsed through sprinkle gave quite turn to see child a be in open aspect looked at whit abashed making baby of doubt a woman of thirty will do even with very big boy when catch on hayrick said to in brazen manner a if have be nobody while be shrinking behind pump craving to get shirt on leetle boy come hither to fine heaven how blue eye be skin like snow naughty man have beaten black oh leetle boy let feel ah how then must have hurt there now will love ' time be touching breast here there very lightly with delicate brown finger understood from voice manner that be not of country foreigner by extraction then be not so shy of because must talk better english than yet longed for jerkin liked not to be rude to 'if please madam must go john fry be waiting by tapster door peggy neighing to if please must get home to night father will be waiting for side of telling house ' there will go leetle dear perhaps will go after have taken much love of baroness be hard to how far call now to bank of sea at wash wash watchett likely mean madam oh very long way road a soft a road to oare ' 'oh ah oh ah will remember be place where leetle boy live day will come seek for now make pump to flow dear give good water baroness will not touch unless nebule be formed outside glass did not know what meant by yet pumped for very heartily marvelled to see for fifty time throw water away in trough a if be not good enough at last water suited with likeness of fog outside glass gleam of crystal under then made curtsey to in sort of mocking manner holding long glass by foot not to take cloud off then wanted to kiss be out of breath have always be shy of work except when come to offer so ducked under pump handle knocked chin on knob of hostler came out asked whether must do a well upon retreated up yard with certain dark dignity foreign way of walking stopped at once from going farther because be so different from fashion of sweetheart one with hung back where half cart load of hay be looked to be sure that must not turn round then one laughed at rest of now up to end of dulverton town on northward side of where two new pig sty be oare folk watchett folk must trudge on together until come to broken cross where murdered man lie buried peggy smiler went up hill a if nothing must be too much for after bean have eaten suddenly turning corner of tree happened upon great coach six horse labouring very heavily john fry rode on with hat in hand a became towards quality be amazed to degree left cap on head drew bridle without knowing for in front seat of coach be way open being of city make day in want of air sate foreign lady who have met at pump offered to salute by side be little girl dark haired very wonderful with wealthy softness on a if must have own way must not look at for two glance did not look at for one being little child busy with hedge in honourable place sate handsome lady very warmly dressed sweetly delicate of colour close to be lively child two may be three year old bearing white cockade in hat staring at everybody now saw peggy took liking to that lady mother if so be be forced to look at pony to tell truth although be not of who adore high folk looked at very kindly with sweetness rarely found in woman who milk cow for then took off cap to beautiful lady without asking wherefore put up hand kissed to thinking perhaps that looked like gentle good little boy for folk always called innocent though god know never be that now foreign lady lady maid a might be who have be busy with little dark eye turned upon going on looked straight in face be about to salute at distance indeed not with nicety have offered to strange to say stared at eye a if have never seen before wished to see again at be so startled such thing being out of knowledge startled peggy also with muscle of leg being fresh from stable mire scraped off with cask hoop broke away so suddenly that must do more than turn round lower cap now five month old to beautiful lady soon overtook john fry asked about how be that have missed starting from hostel john must never talk much till after gallon of cider must win out of be that be beurdering papishers little cared to do with devil a came from good thing for providence be gone down dulverton town to buy sweetstuff for annie else stupid head must have gone astray with great out coming saw more of after turned into sideway soon have fill of hand eye to look to own going for road got worse worse until there be none at perhaps purest thing must do be to be ashamed to show pushed on a best might with doubt of reaching home time except by special grace of god fog came down upon moor a thick a ever saw there be sound of sort breath of wind to guide little stubby tree that stand here there like bush with wooden leg to be drizzled with mess of wet hung point with dropping wherever butt end of hedgerow came up from hollow ground like withers of horse hole of splash be pocked pimpled in yellow sand of coney under dwarf tree oven soon be too dark to see anything else may say except crease in dusk where prisoned light crept up valley after awhile even be gone other comfort left except to see horse head jogging to footstep dark ground pas below lighter where wet be then splash foot after foot more clever than can do orderly jerk of tail smell of what horse be john fry be bowing forward with sleep upon saddle now must no longer see frizzle of wet upon beard for have very brave one of bright red colour trimmed into whale oil knot because be newly married although comb of hair have be subject of wonder to whether in god good time must have like of handsomely set with shining bead small above large below from weeping of heaven still must see jog of hat sunday hat with top to of shoulder bowed out in mist so one must say 'hold up john ' when smiler put foot in beercy of god where be now ' said john fry waking suddenly 'us ought to have passed hold hash jan zeen on road have 'ee ' indeed john old ash nothing else to knowing heard nothing save thee snoring ' vule thee must be then jan myzell better harken lad harken ' drew horse up listened through thickness of air with hand laid to ear at first there be nothing to hear except panting of horse trickle of eaving drop from head cover clothing soft sound of lonely night make feel try not to think then there came mellow noise very low mournsome not sound to be afraid of to long to know meaning with soft rise of hair three time came went again a shaking of thread might pas away into distance then touched john fry to know that there be something near 'doo e be vule jan vaine moozick a iver 'eer god bless man a made un doo ' 'have hanged one of doones then john ' 'hush lad niver talk laike o ' thiccy hang doone god knoweth king must hang pretty quick if did 'then who be in chain john ' felt spirit rise a asked for now have crossed exmoor so often a to hope that people sometimes deserved think that might be lesson to rogue who unjustly loved mutton be never born to of course be born to hanging when set so high 'it be nawbody ' said john 'vor to make fush about belong to t'other zide o ' moor come staling shape to zide red jem hannaford feeling a creaking sound came after 'hould thee tongue lad ' said sharply 'us be naigh doone track now two maile from dunkery beacon hill haighest place of hexmoor so happen be abroad to naight must crawl on belly place boy ' knew at once what meant bloody doones of bagworthy awe of devon somerset outlaw traitor murderer little leg began to tremble to fro upon peggy side a heard dead robber in be by hollow ground zober lad goo zober now if thee wish to see thy moother ' for be inclined in manner of boy to make run of danger cross doone track at full speed to rush for be done with even then wondered why talked of mother so said not word of father be come to long deep 'goyal a call on exmoor word whose fountain origin have nothing to do with only know that when little boy laughed at at well enough to wit long trough among wild hill falling towards plain country rounded at bottom perhaps stiff more than steep at side of whether be straight crooked make difference to rode very shape of ear be sound of horse foot knocking up through splashy ground a if bottom sucked then grunting of weary men lifting noise of stirrup sometimes clank of iron mixed with wheezy croning of john bleated like sheep to cover sheep very cold trembling then just a foremost horseman passed scarce twenty yard below puff of wind came up glen fog rolled off before suddenly strong red light cast by cloud weight downwards spread like finger over moorland opened alley of darkness hung on steel of rider beacon ' whispered john so close into ear that felt lip teeth ashake 'durs fire now except to show doones way home again since naight a went up throwed watchman atop of why wutt be 'bout lad god sake ' for must keep still no longer wriggled away from arm along little gullet still going flat on breast thigh until be under grey patch of stone with fringe of dry fern round there lay scarce twenty foot above head of rider feared to draw breath though prone to do with wonder for now beacon be when trouble of england be swelling to outburst great estate in north country be suddenly confiscated through feud of family strong influence at court owner be turned upon world might think lucky to save neck estate be in co heirship joint tenancy think called although not meaning only so that if tenant died other living must come to live one in spite of testament one of joint owner be sir ensor apportionment when suddenly blow fell on by wile woman meddling instead of dividing land be divided from nobleman be still well to do though crippled in expenditure a for cousin be left beggar with many to beg from thought that other have wronged that trouble of law befell through unjust petition many friend advised to make interest at court for having done harm whatever being good catholic lord lorne be not must be sure to find hearing there probably favour like very hot brained man although have long be married to daughter of cousin whom liked none more for must have nothing to say to attempt at making patch of drove away with wife son relic of money swearing hard at everybody in may have be quite wrong probably perhaps be so be not convinced at what most of must have done same say that in bitterness of wrong outrage slew gentleman of court whom supposed to have borne hand in plundering of fortune others say that bearded king charles first in manner beyond forgiveness one thing at rate be sure sir ensor be attainted made felon outlaw through violent deed ensuing upon dispossession have searched in many quarter for somebody to help with good warrant for hoping inasmuch a in lucky day have be open handed cousinly to who begged advice of now provided with plenty of good advice indeed great assurance of feeling not movement of leg lip purse string in favour good people of persuasion royalty commonalty knowing kitchen range to be cold longer must play turnspit may be seared heart more than loss of land fame in great despair at last resolved to settle in outlandish part where none must be found to know so in evil day for came to west of england not that part of world be at outlandish according to view of for never found better one that be known to be rugged large desolate here when have discovered place seemed almost to be made for so withdrawn so self defended uneasy of access of country folk around brought little offering side of bacon keg of cider hung mutton brisket of venison so for little while be very honest when newness of coming began to wear away good folk be apt to think that even gentleman ought to work pay other men for doing many farmer be grown weary of manner without discourse to cried out to one how unfair be that owning fertile valley young men must not spade plough by reason of noble lineage then young doones growing up took thing must not ask for here let a solid man owner of five hundred acre whether fenced otherwise be own business churchwarden also of parish until go to churchyard proud to be called parson friend for better man never knew with tobacco strong water one who must read lesson so well have be at blundell too once for let declare that be thorough going church state man royalist without mistake about lay down because people judging sausage by skin may take in evil part little gloss of style glibness mottled nature of remark crack now then on frying pan assure be good inside not bit of rue in only queer knot a of marjoram stupid manner of bursting there be not more than dozen of counting few retainer who still held by sir ensor soon grew multiplied in manner surprising to think of whether be venison call strengthening victual whether be exmoor mutton keen soft air of moorland anyhow doones increased much faster than honesty at first have brought lady with of good repute with charity then a time went on added to stock by carrying carried off many good farmer daughter who be sadly displeased at first took to kindly after awhile made new home in baby for woman a seems to like strong men looking more than tailor like enough must meet man for man if chose around crown skirt of exmoor show what cross buttock mean because be so stuggy in regard of stature comeliness bearing woman must look twice at not what john ridd one two know of becomes best not to talk of although hair be gray perhaps den might well have be stormed driven out of forest if honest people have only agreed to clutched child man turned pale at very name of doone for son grandson of sir ensor grew up in foul liberty haughtiness hatred to utter scorn of god man brutality towards dumb animal there be only one bank of whortle berry just rode back to lonely hamlet where have taken death wound man woman be left in morning house for to dwell in only child with reason gone vile deed be done beyond doubt affair best of except when broke out sometimes about good master have lost one of fowl must take notice of except to cluck for barley maiden though have liked well be thinking of sweetheart a spring came on where bee be grindstone somehow must never let anybody behold being set a may say to think over by herself season with weeping many time caught many time turned upon then must not look at asked how long to dinner time now in depth of winter month such a call december father being dead quiet in grave fortnight happened to be out of powder for practice against enemy have never fired shot without thinking 'this for father murderer ' john fry said that made such face be wonder gun went off though must hardly hold gun unless with back against bar did good to hear go off hope to have hitten enemy mother mother ' said that day directly after dinner while be sitting looking at almost ready to say a now did seven time in week like father be growing jack come here kiss ' 'oh mother if only knew how much want shilling ' 'jack will never want shilling while be alive to give thee one what be for dear heart dear heart buy something over at porlock mother perhaps will tell afterwards if tell not will be for good for sake of child 'bless boy one must think be threescore year of age at least give little kiss jack will have shilling ' for hated to kiss be kissed in day so all honest boy must do when god put strength in now wanted powder so much that went kissed mother very shyly looking round corner first for betty not to see gave dozen only one shilling for of must not find in heart to ask for although must have taken in very quick time ran away with shilling in pocket got peggy out on porlock road without mother knowing for mother be frightened of road now a if tree be murderer must never let go alone so much a hundred yard on to tell truth be touched with fear for many year about even now when ride at dark there man by peat rick make shiver until go collar time be very bold having john fry blunderbuss keeping sharp look out wherever lurking place be however saw only sheep small red cattle common deer of forest until be nigh to porlock town then rode straight to mr pooke at sign of spit gridiron mr pooke be asleep a happened not having much to do day so fastened peggy by handle of warming pan at have better manner than to snort blow breath in walked with manful style bearing john fry blunderbuss now timothy pooke be peaceful man glad to live without enjoyment of mind at danger be tall large already a most lad of riper age mr pooke a soon a opened eye dropped suddenly under counting board drew great frying pan over head a if doones be come to rob a custom be mostly after fair time made feel rather hot queer to be taken for robber yet methinks be proud of 'gadzooks master pooke ' said having learned fine word at tiverton 'do suppose know not then way to carry firearm be old spanish match lock in lieu of good flint engine may be borne ten mile more never once go off scarcely couldst thou seem more scared might point at thee muzzle on just so a do now even for hour more like enough must never shoot thee unless pulled trigger hard with crock upon finger so see just so master pooke only trifle harder 'god sake john ridd god sake dear boy cried pooke knowing by time ' e for good love now e show to boy a if be to suck put down for good now thee will have very best of be in shop 'ho replied with much contempt swinging round gun so that fetched hoop of candle down unkindled a be 'ho a if have not attained to handling of gun yet hand be cold coming over moor else must go bail to point mouth at for hour sir cause for uneasiness ' in spite of assurance showed desirous only to see last of gun dare say 'villainous saltpetre a great playwright call be never so cheap before since for shilling master pooke afforded two great package over large to go into pocket a well a mighty chunk of lead bound upon peggy withers a if have not be enough presented with roll of comfit for sister annie whose gentle face pretty manner won love of everybody there be still daylight here there a rose hill above porlock wondering whether mother must be in fright must not know two great package of powder slung behind back knocked so hard against one feared must either spill blow up hurry over peggy ear from woollen cloth rode upon for father always liked horse to have wool upon loin whenever went far from home have to stand about where one pleased hot wet panting father always said that saddle be meant for men full grown heavy losing activity boy young man on farm durst ever get into saddle because knew that master must chuck out pretty quickly a for have tried once from kind of curiosity must not walk for two three day leather galled knee so now a peggy bore bravely snorting now then into cloud of air for night be growing frosty presently moon arose over shoulder of hill pony be half glad to see half afraid of shadow threw image around be ready at moment to shoot at anybody having great faith in blunderbuss hoping not to prove a passed narrow place where doones have killed father fear broke out upon that leaned upon neck of peggy shut eye be cold over however there be not soul to be seen until came home to old farmyard there be mother cry sadly betty muxworthy scolding 'come along now ' whispered to annie moment supper be over if can hold tongue annie will show something ' lifted on bench so quickly flushed so rich with pleasure be obliged to stare hard away make betty look beyond betty thought have something hid in closet beyond clock case be more convinced of by reason of denial not that betty muxworthy one else for matter ever found in falsehood because never told one not even to mother be still stronger thing not even to sweetheart when grew up to have one that betty being wronged in matter of marriage generation two agone by man who came hedging ditching have now no mercy except to believe that men from cradle to grave be liar woman fool to look at when betty must find crime of mine knocked out of way in minute a if have be nobody then began to coax beistress annie a always called draw soft hair down hand whisper into little ear meanwhile dear mother be falling asleep having be troubled so much about watch father pet dog be nodding closer closer up into lap annie will come ' said for wanted to hold ladle for melting of lead come at once annie must go for lizzie let see whole of ' 'indeed then wo do ' said annie 'lizzie to come before john ca stir pot of brewis scarce know tongue from ham then suddenly felt fresh air fell into headlong chapter viii boy girl when came to myself again hand be full of young grass mould little girl kneeling at side be rubbing forehead tenderly with dock place like home can assure tell lie a john fry always used to say when telling very largest that scrambled back to mouth of pit a if evil one have be after sorely repented now of boyish folly madness might well be termed in venturing with none to help nothing to compel into accursed valley once let get out think if ever get in again without being cast in by neck by crop will give new born donkey leave to set up for schoolmaster how kept resolution will see hereafter be enough for now to tell how escaped from den night first sat down in little opening lorna have pointed out to wondered whether have meant a bitterly occurred to must run down into pit be drowned give more trouble in le than minute be ashamed of idea remembered how be vexed to think that even loach must lose life then said to myself 'now surely must value more than thousand loach what said must be quite true about way out of horrible place therefore began to search with utmost care diligence although teeth be chattering bone beginning to ache with chilliness wetness before very long moon appeared over edge of mountain among tree at top of then espied rough step rocky made a if with sledge hammer narrow steep far asunder scooped here there in side of entrance then round bulge of cliff like mark upon great brown loaf where hungry child have picked at higher up where light of moon shone broader upon precipice there seemed to be rude broken track like shadow of crooked stick thrown upon house wall herein be small encouragement at first be minded to lie down die seemed to come amiss to god have time for of seems to advertise when doe not mean to do moreover saw movement of light at head of valley a if lanthorns be coming after nimbleness given thereon to heel be in front of meditation straightway set foot in lowest stirrup a might almost call clung to rock with nail worked to make jump into second stirrup compassed that too with aid of stick although to tell truth be not at time of life so agile a boy of smaller frame be for size be growing beyond year muscle not keeping time with joint of bone not closely hinged with staring at one third step hole be hardest of rock swelled out on over breast there seemed to be attempting until espied good stout rope hanging in groove of shadow just managed to reach end of how clomb up across clearing found way home through bagworthy forest be more than can remember now for took rest of then a dream by reason of perfect weariness indeed be quite beyond hope to tell so much a have told for at first beginning to set down be like mist before nevertheless part grew clearer a one by one remembered having taken little soft cordial because memory frightens for toil of water danger of labouring up long cascade rapid then surprise of fair young maid terror of murderer desperation of getting away be much to even now when be stout churchwarden sit by side of fire after going through many far worse adventure will tell god willing only labour of writing be such especially so a to construe challenge reader on part of speech hope to be even with by pipe hold in hand ever expect to be beaten a in day when old doctor twiggs if made bad stroke in exercise shouted aloud with sour joy ridd sirrah down with small clothes let be a may deserved good beating night after making such fool of myself grinding good fustian to piece when got home supper be in men sitting at white table mother annie lizzie near by eager offering to begin except indeed mother who be looking out at doorway by fire be betty muxworthy scolding cooking tasting work in breath a man must say looked through door from dark by wood stack be half of mind to stay out like dog for fear of rating reckoning way dear mother be looking about browning of sausage got better of nobody must get out of where have be day evening although worried never so much longed to shake to piece especially betty muxworthy who never must learn to let well alone not that made tell lie although must have served right almost for intruding on other people business just held tongue ate supper rarely let try taunt jibe drove almost wild after supper by smiling exceeding knowingly indeed must have told thing a hinted once twice then poor betty little lizzie be so mad with eagerness between went into fire being thoroughly overcome with laughter own importance now what working of mind be if indeed worked at did not rather follow suit of body be not in power to say only that result of adventure in doone glen be to make dream good deal of night have never done much before to drive with tenfold zeal purpose to practice of bullet shooting not that ever expected to shoot doone family one by one even desired to do so for nature be not revengeful that seemed to be somehow business to understand gun a thing must be at home with must hit barn door now capitally well with spanish match lock even with john fry blunderbuss at ten good land yard distance without rest for fusil what be very wrong of though did not see then kept john fry there to praise shot from dinner time often until grey dusk while time must have be at work spring ploughing upon farm for matter so must have be at rate driving horse john be by mean loath to be there instead of holding plough tail indeed one of old saying be for pleasure sake must liefer wet than have ' ten lump of gold for one of sweat again be not bad proverb though unthrifty unlike scotsman god make wheat grow greener while farmer be at dinner devonshire man somerset belong to of ever think of working harder than god like to see nevertheless worked hard at gun by time have sent church roof gutter so far a honestly must cut through red pine door began to long for better tool must make le noise throw straighter sheep shearing came hay season next then harvest of small corn digging of root called 'batata new good thing in neighbourhood folk have made into 'taties then sweating of apple turning of cider press stacking of firewood netting of woodcock springles to be minded in garden by hedgerow where blackbird hop to molehill in white october morning grey bird come to look for snail at time when sun be rising be wonderful how time run away when thing great many others come in to load down hill prevent from stopping to look about for part can never conceive how people who live in town city where lamb bird be except in shop window growing corn meadow grass even so much a stick to cut stile to climb sit down upon how poor folk get through life without being utterly weary of dying from pure indolence be thing god only know if mercy allows to think of how year went by know not only that be abroad day shooting fishing minding farm riding after stray beast away by seaside below glenthorne wondering at great water resolving to go for sailor for in day have firm belief a many other strong boy have of being born for seaman indeed have be in boat nearly twice second time mother found out came drew back again after cried so badly be forced to give word to to go more without telling betty muxworthy spoke mind quite in different way about while be wringing hosen clattering to drying horse 'zailor ee fai ay zarve un raight ca kape out o ' watter here whur ' must goo vor to vaind un zame a gurt to ad squalloping mux up till be wore out be wi ' very saight of braiches how wil un ever baide aboard zhip wi ' watter zinging out under un comin ' up splash when wind blow latt un goo missus latt un goo zay for wan old davy wash clout for un discourse of betty tended more than mother prayer fear to keep from going for hated betty in day a child always hate cross servant often get fond of false one betty like many active woman be false by crossness only thinking just for moment perhaps rushing away with bucket ready to stick to like clenched nail if beaten wrong way with argument melting over if left a stinging soap left along in basin spread abroad without bubbling be beyond child beyond too for matter even now in ripe experience for never did know what woman mean never will except when tell if be in power now let that question pas for although be now in place of authority have observed that one ever listens to when attempt to lay down law be waiting with open ear until do enforce so methinks who read history care not much for wisdom folly of writer knowing well that former be far le than own latter vastly greater hurry to know what people did how got on about can tell if one can having be in thick of fright have taken that night in glen doone satisfied for long time thereafter took good care not to venture even in field wood of outer farm without john fry for company john be greatly surprised pleased at value now set upon until what betwixt desire to vaunt longing to talk thing over gradually laid bare to nearly have befallen except indeed about lorna whom sort of shame kept from mentioning not that did not think of wish very often to see again of course be only boy a yet therefore inclined to despise young girl a being unable to do anything only meant to listen to order when got along with other boy be how always spoke of if deigned to speak at a being of lower order only good enough to run errand for to nurse boy baby yet sister annie be in truth great deal more to than boy of parish of brendon countisbury put together although at time never dreamed must have laughed if told so annie be of pleasing face very gentle manner almost like lady people said without air only trying to give satisfaction if failed must go weep without letting one know believing fault to be own when mostly be of others if succeeded in pleasing be beautiful to see smile stroke soft chin in way of own always used when taking note how to do right thing again for then cheek have bright clear pink eye be a blue a sky in spring stood a upright a young apple tree one must help smile at pat brown curl approvingly whereupon always curtseyed for never tried to look away when honest people gazed at even in court yard must come help to take saddle tell without asking what there be for dinner afterwards grew up to be very comely maiden tall with well built neck very fair white shoulder under bright cloud of curling hair ala poor annie like most of gentle maiden tush be not come to yet for present seemed to little to look at after beauty of lorna doone chapter x brave rescue rough ride happened upon november evening when be about fifteen year old out growing strength very rapidly sister annie being turned thirteen deal of rain having fallen trough in yard being flooded bark from wood rick washed down gutter even water shoot going brown that duck in court made terrible quacking instead of marching off to pen one behind thereupon annie ran out to see what might be sense of there be thirteen duck ten lily white a fashion then of duck be not mean twenty three in ten white three brown striped one without being nice about colour quacked very movingly pushed gold coloured bill here there yet dirty a gold be apt to be jumped on triangle of foot sounded out of nostril of over excited one ran along low on ground quacking grievously with bill snapping bending roof of mouth exhibited annie began to cry 'dilly dilly einy einy ducksey ' according to burden of tune seem to have accepted a national duck anthem instead of being soothed by only quacked three time a hard ran round till be giddy then shook tail together looked grave went round round again now be uncommonly fond of duck roasted roasting roystering be fine sight to behold walk poddling one after other with toe out like soldier drilling little eye cocked way at once way that dib with bill dabble throw up head enjoy something then tell others about therefore knew at once by way be carrying on that there must be something other gone wholly amiss in duck world sister annie perceived too with greater quickness for counted like good duck wife must only tell thirteen of when knew there ought to be fourteen so began to search about duck ran to lead aright having come that far to fetch when got down to foot of court yard where two great ash tree stand by side of little water found good reason for urgence melancholy of duck bird lo old white drake father of bird of high manner chivalry always last to help from pan of barley meal first to show fight to dog cock intruding upon family fine fellow pillar of state be now in sad predicament yet quacking very stoutly for brook wherewith have be familiar from callow childhood wherein be wont to quest for water newt tadpole caddis worm other game brook afforded very often scanty space to dabble in sometimes starved cress be now coming down in great brown flood a if bank never belonged to foaming of noise cresting of corner up down like wave of sea be enough to frighten duck though bred upon stormy water duck never have be there be always hurdle six foot long four half in depth swung by chain at end from oak laid across channel use of hurdle be to keep kine at milking time from straying away there drinking for in truth be very dainty to fence strange cattle farmer snowe horse from coming along bed of brook unknown to steal substance now hurdle hung in summer foot above trickle must have be dipped more than two foot deep for power against for torrent came down so vehemently that chain at full stretch be creaking hurdle buffeted almost flat thatched so to say with drift stuff be going see saw with sulky splash on dirty red comb of water saddest to see be between two bar where fog be of rush flood wood wild celery haulm dead crowsfoot who venerable mallard jammed in by joint of shoulder speaking aloud a rose fell with top knot full of water unable to comprehend with tail washed far away from often compelled to be silent being ducked very harshly against will by choking fall to of hurdle for moment must not help laughing because being borne up high dry by tumult of torrent gave look from one little eye having lost one in fight with turkey cock gaze of appealing sorrow then loud quack to second quack came out of time suppose for throat got filled with water a hurdle carried back again then there be scarcely screw of tail to be seen until swung up again left small doubt by way sputtered failed to quack hung down poor crest what must drown in minute frog triumph over body annie be cry wringing hand be about to rush into water although liked not look of hoped to hold on by hurdle when man on horseback came suddenly round corner of great ash hedge on other side of stream horse foot be in water there ' cried 'get thee back boy flood will carry thee down like straw will do for thee trouble ' with leaned forward spoke to mare be just of tint of strawberry young thing very beautiful arched up neck a misliking job yet trusting must attempt entered flood with dainty fore leg sloped further further in front of delicate ear pricked forward size of great eye increasing kept straight in turbid rush by pressure of knee on then looked back wondered at a force of torrent grew stronger bade go on on went foamed up over shoulder tossed up lip scorned for now courage be waking then a rush of swept away struck with forefoot down stream leaned from saddle in manner never must have thought possible caught up old tom with left hand set between holster smiled at faint quack of gratitude in moment be carried downstream rider lay flat on horse tossed hurdle clear from made for bend of smooth water landed thirty forty yard lower in midst of kitchen garden where winter cabbage be though annie crept in through hedge be full of thanks admiring must answer never word until have spoken in full to mare a if explaining whole to beweetheart know thou couldst have leaped ' said a patted cheek being on ground by time be nudging up to with water pattering off 'but have good reason winnie dear for making thee go through ' answered kindly with soft eye smiled at very lovingly understood one then took from waistcoat two peppercorn made old drake swallow tried softly upon leg where leading gap in hedge be old tom stood up quite bravely clapped wing shook off wet from tail feather then away into court yard family gathered around made noise in throat stood up put bill together to thank god for great deliverance having taken trouble watched end of adventure gentleman turned round to with pleasant smile on face a if be lightly amused with came up looked at be rather short about john fry height may be little taller very strongly built springy a gait at step showed plainly although leg be bowed with much riding looked a if lived on horseback to boy like seemed very old being over twenty well found in beard be not more than four twenty fresh ruddy looking with short nose keen blue eye merry waggish jerk about a if world be not in earnest yet have sharp stern way like crack of pistol if anything misliked knew for child see such thing that be safer to tickle than buffet 'well young un what be gaping at ' gave pretty annie chuck on chin took in without winking 'your mare ' said standing stoutly up being tall boy now never saw such beauty sir will let have ride of thou couldst ride lad will have burden mine thou couldst never ride tut must be loath to kill thee ' 'ride cried with bravest scorn for looked so kind gentle 'there never be horse upon exmoor foaled must tackle in hour only never ride upon saddle take leather off of looked at with dry little whistle thrust hand into breech pocket so grinned must not stand annie laid hold of in way be almost mad with laughed approved for doing so worst of be said nothing 'get away annie will do think be fool good sir only trust with will not override ' will go bail son be liker to override thee ground be soft to fall upon after rain now come out into yard young man for sake of mother cabbage mellow straw bed will be softer for thee since pride must have fall be thy mother cousin boy be going up to house tom faggus be name a everybody know be young mare winnie ' what fool must have be not to know at once tom faggus great highwayman young blood mare strawberry already fame be noised abroad nearly a much a master longing to ride grew tenfold fear came at back of not that have smallest fear of what mare must do to by fair play horse trickery that glory of sitting upon seemed to be too great for especially a there be rumour abroad that be not mare after witch however looked like filly over wonderfully beautiful with supple stride soft slope of shoulder glossy coat beaded with water prominent eye full of docile fire whether came from eastern blood of arab newly imported whether cream colour mixed with bay led to bright strawberry tint be certainly more than can decide being chiefly acquaint with farm horse come of colour form never can count what will be be lucky to get four leg to mr faggus gave mare wink walked demurely after bright young thing flowing over with life yet dropping soul to higher one led by love to anything a manner be of female when know what be best for then winnie trod lightly upon straw because have soft muck under delicate foot came back again 'up for still boy be ye tom faggus stopped mare stopped there looked at provokingly 'be able to leap sir there be good take off on side of brook mr faggus laughed very quietly turning round to winnie so that might enter into for part seemed to know exactly where fun lay tumble off mean boy well there can be small harm to thee be akin to thy family know substance of skull get up ' said waxing wroth for reason can not tell because be too manifold 'take off saddle bag thing will try not to squeeze rib in unless play nonsense with ' then mr faggus be up on mettle at proud speech of mine john fry be running up while bill dadds dozen tom faggus gave one glance around then dropped regard for high repute of mare be at stake what be life compared to through defiance stupid way here be in duello leg not come to strength yet arm a limp a herring something of occurred to even in wrath with for spoke very softly to filly who now must scarce subdue drew in nostril breathed to breath did must to answer 'not too hard dear ' said 'led gently down on mixen will be quite enough ' then turned saddle off be up in moment began at first so easily pricked ear so lovingly minced about a if pleased to find so light weight upon thought knew must ride little feared to show caper wug polly cried for men be now looking on being then at leaving off time 'gee wug polly show what thou be'est made of ' with plugged heel into billy dadds flung hat up nevertheless outraged not though eye be frightening annie john fry took pick to keep safe curbed to fro with strong forearm rising like spring ingathered waiting quivering grievously beginning to sweat about then master gave shrill clear whistle when ear be bent towards felt form beneath gathering up like whalebone hind leg coming under knew be in for first reared upright in air struck full on nose with comb till bled worse than robin snell made then down with fore foot deep in straw hind foot going to heaven finding stick to still like wax for mettle be up a hers be away flew with swifter than ever went before since trow drove full head at cobwall jack slip off ' screamed annie then turned like light when thought to crush ground left knee against beux ' cried for breech be broken short word went furthest kill will die with ' then took court yard gate at leap knocking word between teeth then right over quick set hedge a if sky be breath to away for water meadow while lay on neck like child at breast wished have never be born straight away in front of wind scattering cloud around knew of speed made be frightful flash of shoulder mane like tree in tempest felt earth under rushing away air left far behind breath came went prayed to god be sorry to be so late of long swift while without power of thought clung to crest shoulder dug nail into crease toe into flank part be proud of holding on so long though sure of being beaten then in fury at feeling still rushed at device for leaped wide water trough sideways across to fro till breath be left in hazel bough took too hard in face tall dog brier got hold of ache of back be like crimping fish till longed to give up thoroughly beaten lie there die in cress there came shrill whistle from up home hill where people have hurried to watch mare stopped a if with bullet then set off for home with speed of swallow going a smoothly silently never have dreamed of such delicate motion fluent graceful ambient soft a breeze flitting over flower swift a summer lightning sat up again strength be spent time left to recover though rose at gate like bird tumbled off into mixen chapter xi tom deserves supper 'well done lad ' mr faggus said good naturedly for be now gathered round a rose from ground somewhat tottering miry crest fallen otherwise none worse having fallen upon head be of uncommon substance nevertheless john fry be laughing so that longed to clout ear for 'not at bad work boy may teach to ride by by see thought not to see stick on so long ' must have stuck on much longer sir if side have not be wet be so slippery ' thou art right hath given many slip have have vex not jack that laugh at thee be like sweetheart to better than of be must have gone to heart if thou hadst conquered none can ride winnie mare ' shame to thee then tom faggus cried mother coming up suddenly speaking so that be amazed having never seen wrathful 'to put boy boy across a if life be more than thine only son of father honest man quiet man not roystering drunken robber man must have taken thy mad horse thee flung into horse pond ay what be more will have done now if hair of head be injured oh boy boy what must do without thee put up other arm johnny ' time mother be scolding so be feeling wiping while faggus tried to look greatly ashamed having sense of way of woman 'only look at jacket mother ' cried annie 'and shillingsworth gone from small clothes care for clothes thou goose take heed thine own bit mother gave annie slap sent swinging up against mr faggus caught kissed protected looked at very nicely with great tear in soft blue eye fie upon thee fie upon thee ' cried mother being yet more vexed with because have beaten annie 'after have done for thee saved thy worthless neck to try to kill son for never more will horse of thine enter stable here since be thy return to small thanks to john fry say bill dadds jem slocomb rest of coward lot how quiet be day by day how pleasant to be cheated men began to shoulder shovel so a to be away from to go tell wife of winnie too be looking at being pointed at so much wondering if have done amiss then came to trembled stooped head asked pardon if have be too proud with 'winnie will stop here to night ' said for tom faggus still said never word while began to buckle thing on for knew that woman be to be met with wool a cannon ball be at siege of tiverton castle tell winnie will stop else will go away with never knew what be till now to ride horse worth riding ' 'young man ' said tom faggus still preparing sternly to depart 'you know more about horse than man on exmoor mother may well be proud of need have have fear a if tom faggus father cousin only thing be proud of must ever have let mount mare duke prince have vainly sought except for courage in eye look of father about knew must ride when saw rarely have conquered woman understand good bye john be proud of hoped to have done pleasure indeed came full of courtly tale must have made hair stand up though not crust have tasted since time yesterday having given meat to widow will go starve on moor far sooner than eat best supper that ever be cooked in place have forgotten ' with fetched heavy sigh a if have be for father feebly got upon winnie back came to say farewell to lifted hat to mother with glance of sorrow never word to said 'open gate cousin john if please have beaten so that can not leap poor thing ' before be truly gone out of yard mother came softly after with afternoon apron across eye one hand ready to offer nevertheless made a if have not seen though let horse go slowly betop cousin tom mother said ' word with before go ' bless heart ' tom faggus cried with form of countenance so changed that verily thought man must have leaped into clothes see cousin sarah thought one be ashamed of afraid to offer shelter since lost best cousin john ridd here ' used to say 'tom come here when be worried wife will take good care of ' 'yes dear john ' used to answer ' know promised mother so people have taken to think against so might cousin sarah ' ah be man man if only heard how answered let though father have be dead so long looked on with stupid surprise having stopped from cry long ago can tell one will ' cried tom jumping off winnie in trice looking kindly at mother ' can allow for cousin sarah in everything one be in way bad man know value of good one if gave order by god ' shook fist towards bagworthy wood just heaving up black in sundown tom hush for god sake ' mother meant without pointing at at least thought did for ever have weaned from thought of revenge even from longing for judgment 'god know best boy ' used to say 'let wait time without wishing ' so to tell truth did partly through teaching partly through own mild temper knowledge that father after be killed because have thrashed 'good night cousin sarah good night cousin jack ' cried tom taking to mare again beany mile have to ride not bit inside of food shelter side of exeford night will be black a pitch trow serf right for indulging lad being taken with look so 'cousin tom ' said mother trying to get so that annie must not hear 'it must be sad unkinlike thing for to despise dwelling house can not entertain a lordly inn on road do have small change of victual men will go home being saturday so will have fireside to child there be few collops of red deer flesh ham just down from chimney dried salmon from lynmouth weir cold roast pig oyster if none of be to liking must roast two woodcock in hour annie must make toast for good folk made mistake last week going up country left keg of old holland cordial in coving of wood rick having borrowed smiler without asking leave fear there be something unrighteous about what can poor widow do john fry must have taken for jack jack be little too sharp for ' ay be john fry have got like billet under apron going away in gray of morning a if to kindle make stop rub john ' said be got log with round hole in end of who have be cutting gun wad just lift apron will ' to return to tom faggus stopped to sup night with took little of everything few oyster first then dried salmon then ham egg done in small curled rasher then few collops of venison toasted next to little cold roast pig woodcock on toast to finish with before scheidam hot water having changed wet thing first seemed to be in fair appetite praised annie cooking mightily with kind of noise like smack of lip rubbing of hand together whenever must spare have gotten john fry best small clothes on for said be not good enough to go into father mother kept to look at man enough to fill in truth mother be very glad that refused when offered john be over proud to have in power to say that famous man have ever dwelt in clothes of afterwards made show of for mr faggus glory then though not so great a now be be spreading very fast indeed about neighbourhood even a far a bridgewater tom faggus be jovial soul if ever there have be one not making bone of little thing caring to seek evil there be about love of genuine human nature that if traveller said good thing must give back purse again be true that took people money more by force than fraud law being used to inverse method be bitterly moved against although must quote precedent thing understand having seen so much of robbery legal illegal that scarcely know a here say one crow foot from other be beyond above to discus subject in truth love law right well when doth support when can lay down to liking with prejudice to nobody loyal too to king be a behoves churchwarden ready to make best of a generally requires after must not see until grew much older came to have property why tom faggus working hard be called robber felon of great while king doing nothing at a became dignity be liege lord paramount owner with everybody to thank kindly for accepting tribute for present however learned nothing more a to what cousin profession be only that mother seemed frightened whispered to now then not to talk of something because of child being there whereupon always nodded with sage expression applied to holland let go see winnie jack said to after supper 'for most part feed before myself be so hot from way drove now must be grieving for never let grieve long ' be too glad to go with annie came slyly after filly be walking to fro on naked floor of stable for must not let have straw until must make bed for without so much a headstall on for must not have fastened 'do take mare for dog have said when john fry
