caught by waistband lifted clean from ground be casting down to trample upon when stopped suddenly 'what think of boy have horse dog must do for ay more than will do if be to whistle by by in tone tell danger must break stable door down rush into room to nothing will keep from then stone wall church tower ah winnie winnie little witch will die together then turned away with joke began to feed nicely for be very dainty not husk of oat must touch have be under breath of horse however hungry might be with oat mixed powder fetching from saddle bag what be must not guess neither must tell laughed called betar shaving watched eat morsel of with two three drink of pure water ministered between while then made bed in form have never seen before so said 'good night ' to afterwards by fireside kept very merry sitting in great chimney corner making play game with while be smoking tobacco in manner never have seen before not using pipe for having rolled in little stick about a long a finger blunt at one end sharp at other sharp end must put in mouth lay brand of wood to other then draw white cloud of curling smoke never tired of watching wanted to let do said son be not meant for boy then annie put up lip asked with hand on knee for have taken to wonderfully 'be meant for girl then cousin tom ' have better not have asked for gave to try shut eye sucked at one breath however be quite enough for made cough so violently that lizzie must thump back until be almost cry to atone for cousin tom set to told whole page of story not about own doings at strangely enough seemed to concern almost one else have ever heard of without halting once for word deed tale flowed onward a freely brightly a flame of wood up chimney with smaller variety for spoke with voice of twenty people giving person proper manner proper place to speak from so that annie lizzie ran about searched clock linen press changed face moment so with such power of mimicry that without so much a smile of own made even mother laugh so that broke new tenpenny waistband a for child rolled on floor betty muxworthy roared in wash up chapter xii man justly popular now although mr faggus be so clever generous celebrated know not whether upon whole be rather proud of a member of family inclined to be ashamed of indeed think that sway of balance hung upon company be in for instance with boy at brendon for there be village at oare be exceeding proud to talk of must freely brag of cousin tom with rich parson of neighbourhood justice who came round now then be glad to ride up to warm farm house even well to do tradesman of porlock in word settled power be afraid of losing thing with of be very shy of claiming kinship to great outlaw sure must pity a well a condemn though way in world be so different knowing a do story knowledge methinks must often lead to let alone god prerogative judgment hold by man privilege pity not must find excuse for tom downright dishonesty be beyond doubt disgrace to credit to kinsfolk only that came about without meaning harm seeing how took to wrong yet gradually knowing now to save further trouble to meet who disparage without allowance for time cross laid upon will tell history of just a if be not cousin hoping to be heeded defy man to say that word of be false in way coloured by family much cause have to be harsh with world yet acknowledged very pleasant when man gave up money often often paid toll for carriage coming after because have emptied pocket must not add inconvenience by trade have be blacksmith in town of northmolton in devonshire rough rude place at end of exmoor so that many people marvelled if such man be bred there not only must read write have solid substance piece of land worth hundred pound right of common for two hundred sheep score half of beast lifting up lying down being left orphan with care upon began to work right early made fame at shoeing of horse that farrier of barum be like to lose custom indeed won golden jacobus for best shod nag in north of devon say that never be forgiven a to know more except that men be jealous whether be that not fell into bitter trouble within month of victory when trade be growing upon sweetheart ready to marry for loved maid of southmolton currier daughter think be name be betsy paramore father have given consent tom faggus wishing to look best be clean of course have tailor at work upstairs for who have come way from exeter betsy thing be ready too for accused afterwards a if must help when suddenly like thunderbolt lawyer writ fell upon be beginning of law suit with sir robert bampfylde gentleman of neighbourhood who tried to oust from common drove cattle harassed by suit of law poor tom be ruined altogether for sir robert must pay for much swearing then good farm be sold up even smithery taken saddled horse before must catch rode away to southmolton looking more like madman than good farrier a people said who saw when arrived there instead of comfort showed face of door alone for news of loss be before master paramore be sound prudent man high member of town council be said that even gave notice to pay for betsy wedding clothes now that be too poor to marry may be false indeed doubt in first place because southmolton be busy place for talking in next think action must have lain at law especially a maid lost nothing used for wedding next month with dick vellacott of mockham be very sore upon tom took to heart so grievously that said a better man might have said being loose of mind property 'the world hath preyed on like wolf god help now to prey on world in did seem for while a if providence be with for took rare toll on highway name be soon a good a gold anywhere side of bristowe studied business by night by day with three horse in hard work until have made fine reputation then be competent to to rest have plenty left for charity ought to say for society too for truly loved high society treating squire nobleman who much affected company to very best fare of hostel say once king justitiaries being upon circuit accepted invitation declaring merrily that if never true bill have be found against mine host must now be qualified to draw one so landlord did always paid handsomely so that of be kind to contended for visit let be known in township mr faggus be taking leisure at inn straightway men flocked thither to drink health without outlay woman to admire while child be set at cross road to give warning of officer one of earliest meeting be with sir robert bampfylde who be riding along barum road with only one serving man after tom faggus put pistol to head being then obliged to be violent through want of reputation while serving man pretended to be along way round corner then baronet pulled out purse quite trembling in hurry of politeness tom took purse ring time piece then handed back with very low bow saying that be against usage for to rob robber then turned to unfaithful knave trounced right well for cowardice stripped of property now mr faggus kept only one horse lest government must steal that one be young mare winnie how came by never must tell think that be presented to by certain colonel lover of sport very clever in horseflesh whose life tom have saved from gambler when have added that faggus a yet have never be guilty of bloodshed for eye click of pistol at first now high reputation made wish respected that never robbed poor man neither insulted woman be very good to church of hot patriotic opinion full of jest jollity have said a much a be fair for shown why be so popular everybody cursed doones who lived apart disdainfully good people liked mr faggus when have not robbed many poor sick man woman blessed for other people money hostler stable boy tapster entirely worshipped have be rather long perhaps tedious in account of lest at time hereafter character must be misunderstood good name disparaged whereas be second cousin lover of let bide 't be melancholy story came again about three month afterwards in beginning of spring time brought beautiful new carbine having learned love of such thing great desire to shoot straight mother must not let have gun until averred upon honour that have bought honestly so have doubt so far a be honest to buy with money acquired rampantly scarce must stop to make bullet in mould came along with must be off to quarry hill new target have made there taught then how to ride bright winnie who be grown since have seen remembered most kindly after making much of annie who have wondrous liking for said be godfather god know how must have be unless confirmed precociously away went young winnie side shone like cherry by candlelight now feel that of boyish day have little more to tell because everything went quietly a world for most part doe with began to work at farm in earnest tried to help mother when remembered lorna doone seemed no more than thought of dream must hardly call to mind now who care to know how many bushel of wheat grew to acre how cattle milched till ate what turn of season be stupid self seemed like to be biggest of cattle for having much to look after sheep being always in kind appetite grew four inch longer in year of farming matter of two inch wider until there be man of size to be seen elsewhere upon exmoor let pas what odds to how tall wide be there be doone door at plover barrow if there be must never go through vexed so much about size long before have completed girding at with paltry joke whose wit be good only to stay at home that grew shame faced about matter feared to encounter looking glass mother be very proud said never must have too much of worst of to make ashamed of bearing head so high thing saw way to help for never must hang chin down back be like gatepost tried to bend worst of be little eliza who never must come to size though have wine from sacrament at easter allhallowmas only to be small skinny sharp clever crookedly not that body be out of straight being too small for perhaps that wit be full of corner jagged strange uncomfortable never must tell what might say next like not that kind of woman now god forgive for talking so of own father daughter so much more by reason that father must not help right way be to face matter then be sorry for one mother fell grievously on slide john fry have made nigh apple room door hidden with straw from stable to cover own great idleness father laid john nose on ice kept warm in spite of be too late for eliza be born next day with more mind than body worst thing can befall man annie other sister be now fine fair girl beautiful to behold must look at by fireside for hour together when be not too sleepy think of dear father must do same thing by only wait between of blaze hair be done up in knot behind must fall over shoulder dancing of light be sweet to see through man eyelash there never be face showed light shadow of feeling a if heart be sun to more than dear annie did to look at carefully might think that be not dwelling on anything then must know be looking at eye must tell about god know that try to be simple enough to keep to meaning in not make worst of child yet often have be put to shame ready to bite tongue off after speaking amiss of anybody letting out littleness when suddenly mine eye have met pure soft gaze of annie a for doones be thriving still one to come against except indeed by word of mouth to lent heed complaint be made from time to time in high low quarter a rank might be of people robbed once twice in highest of to wit king majesty made good joke about not meaning harm doubt be so much pleased with thereupon that quite forgave mischief moreover main authority be long way off chancellor have cattle on exmoor a for lord chief justice rogue have taken silver spoon whereupon lordship swore never man must hang until have that one by neck therefore doones went on a listed none saw fit to meddle with for only man who must have dared to come to close quarter with be to say tom faggus be quarry for law if ever must be unhooded moreover have transferred business to neighbourhood of wantage in county of berk where found climate drier also good down common excellent for galloping richer yeoman than ours be better road to rob on folk who have wiser attended to own affair said that being sizeable now able to shoot not badly ought to do something against doones show what be made of for time be very bashful shaking when called upon suddenly blushing a deep a maiden for strength be not come upon mayhap have grown in front of again though loved father still must fire at word about saw not how must do good for to harm injurers race be of revengeful kind will for year pursue wrong sacrifice world next for moment foul satisfaction methinks come of black blood perverted never purified doubt men of true english birth be stouter than so to be twisted though of woman may take turn if own life run unkindly let that pas be never good at talking of thing beyond know be that if have met doone who have killed father must gladly have thrashed black blue supposing be able must never have fired gun at unless began that game with fell upon more of family be violent among woman to do justice mother annie be equally kind gentle eliza must flame grow white with contempt not trust to speak to now strange thing came to pas that winter when be twenty one year old very strange thing affrighted rest made feel uncomfortable not that there be anything in to do harm to one only that none must explain except by attributing to devil weather be very mild open scarcely snow fell at rate none lay on ground even for hour in highest part of exmoor thing knew not before since a long a can remember night be wonderfully dark a though with star in heaven day long mist be rolling upon hill down a if whole land be wash house moorland be full of snipe teal curlew flying cry lapwing flapping heavily raven hovering round dead sheep yet redshank dottrell scarce golden plover of have great store generally vast lonely bird cried at night moved whole air with pinion yet man ever saw be dismal a well a dangerous now for man to go fowling of late loved much in winter because fog must come down so thick that pan of gun be reeking fowl out of sight ere powder kindled then sound of piece be so dead that shooter feared harm glanced over shoulder danger of course be far le in than in losing of track falling into mire over brim of precipice nevertheless must need go out being young very stupid feared of being afraid fear wise man have long cast by having learned of manifold danger ever ever encompass beside folly wildness of youth perchance there be something know not what of joy have in uncertainty mother in fear of missing home though for matter must smell supper when hungry through hundred land yard of fog dear mother who thought of ten time for one thought about gave order to ring great sheep bell hung above pigeon cote ten minute of day sound came through plait of fog be vexed about like letter of copy book reminded too of blundell bell grief to go into school again during two month of fog for have winter saddest heaviest thing be to stand beside sea to be upon beach see long wave coming in to know that be long wave only see piece of to hear lifting roundly swelling over smooth green rock plashing down in hollow corner bearing on same a ever soft sleek sorrowful till little noise be over one old man who lived at lynmouth seeking to be buried there having be more than half over world though shy to speak about fain to come home to birthplace old will watcombe who dwelt by water said that strange winter arose from thing called 'gulf stream ' rushing up channel suddenly said be hot water almost fit for man to shave with threw cold water out ruined fish spawning time cold spring must come after be fond of going to lynmouth on sunday to hear old man talk for sometimes must discourse with when nobody else must move told that powerful flood set in upon west so hard sometimes once in ten year sometimes not for fifty lord only knew sense of that when came therewith came warmth cloud fog moisture nut fruit even shell tide be thrown abroad a for nut winked awhile chewed piece of tobacco yet did not comprehend only afterwards heard nut with liquid kernel came travelling on gulf stream for never before be known so much foreign cordial landed upon coast floating ashore by mistake in fog what with tossing mist too much astray to learn duty folk who be ever too prone to talk said that will watcombe knew better than anybody else about drift of gulf stream place where must come ashore cave took in draught de whichehalse great magistrate certified that there be proof of unlawful importation neither good cause to suspect at time of christian charity knew that be foul thing for quarryman to say that night after night have be digging new cellar at ley manor to hold little mark of respect found in cavern at high water weed let that be be none of business to speak evil of dignity duly common people joked of 'gulp stream ' a called thing astonished frightened so be not do assure landing of foreign spirit loom of lugger at twilight in gloom of winter moonrise made a crouch in by fire draw bed clothes over try to think of something else be strange mysterious sound at grey of night when sun be gone red in west remained be star forthcoming suddenly wailing voice rose along valley sound in air a of people running mattered not whether stood on moor crouched behind rock away from down among reedy place a one sound must come now from heart of earth beneath now overhead bearing down on then there be rushing of something by melancholy laughter hair of man must stand on end before must reason properly god in mercy know that be stupid enough for man very slow of impression ever must bring to believe that father must let evil one get upper hand of when have heard that sound three time in lonely gloom of evening fog cold followed line of air be loath to go abroad by night even so far a stable loved light of candle more glow of fire with company there be many story about of course over breadth of moorland who have heard most often declared that must be wail of woman voice rustle of robe fleeing horribly fiend in fog going after to however paid heed when anybody be with only drew more close together barred door at sunset chapter xiii master huckaback come in mr reuben huckaback whom many good folk in dulverton will remember long after time be mother uncle being indeed mother brother owned very best shop in town did fine trade in soft ware especially when pack horse came safely in at christmas time being now only kindred except indeed granddaughter little ruth huckaback of whom one took heed mother beheld christian duty to keep a well a must be with for love of nice old man for sake of child truly dulverton people said that be richest man in town must buy up county armiger if came to that must like to see man at bampton at wivelscombe might say almost taunton who must put down golden jacobus carolus against now old gentleman so called according to money have seen many worse one more violent le wealthy must need come away time to spend new year tide with not that wanted to do for hated country life because mother pressing a mother will do to good bag of gold have wrung promise from only boast of life be that never yet have broken word at least since opened business now pleased god that christmas time in spite of fog to send safe home to dulverton be more with load quite safe goodly string of packhorse nearly half of charge be for uncle reuben knew how to make most of then having balanced debit credit set writ running against defaulter a behoves good christian at christmas tide saddled horse rode off towards oare with good stout coat upon leaving ruth head man plenty to do little to eat until must see again have be settled between that must expect soon after noon on last day of december for doones being lazy fond of bed a manner be of dishonest folk surest way to escape be to travel before be up about to wit in forenoon of day herein reckoned without host for being in high festivity a became good papist robber be too lazy seems to take trouble of going to bed forth rode on old year morning not with view of business purely in search of mischief have put off dinner till one o'clock to be sad foregoing there be to be brave supper at six of clock upon new year eve singer to come with lanthorns do outside parlour window then have hot cup till head must go round after making away with victual for although there be nobody now in family to be churchwarden of oare be well admitted that be people entitled alone to dignity though nicholas snowe be in office by name managed only by mother advice pretty mess made of so that one longed for ridd again soon a ever must be old enough nicholas snowe be to come in evening with three tall comely daughter strapping girl well skilled in dairy story be over parish on stupid conceit of john fry must have be in love with three if there have be one of snowes be to come come did partly because mr huckaback liked to see fine young maiden partly because none nicholas snowe must smoke pipe now around part except of very high people whom durst never invite uncle ben a knew well be great hand at pipe must sit for hour over in warm chimney corner never want to say word unless be inside only liked to have somebody there over against smoking now when came in before one o'clock after seeing to cattle for day be thicker than ever must keep cattle close at home if wished to see more of fully expected to find uncle ben sitting in fireplace lifting one cover then a favourite manner be making sweet mouth over for loved bacon rarely have good leek at dulverton be man who always must see business done there instead of finding with quaint dry face pulled out at then shut up sharp not to be cheated who must run out betty muxworthy poke with saucepan lid out of now betty ' said in politest manner for really betty be now become great domestic evil must have own way so of thing most distressful be for man to try to reason 'zider press ' cried betty again for thought fine joke to call that because of size hatred of 'here be rare get up anyhow ' ' rare good dinner mean betty well have rare good appetite with wanted to go smell not to stop for betty 'troost thee for thiccy jan ridd thee must keep bit langer reckon baint coom maister ziderpress whatt ' e mak of now 'do mean to say that uncle ben have not arrived yet betty ' 'raived knaws nout about whuther hath of noo only tell ' e baint coom rackon dooneses hath gat betty who hated uncle ben because never gave groat be not allowed to dine with be sorry to say that betty muxworthy grinned across poked again with greasy saucepan cover misliking so to be treated strode through kitchen indignantly for betty behaved to even now a if be only eliza johnny johnny mother cried running out of grand show parlour where case of stuffed bird be peacock feather white hare killed by grandfather ' be so glad be come at last there be something sadly amiss johnny mother have upon wrist something very wonderful of nature of fal lal a say for have inborn turn being of good draper family polished above yeomanry nevertheless must never bear partly because felt to be out of place in good farm house partly because hate frippery partly because seemed to to have nothing to do with father partly because never must tell reason of hating yet poor soul have put on not to show hand off be above station simply for child sake because uncle ben have given thing never must bear for man woman to call ' 'jack ' cared not be honest enough smallness of there say 'well mother what be matter then ' be sure need not be angry johnny only hope be nothing to grieve about instead turn flap over in inside of roasting pig ' mother dear be very sorry let have dinner know promised not to wait for after one o'clock only make hungry everything will be spoiled mother what pity to think of after will go to seek for in thick of fog like needle in hay band be to say unless think ' for looked very grave about 'unless really think mother ought to go without dinner ' 'oh john never thought that thank god bless for child appetite what be uncle ben to ' so made very good dinner indeed though wishing that must have of wondering how much to leave for then a sound of horse have be heard set out with gun to look for followed track on side of hill from farm yard where sledd mark be for have wheel upon exmoor yet ever will suppose though dunder headed man tried last winter broke axle piteously be nigh to break neck after went along on ridge of rabbit cleve with brook running thin in bottom then down to lynn stream leaped so up hill moor beyond fog hung close around then when turned crest of highland gorse before behind looked like man crouching down in ambush still there be good cloud of daylight being scarce three of clock yet when lead of red deer came across must tell from sheep even now be half inclined to shoot at for child did love venison drooped head so looked so faithful that seemed hard measure to do if one of have bolted away doubt have let go at after kept on track trudging very stoutly for nigh upon three mile beard now beginning to grow at length be full of great drop prickly whereat be very proud have not so much a dog with place be unkind lonesome rolling cloud very desolate now if wild sheep ran across be scared at a enemy for part must not tell meaning of mark on called part gibbet moor not being in parish though there be gibbet enough upon most part of body be gone for value of chain said teaching of young chirurgeons of have little fear being more schoolboy now youth well acquaint with exmoor wise art of sign post whereby man who barred road now open up way with finger bone so far a rogue allow carbine be loaded freshly primed knew to be even now match in strength for two men of size around neighbourhood except in glen doone jan ridd ' be called already folk grew feared to wrestle with though be tired of hearing about often longed to be smaller most of upon sunday when have to make way up little church maiden tittered at soft white mist came thicker around a evening fell peat rick here there furze huck of summer time be out of shape in twist of by by began to doubt where be how come there not having seen gibbet lately then heard draught of wind up hollow place with rock to for first time fear broke out like cold sweat upon yet knew what fool be to fear nothing sound when stopped to listen there be sound more than beating noise be inside therefore went on again making company of myself keeping gun quite ready now when came to unknown place where stone be set up endwise with faint red cross upon polish from conflict gathered courage to stop think having sped on way too hotly against stone set gun trying spirit to leave so keeping with hand for then what to do next be wonder a for finding uncle ben be own business at rate executor first have to find plentifully must thank god to find at home again for sake of family volume of mist came rolling at like great log of wood pillowed out with sleepiness between there be nothing more than waiting for next one then everything went out of sight glad be of stone behind view of mine own shoe then distant noise went by a of many horse galloping in fright set gun said 'god send something to shoot at ' yet nothing came gun fell back without will to lower presently while be thinking 'what fool be arose a if from below foot so that great stone trembled that long lamenting lonesome sound a of evil spirit not knowing what to do with for moment stood like root without hand foot to help hair of head began to crawl lifting hat a snail lift house heart like shuttle went to fro finding harm to come of visible form approaching wiped forehead hoped for best resolved to run step of way till drew own latch behind yet here again be disappointed for sooner be come to cross way by black pool in hole heard through patter of own foot rough low sound very close in fog a of hobbled sheep coughing listened feared yet listened again though wanted not to hear for being in haste of homeward road heart having heel to loath be to stop in dusk for sake of aged wether yet partly love of animal partly fear of farmer disgrace compelled to go to succour noise be coming nearer dry short wheezing sound be barred with cough want of breath thus made meaning of have mercy upon o lord upon soul have mercy if cheated sam hick last week lord knowest how well deserved lied in stocking mouth oh lord where be going ' word with many jog between came to through darkness then long groan choking made towards sound a nigh a ever must guess presently be met point blank by head of mountain pony upon back lay man bound down with foot on neck head to tail arm falling down like stirrup wild little nag be scared of life by unaccustomed burden have be tossing rolling hard in desire to get ease of before little horse must turn caught jaded a be by wet grizzled forelock saw that be vain to struggle strove to bite none le until smote upon nose 'good worthy sir ' said to man who be riding so roughly 'fear nothing harm will come to thee ' good friend whoever thou art ' gasped must not look at because neck be jerked so 'god hath sent thee not to rob because be done already 'what uncle ben ' cried letting go horse in amazement that richest man in dulverton 'uncle ben here in plight what mr reuben huckaback honest hosier draper serge warehouseman groaned from rib to rib sign of gartered kitten in loyal town of dulverton for god sake let down good fellow from accursed marrow bone groat of good money will pay thee safe in house to dulverton take notice that horse be mine no le than nag robbed from ' 'what uncle ben dost thou not know thy dutiful nephew john ridd ' not to make long story of cut thong bound set astride on little horse be too weak to stay so therefore mounted on back turning horse into horse step leading pony by cord fastened around nose set out for plover barrow uncle ben went fast asleep on back being jaded shaken beyond strength for man of three score five a soon felt assured of safety must talk more to tell truth snored so loudly must almost believe that fearful noise in fog night came way from dulverton now a soon a ever brought in set up in chimney corner comfortable handsome be little delight to to get off back for like own fortune uncle ben be of good round figure gave long coat shake two stamped about in kitchen until be sure of whereabouts then fell asleep again until supper must be ready 'he will marry ruth ' said by by to not to 'he will marry ruth for have little saving soon a be worth having very little a yet very little indeed ever so much gone to day along of rascal robber mother made dreadful stir of course about uncle ben being in plight a so left to care annie soon fed rarely while went out to see to comfort of captured pony in truth be worth catching served very well afterwards though uncle ben be inclined to claim for business at dulverton where have cart that like 'but said 'you will have sir welcome if will only ride home a first found riding ' with dropped very strange old man be short in manner though long of body glad to do contrary thing to what one expected of always looking sharp at people a if feared to be cheated surprised much at first because showed ignorance of what farmer be upright race a may find scarcely ever cheating indeed except upon market day even then no more than may be helped by reason of buyer expecting now simple way be puzzle to a told very often only laughed rubbed mouth with back of dry shining hand think shortly began to languish for want of one to higgle with have great mind to give pony because thought cheated in case only must conclude that did with view to legacy of course doones nobody else have robbed good uncle reuben then grew sportive took horse especially sober nag bound master upon wild one for little change a told for two three hour have fine enjoyment chasing through fog making much sport of groanings then waxing hungry went way left to opportunity now mr huckaback growing able to walk in few day time became thereupon impatient must not be brought to understand why must have be robbed at have never deserved ' said to not knowing much of providence except with small p to ' have never deserved will not stand in name of lord king not at other time must burst forth thus 'three score year five have lived honest laborious life yet never be robbed before now to be robbed in old age to be robbed for first time now thereupon of course must tell how truly thankful ought to be for never having be robbed before in spite of living so long in world that be taking very ungrateful not to say ungracious view in thus repining feeling aggrieved when anyone else must have knelt thanked god for enjoying so long immunity say what must be a one uncle ben stuck fast to that have nothing to thank god for chapter xiv motion end in mull instead of minding new year pudding master huckaback carried on so about mighty grievance at last began to think there must be something in after especially a assured that choice costly present for young people of household be among good divested mother told child have plenty wanted gold silver little eliza spoke up said 'you can give pretty thing uncle ben when come in summer to see ' mother reproved eliza for although be heel of own foot then to satisfy uncle promised to call farmer nicholas snowe to be of council that evening 'and if young maiden must kindly come without taking thought to smoothe why must be merrier who knew what uncle huckaback might bless day of robbery etc etc thorough good honest girl be fit helpmate for shop farm ' of be meant for stuck to platter answered not in evening farmer snowe came up leading daughter after like filly trimmed for fair uncle ben who have not seen on night of mishap because word have be sent to stop be mightily pleased very pleasant according to town bred way damsel have seen good company soon got over fear of wealth played number of merry prank made mother quite jealous for annie who be always shy diffident however when hot cup be done before mulled wine be ready packed maiden in parlour turned key upon then drew near to kitchen fire to hear uncle ben proposal farmer snowe sat up in corner caring little to bear about anything smoking slowly nodding backward like sheep dog dreaming mother be in settle of course knitting hard a usual uncle ben took to three legged stool a if have be thieved from howsoever kept breath from speech giving privilege a be due to mother beaster snowe be well assured ' said mother colouring like furze a took flame fell over 'that kinsman here hath received rough harm on peaceful journey from dulverton time be bad a know well there be sign of bettering if must see lord king might say thing to move nevertheless have have so much of own account to vex for 'you be flying out of subject sarah ' said uncle ben seeing tear in eye tired of matter 'zettle pralimbinaries spoke farmer snowe on appeal from 'virst zettle pralimbinaries then know what be drivin ' at 'preliminaries be damned sir cried uncle ben losing temper preliminary be there when be robbed must like to know robbed in parish a can prove to eternal disgrace of oare scandal of england hold parish to answer for sir parish will make good being nest of foul thief a be ay farmer yeoman of will beggar man in parish if be not beggar already ay sell old church up before eye what will have back tarlatan time piece saddle dove tailed nag ' mother looked at looked at farmer snowe be sorry for master huckaback putting hand up one to that nobody must browbeat because knew what parish be none worse for strong language however rich man might be uncle ben took in different way thought that be afraid of oare parish be a moab edom for to cast shoe over 'nephew jack cried looking at when be thinking what to say finding only emptiness 'you be heavy lout sir bumpkin clodhopper will leave perhaps 'as for parish mother cried being too hard set to contain parish can defend may leave to do so jack be not like sir will not have spoken of leave indeed who want to do more than to leave alone know uncle reuben if one in world ought other people child 'well well uncle reuben answered know very little of child except little ruth be nothing wonderful never said that child be wonderful uncle ben did ever think a for being good ' here mother fetched out handkerchief being overcome by goodness told with hand to mouth not to notice though might be worth ten thousand time ten thousand pound to zay 'bout here parish oother mind oother parish thees use vreedom zur for to tell ' e that thee be laiar then farmer nicholas snowe folded arm across with bowl of pipe on upper one gave nod then one to mother to testify how have done duty recked not what might come of however got little thanks from for parish be nothing at to mother compared with child interest thought hard that uncle of mine old man too must be called liar by visitor at fireplace for in rude part of world counted one of worst disgrace must befall man to receive lie from one uncle ben a seems be used to in way of trade just a people of fashion be by style of courtesy therefore old man only looked with pity at farmer nicholas with sort of sorrow too reflecting how much might have made in bargain with customer so ignorant hot headed let bandy word more said mother very sweetly 'nothing be easier than sharp word except to wish unspoken a do many many time when think of good husband now let hear from uncle reuben what must have do to remove disgrace from amongst to satisfy of good ' care not for good woman ' master huckaback answered grandly 'although be of large value about say nothing what demand be punishment of scoundrel 'zober man zober cried farmer nicholas be too naigh badgery 'ood to spake like of dooneses ' 'pack of coward said uncle reuben looking first at door however beuch chance see of getting redress from valour of exmoor master snowe very man whom looked to to raise country take lead a churchwarden why youngest shopman must match ell against pack of coward cried uncle ben rising shaking lappet at ' pretend to answer shake off that hing more to do with ' knew useless to answer conveyed knowledge to one without anything to vex however when mulled wine be come good deal of gone season being epiphany uncle reuben began to think that might have be too hard with moreover be beginning now to respect farmer nicholas bravely because of way have smoked pipe little noise made over lizzie annie be doing best for now have let girl out to wake more lightsome uproar also young faith snowe be toward to keep old men cup aflow hansel to liking so at close of entertainment when girl be gone away to fetch light lanthorns over made rare noise blowing other out for counting of spark to come master huckaback stood up without much aid from crock saw looked at mother of 'let one leave place ' said 'until have said what want to say for saving of ill will among growth of cheer comfort may be have carried thing too far even to bound of churlishness beyond bound of good manner will not unsay one word have said having never yet done so in life must alter manner of set forth in light if folk upon exmoor here be loath wary at fighting yet be brave at better stuff best kindest ever knew in matter of feeding ' here sat down with tear in eye called for little mulled bastard maid who be now come back raced to get for annie of course be foremost herein ended expedition perilous great one against doones of bagworthy enterprise over have talked plainly more than be good for for part slept well that night feeling at home again now that fighting be put aside fear of turned to comfort of talking what must have done chapter xv master huckaback fails of warrant on following day master huckaback with show of mystery demanded from mother escort into dangerous part of world to business compelled mother made answer to that be kindly welcome to take john fry with at good clothier laughed said that john be nothing like big enough john must serve turn not only for size because if be carried away stone must be left unturned upon exmoor until must be brought back again hereupon mother grew very pale found fifty reason against going of weightier than true one a eliza who be jealous of managed to whisper to annie on other hand be quite resolved directly thing be mentioned to see uncle reuben through with added much to self esteem to be guard of so rich man therefore soon persuaded mother with head upon breast to let go trust in god after be greatly vexed to find that dangerous enterprise be nothing more than visit to baron de whichehalse to lay information sue warrant against doones posse to execute stupid a always have be must ever be doubt must well have told uncle reuben that journey be wiser than of men of gotham that never must get from hugh de whichehalse warrant against doones moreover that if did get one own wig must be singed with for diver reason held peace partly from youth modesty partly from desire to see please god must see partly from other cause rode by way of brendon town illford bridge babbrook to avoid great hill above lynmouth day being fine clear again laughed in sleeve at uncle reuben for fine precaution when arrived at ley manor be shown very civilly into hall refreshed with good ale collared head back of christmas pudding have never be under so fine roof unless be of church before pleased greatly to be so kindly entreated by high born folk uncle reuben be vexed little at being set down side by side with man in very small way of trade who be come upon business there who made bold to drink health after finishing horn of ale beir said uncle ben looking at bey health must fare much better if must pay three pound twelve shilling have owed five year back now be met at justice opportunity be good sir after that be called to justice room where baron be sitting with colonel harding justiciary of king peace to help have seen baron de whichehalse before be not at afraid of having be at school with son a knew made very kind to indeed be kind to everybody people spoke well of so much more because knew that house be in decadence for first de whichehalse have come from holland where have be great nobleman hundred fifty year agone being persecuted for religion when spanish power be everything fled to england with must save bought large estate in devonshire since then descendant have intermarried with ancient county family cottwells marwoods walronds welses of pylton chichesters of hall several of lady brought large increase of property so about fifty year before time of be writing there be few name in west of england thought more of than de whichehalse now have lost great deal of land therefore of go with land a surely a fame belongs to earth mean big reputation how have lost none must tell except that a first descendant have manner of amassing so later one be gifted with power of scattering whether came of good devonshire blood opening sluice of low country vein be beyond province power to inquire anyhow people loved last strain of de whichehalse far more than name have be liked hundred year agone hugh de whichehalse white haired man of very noble presence with friendly blue eye sweet smooth forehead aquiline nose quite beautiful a might expect in lady of birth thin lip curving delicately gentleman rose a entered room while colonel harding turned on chair struck one spur against other be sure that without knowing aught of must have reverenced more of two one who showed respect to yet nine gentleman out of ten make dull mistake when dealing with class below uncle reuben made very best scrape then walked up to table trying to look a if did not know to be wealthier than gentleman put together of course be no stranger to more than be a proved afterwards colonel harding owed lump of money upon very good security of uncle reuben took notice addressed to de whichehalse baron smiled very gently so soon a learned cause of visit then replied quite reasonably ' warrant against doones master huckaback of doones so please christian name what be ' bey lord be not godfather most like never have know old sir ensor name so that may be obstacle ensor doone son so be how many son master huckaback what be name of one 'how can tell lord even if have known a well a own shop boy nevertheless there be seven of must be obstacle ' ' warrant against sir ensor doone seven son of sir ensor prove that be not there may be indicted for perjury a for seven son of of course can swear that be son not nephew grandchild even doones at bey lord can swear that be doones moreover can pay for mistake make therein need be obstacle yes can pay can pay well enough ' said colonel harding shortly ' be heartily glad to hear ' replied baron pleasantly 'for prof after that robbery if robbery there have be be not so very ruinous sometimes people think be robbed then be very sweet afterwards to find that have not be so for add to joy in property now be quite convinced good sir that people if particular family ' 'because must be nobody else because in spite of fog 'fog cried colonel harding sharply 'fog said baron with emphasis 'ah explains whole affair to be sure now remember weather have be too thick for man to see head of own horse doones if still there be doones must never have come abroad be a sure a simony master huckaback for good sake be heartily glad that charge have miscarried thoroughly understand now fog explains whole of ' 'go back good fellow ' said colonel harding 'and if day be clear enough will find thing where left know from own experience what be to be caught in forest blackest loneliest place of keep sun out even now in winter time with most of wood unriddled rest of pinched brown hung around like cloak containing little comfort kept quite close to peggy in graceful bend of tree even in 'lords lady clumped in scoop of hedgerow most of in soft primrose wrung by wind stealing back smiling when wrath be passed in of many others there be aching ecstasy matter without disclosing circumstance now wisest person in part be reckoned to be certain wise woman well known over exmoor by name of mother melldrum real name be maple durham a learned long afterwards came of ancient family of devon somerset nevertheless be quite at home with proper mode of divination knowing that liked best a man doe own religion must always practise for people of country while must let know that kept higher nobler mode for who looked down upon one not having be bred born to have two house rather have none at two home wherein to find according to time of year in summer lived in pleasant cave facing cool side of hill far inland near hawkridge close above tarr step wonderful crossing of barle river made a everybody know by satan for wager throughout winter found sea air agreeable place where thing must be have on credit more occasion of talking not what must have credit for one be afraid of in neighbourhood of tarr step only there be one handy owning thing worth taking therefore at fall of leaf when wood grew damp irksome wise woman always set face to warmer cliff of channel where shelter be dry fern bedding folk to be seen in distance from bank upon sun shone there a knew from john fry who have be to about rheumatism sheep possessed with evil spirit wart on hand of son young john one who chose might find towards close of winter day gathering stick brown fern for fuel talking to herself while in hollow stretch behind cliff foreigner who come go without seeing much of exmoor have called valley of rock valley goyal a term being small for valley lie to west of linton about mile from town perhaps away towards ley manor homefolk always call dane denes be more tell than hollow place even a word 'den be however let that pas for know very little about place be pretty one though nothing to frighten anybody unless hath lived in gallipot be green rough sided hollow bending at middle touched with stone at crest dotted here there with slab in out bramble on right hand be upward crag called by castle easy enough to scale giving great view of channel facing from inland side elbow of valley queer old pile of rock arises bold behind one quite enough to affright man if only be ten time larger be called devil cheese ring devil cheese knife mean same thing a father be used to eat cheese from scoop perhaps in old time upmost rock have fallen away since knew be like to implement if satan eat cheese untoasted middle of valley be place to rest in to sit think that trouble be not if must not make to know sea outside hill never to behold only by sound of wave to pity sailor labouring then to watch sheltered sun coming warmly round turn like guest expected full of gentle glow gladness casting shadow far away a thing to hug awakening life from dew hope from spreading bud then to fall asleep dream that fern be asparagus ala be too young in day much to care for creature comfort to let pure palate have thing must improve anything went down with a doe with most of too late know good from bad knowledge be pleasure then being memory medicine rather than wine of hope now mother melldrum kept winter in vale of rock sheltering from wind rain within devil cheese ring added greatly to fame because else for mile around be afraid to go near after dark even on gloomy day under eaves of lichened rock have winding passage none ever knew of durst enter to place went to seek in spite of misgiving upon sunday in lenten season when sheep be folded parson a if have known intent have preached beautiful sermon about witch of endor peril of meddle wantonly with unseen power therein referred especially to strange noise in neighbourhood upbraided for want of faith many other backsliding listened to very earnestly for like to hear from better about thing be beyond to be roused up now then like sheep with good dog after who can pull wool without biting nevertheless must not see how want of faith must have made that noise especially at night time notwithstanding believed hoped to do little better so came home from church most of people dined with a always do on sunday because of distance to go home with only word inside parson who always sat next to be afraid that might have vexed must not have best piece of meat according to custom soon put at ease showed be proud of then made more to do accepted best of sirloin chapter xviii witchery lead to witchcraft although end of march wind blew wild piercing a went on foot afternoon to mother melldrum dwelling be safer not to take horse lest if anything vexed must put spell upon a have be done to farmer snowe stable by wise woman of simonsbath sun be low on edge of hill by time entered valley for must not leave home till cattle be tended distance be seven mile more shadow of rock fell far deep brown dead fern be fluttering bramble with sere leaf hanging swayed tatter to fro with red look on in patch underneath crag few wild goat be browsing then tossed horn fled leaped on ledge stared at moreover sound of sea came up went length of valley there lapped on butt of rock murmured like shell taking thing one with feeling lonesomeness having stick with be much inclined to go briskly back come at better season when beheld tall grey shape of something moving at lower end of valley where shade be gave such stroke of fear after many others that thumb lay in mother bible brought in big pocket for sake of safety shook so much that came out must not get in again 'this serf right ' said to myself 'for tampering with beelzebub oh have listened to parson thereupon struck aside not liking to run away quite a people might call seeking to look like wanderer who be come to see valley have seen almost enough of must have succeeded gone home then be angry at want of courage that on very turn bending of footstep woman in distance lifted up staff to so be bound to stop now being brought face to face by will of god a one might say with anything might come of kept quite straight stiff thrust away white feather trusting in bible still hoping that must protect though have disobeyed upon remembrance conscience took by leg so must not go forward while fearful woman be coming near more near to be glad to sit down on rock because knee be shaking so tried to think of many thing none of must come to must not take eye away though prayed god to be near when be come so nigh to that must descry feature there be something in countenance that made not dislike looked a if have be visited by many trouble have felt one by one yet held enough of kindly nature still to grieve for others long white hair on side be falling down below chin through wrinkle clear bright eye seemed to spread upon though have plenty of time to think be taken by surprise le unable to say anything yet eager to hear silence broken longing for noise two 'thou art not come to ' said looking through simple face a if be glass 'to be struck for bone shave to be blessed for barn gun give forth thy hand john ridd tell why thou art come to ' be so much amazed at knowing name about feared to place hand in power even tongue by speaking 'have fear of son have gift to harm thee if have must be idle now if thou hast wit tell why love thee ' never have wit mother ' answered in devonshire way 'and never set eye on thee before to furthest of knowledge ' 'and yet know thee a well john a if thou wert grandson remember old oare oak bog at head of exe child who must have died there for thy strength courage most of thy kindness be granddaughter john have on earth to love ' now that came to speak of with place so clearly remembered about thing happened last august thought how stupid must have be not to learn more of little girl who have fallen into black pit with basketful of whortleberry who might have be gulfed if little dog have not spied in distance carried on back to mother then dressed anew took where ordered did not tell who be anything more than christian name that be eight year old fond of fried batatas did not seek to ask more a manner be with visitor thinking of little story seeing how looked at lost fear of mother melldrum began to like partly because have helped grandchild partly that if be so wise need must have be for to save little thing from drowning therefore stood up said though scarcely yet established in power against hers mother shoe lost be in mire not with must not match although gave pair of sister lizzie ' bey son what care for shoe how simple thou art foolish according to thought of now tell for thou canst not lie what have brought thee to ' being so ashamed bashful be half inclined to tell lie until said must not do then knew must not ' be come to know ' said looking at rock while to keep voice from shaking 'when may go to see lorna doone ' more must say though mind be charged to ask fifty other question although looked away be plain that have asked enough felt that wise woman gazed at in wrath a well a sorrow then grew angry that one must seem to make light of lorna ridd ' said woman observing for now faced bravely 'of whom art thou speaking be child of men who slew father ' ' can not tell mother how must know what be to thee be something to thy mother john something to thyself trow nothing worse must befall thee ' waited for to speak again because have spoken so sadly that took breath away ridd if thou hast value for thy body thy soul thy mother thy father name have nought to do with doone gazed at in earnest so raised voice in saying until whole valley curving like great bell echoed 'doone ' that seemed to heart be gone for one everything if be god will for to have more of lorna let sign come out of rock must try to believe sign came turned to woman longed that have be man poor thing with bone blade pail of water door key what know about destiny of maiden such a lorna chilblain may treat bone shave ringworm scaldings even scabby sheep may limp better for striking john baptist cousin with wool hyssop be for mare ailing dog fowl have jaundice look at now mother melldrum be like fool 'that thou art son ala that be other now behold end of john ridd mark end of ' pointed to castle rock where upon narrow shelf betwixt coming star bitter fight be raging fine fat sheep with honest face have clomb up very carefully to browse on bit of juicy grass now dew of land be upon to from upper crag lean black goat came hurrying with leap skirmish of horn angry noise in nostril goat have grazed place before to utmost of liking cropping in out with jerk a manner be of feeding nevertheless fell on sheep with fury great malice simple wether be much inclined to retire from contest looked around in vain for way to peace comfort enemy stood between last leap have taken there be nothing left to fight be hurled into sea five hundred foot below down lie down ' shouted to a if be dog for have seen battle like before knew that sheep have chance of life except from greater weight difficulty of moving 'lie down lie down john ridd ' cried mother melldrum mocking without sign of smiling poor sheep turned upon voice looked at so piteously that must look no longer ran with speed to try save from combat saw must not be in time for goat be bucking to leap at so good wether stooped forehead with harmless horn curling aside of goat flung heel up rushed at with quick sharp jump trick of movement point of long horn always foremost little scut cocked like gun hammer a ran up steep of rock must not see what be doing sheep must have fought very bravely at last yielded ground quite slowly hoped almost to save just a head topped platform of rock saw flung from backward with sad low moan gurgle body made quite short noise in air like bucket thrown down well shaft must not tell when struck water except by echo among rock so be with goat at moment being somewhat scant of breath unable to consider caught by right hind leg before must turn from victory hurled after sheep to learn how liked own compulsion chapter xix dangerous interview although left denes at once having little heart for further question of wise woman being afraid to visit house under devil cheese ring to kindly invited although ran most part of way be very late for farm house time upon sunday evening before be back at plover barrow mother have great desire to know about matter must not reconcile with respect so to frighten therefore tried to sleep off keeping own counsel when proved of avail strove to work away might be by heavy outdoor labour weariness good feeding indeed have effect helped to pas week two quite stripling lad 'worshipful guardian said there be time now for history if thou art in haste be can not stay here idling only tell how be akin under wardship to thee what purpose brings thee here lord in council of king charles second appointed to learn law not for livelihood thank god because felt lack of in affair of state first leave young mistress lorna can not lay down legal maxim without aid of smoke leaned against willow tree drawing from gilded box little dark thing like stick placed between lip then striking flint on steel made fire caught upon touchwood with kindled tip of stick until glowed with ring of red then breathed forth curl of smoke blue smelling on air like spice have never seen done before though acquainted with tobacco pipe made laugh until thought of peril must follow have fear said make safer will take for glow worm thee for flower shine upon to return of law learned a may suppose little although have capacity thing be far too dull for care for be adventure moving chance hot encounter therefore of law learned be how to live without nevertheless for amusement sake a must need be at desk hour so in afternoon took to sporting branch of law pitfall ambuscade of trap to be laid therein pedigree be rarest there be scarce man worth cross of butter what may find hole in shield within four generation so struck own escutcheon sounded hollow there be point heed not that enough that being curious now followed up quarry be come to at last even lord of loch awe have outlaw for cousin must have more if be like beir answered being amused by manner be new to for doones be much in earnest surely count disgrace to be of kin to sir ensor doone honest family 'if be so be in truth very highest honour must heal ten hole in escutcheon what noble family spring from captain among robber trade alone can spoil blood robbery purifies robbery of one age be chivalry of next may start anew vie with even nobility of france if can once enrol doones upon lineage ' like not to hear speak of doones a if be more than exclaimed being now unreasonable will tell once for sir how be guardian 'that will do be ward because be father ward under scottish law now father being so deaf have succeeded to right at least in own opinion under claim be here to neglect trust no longer to lead away from scene deed though of good repute comely be not best for young gentlewoman there spoke not like guardian after can mistrust 'but said good cousin alan if may so call be not meet for young gentlewoman to go away with young gentleman though fifty time guardian if will only come with explain tale to grandfather will listen to quietly take advantage of ' thank much kind mistress lorna to lead goose into fox den setting by thought of danger have other reason against now come with faithful guardian child will pledge honour against harm to bear safe to london by law of realm be now entitled to custody of fair person of chattel sir that have learned of law be how to live without 'fairly met fair cousin mine wit will do credit after little sharpening there be none to do better than aunt mother although know not of coming be longing to receive come in few month time will set mode at court instead of pining here weaving coronal of daisy turned aside thought little although seemed so light of mind gay in dress manner must not doubt honesty saw beneath jaunty air true mettle ripe bravery scarce have thought of project twice until spoke of aunt mother then form of dearest friend sweet aunt sabina seemed to come bid listen for be what prayed for moreover felt though not a now that doone glen be place for proud young maiden while thought yellow lightning spread behind bulk of cloud three time ere flash be done far off void of thunder from pile of cloud before cut a from black paper lit to depth of blackness by blaze behind form a of aged man sitting in chair loose mantled seemed to lift hand warn 'this minded of grandfather care owed moreover now storm be rising began to grow afraid for of thing awful to thunder be dreadfulest doth so growl like lion coming then so roll roar rumble out of thickening darkness then crack like last trump overhead through cloven air terror that heart lie low quiver like weed in water listened now for distant rolling of great black storm heard be hurried by youth before waved rolled tobacco at drawled in daintiest tone manner 'the sky be having smoke see dropping spark grumbling must have thought exmoor hill too small to gather thunder ' can not go will not go with lord alan brandir answered being vexed little by word of be not grave enough for be not old enough for aunt sabina must not have wished must leave grandfather without full permission thank much for coming sir be gone at once by way came pray how did come sir 'fair cousin will grieve for will mourn when can not mend must mother have be here soon must have persuaded yet added with smile of accustomed gaiety must have be unco thing a say in scotland for ladyship to have waited upon a graceless son have done hope to do again ere long down cliff came up must make way back again now adieu fair cousin lorna see be in haste tonight be right proud of guardianship give just one flower for token here kissed hand to threw truss of woodbine adieu fair cousin trust well will soon be here again 'that thou never shalt sir cried voice a loud a culverin carver doone have alan brandir a spider hath fly boy made little shriek at first with sudden shock terror then looked methought ashamed of set face to fight for very bravely strove struggled to free one arm grasp sword a well might infant buried alive attempt to lift gravestone carver doone with great arm wrapped around slim gay body smiled a saw by flash from heaven at poor young face turned up to then a nurse bear off child who be loath to go to bed lifted youth from foot bore away into darkness be young then be older now older by ten year in thought although be not twelvemonth since if black deed be done again must follow must combat must throw weak arm on murderer strive to be murdered also be now at home with violence dark death surprise 'but being a be that night horror overcame crash of thunder overhead last despairing look death piece framed with blaze of lightning young heart be so affrighted must not gasp breath went from knew not where be who what only lay cowered under great tree full of thunder must neither count moan have foot to help 'yet hearkening a coward doe through brushing of wind echo of far noise heard sharp sound a of iron fall of heavy wood unmanly shriek came with cry for mercy carver doone know what be so did alan brandir ' here lorna doone must tell no more being overcome with weeping only through tear whispered a thing too bad to tell that have seen that giant carver in few day afterwards smoking little round brown stick like of poor cousin must not press more with question for clearness although longed very much to know whether have spoken of to grandfather counsellor be now in such condition of mind body from force of own fear multiplied by telling did nothing more than coax at distance humbly so that must see that one be at least afraid of although knew not woman in day a now do never will know much of say so brought round that fear be now for how to get safely off without mischance to one sooth to say in spite of longing just to see if master carver must have served such trick a grew towards dusk be not best pleased to be there for seemed lawless place of lorna fright stayed with a talked away from chapter xxii after hearing that tale from lorna went home in sorry spirit having added fear for misery about to other ailment be not quite certain now that being owned full cousin to peer lord of scotland although be dead one must have nought to do with yeoman son bound to be father of more yeoman have be very sorry when first heard about poor young popinjay must gladly have fought hard for now struck that after have right to be there prowling a be for lorna without invitation farmer love not trespass still if have seen thing must have tried to save moreover be greatly vexed with own hesitation stupidity shyness else be have held back from saying ere told story what be in heart to say videlicet must die unless let love not be fool enough to think that must answer according to liking begin to care about for long time yet if indeed ever must hardly dared to hope have heard from men more skillful in matter that be wise to be in time so maid may begin to think when know that be thought of to tell truth have bitter fear on account of wondrous beauty lest young fellow of higher birth finer part finish might steal in before poor cut out altogether thinking of used to double great fist without knowing keep in pocket ready worst of be that in great dismay anguish to see lorna weeping so have promised not to cause further trouble from anxiety fear of harm being brought to practice meant be not to show within precinct of glen doone for at least month unless indeed a contrived to edge into agreement anything must happen to increase present trouble day uneasiness in case be to throw dark mantle covering of sort over large white stone hung within entrance to retreat mean outer entrance though unseen from valley be a have observed conspicuous from height where stood with uncle reuben now coming home so sad weary yet trying to console with thought love o'erleapeth rank must still be lord of found shameful thing going on made very angry for need must happen that young marwood de whichehalse only son of baron riding home very evening from chasing of exmoor bustard with hound serving men must take short cut through farmyard being dry from exercise must come ask for drink need must happen also that there must be none to give to sister annie more than suspect that have heard report of annie comeliness have mind to satisfy upon subject now a took large ox horn of quarantine apple cider always keep apart from rest being too good except for quality let finger dwell on annie by sort of accident while lifted beaver gallantly gazed on face in light from west then what did annie do a told afterwards make very best curtsey to being pleased that be pleased with while thought what fine young man be so much breeding about in truth be dark handsome fellow hasty reckless changeable with look of sad destiny in black eye must make woman pity what be thinking of annie be not for to say although may think that must not have found such maiden on exmoor except of course lorna though young squire marwood be so thirsty spent much time over cider at rate over ox horn made many bow to annie drank health to family spoke of a if have be very best friend at blundell whereas knew well enough time that have nought to say to one being three year older therefore of course disdaining while be casting about perhaps for excuse to stop longer annie be beginning to fear lest mother must come after eliza be at window betty up in pig house suddenly there came up to a if from very heart of earth long low hollow mysterious sound spoke of in winter young man started in saddle let horn fall on horse step gazed around in wonder while a for annie turned like ghost tried to slam door failed through violence of trembling for never till now have one heard so close at hand a might say in mere fall of twilight by time there be man at least in parish knew for parson have told so that be devil groaning because doones be too many for marwood de whichehalse be not so alarmed what saw fine opportunity leaped from horse laid hold of dear annie in highly comforting manner never must tell about being so shy modest whether in breathing comfort to tried to take from pure lip hope did not because to must seem not deed of gentleman be of good old family at very moment who must come into end of passage upon heavy writer of doings john ridd walking faster may be on account of noise mentioned entered house with wrath upon at seeing gazehounds in yard for seems cruel thing to to harass bird in breeding time to amazement there saw squire marwood among milk pan with arm around annie waist annie blushing coaxing off for be not come to scold yet perhaps be wrong god know if be doubt will pay for gave flat of hand on head down went in thick of milk pan must have have fist doubt for having be at school with after that be like enough must never have spoken word a be lay stunned with cream running on while took poor annie up carried in to mother who have heard noise be frightened concerning matter asked more held ready to bear out in form convenient feeling have done duty cared not for consequence only for several day dear annie seemed frightened rather than grateful oddest result of be that eliza who have so despised made very rude verse about now came trying to sit on knee kiss give best of pan however must not allow because hate sudden change thing also astonished namely beautiful letter from marwood de whichehalse sent by groom soon afterwards in apologised to a if have be equal for rudeness to sister be not intended in least came of common alarm at moment desire to comfort also begged permission to come see a old schoolfellow set everything straight between a must be among honest blundellites be so different to idea of fighting out quarrel when once be upon man knew not what to make of bowed to higher breeding only one thing resolved upon come when must must not see annie to do sister justice have desire to see however be too easy there be doubt of being very quick to forgive man very slow to suspect unless hath once lied to moreover a to annie have always seemed to much against wish that shrewd love of waiting sort be between tom faggus though tom have made fortune now everybody respected of course be not to be compared in point of respectability with people who hanged robber when fortune turned against so young squire marwood came again a though have never smitten spoke of in a light way a if be still at school together be not in nature of course to keep anger against knew what condescension be for to visit be very grievous thing touch small landowner to see ancient family day by day decaying when heard that ley barton manor of lynton be under heavy mortgage debt to john lovering of weare gifford there be not much in little way that must not gladly do suffer for benefit of de whichehalse meanwhile work of farm be toward day gave more ado to dispose of what be doing for after long dry skeltering wind of march part of april there have be fortnight of soft wet when sun came forth again hill valley wood meadow must not make enough of many spring have seen since then never yet two spring alike never one so beautiful be that love came forth touched world with beauty spring be in valley now creeping first for shelter shyly in pause of blustering wind there lamb came bleating to orchis lifted up thin dead leaf of clover lay for new one to spring through there stiffest thing sleep stubby oak saplin 'd beech dropped brown defiance to prepared for soft reply while over eager child who have started forth to meet through frost shower of sleet catkin 'd hazel gold gloved withy youthful elder old woodbine with tribe of good hedge climber who must hasten while haste may be there one of did not claim merit of coming first there stayed held revel a soon a fear of frost be gone air be fount of freshness earth of gladness laughing water prattled of kindness of sun made much harder for plying hoe rake to keep field with room upon for corn to tiller winter wheat be well enough being sturdy strong sided spring wheat barley oat be overrun by ill weed growing faster therefore a old saying be farmer that thy wife may thrive let not burr burdock wive if thou wouldst keep thy son see that bine gith have none so be compelled to go down field up striking in out with care where green blade hung together so that have space to move in to spread root abroad do assure now though may not believe be harder work to keep john fry bill dadds jem slocomb in line moving nimbly to tune of own tool than be to set out in morning alone hoe acre by dinner time for instead of keeping good ash moving must for ever be finding something to look at to speak of at rate to stop with blaming shape of tool perhaps talking about other people affair what be most irksome of to taking advantage a married men whispering joke of excellence about having having not being ashamed of sweetheart went so far young lady for so in sooth called way home with stable lanthorn begged good leave of farmer nicholas who have hung way behind to say word in private to before entered own house ' plaisure in laife zon 'ooman never kep in doubt about though there wad mooch to zettle on spak maind laike man did right happy be wi ' ah well day ah god knoweth best never will zee laike again be best judge of dung heap not to be cursed so 'nay think ill said kidney be good uncommon good if do without burning be so galled in saddle ten day never comely meal of when hear king service cried give worst of everything way down from london have rogue of fellow in front of eating fat of land before one bowing down to must go three mile to one though never changed horse might have robbed at minute if have be worth trouble red mare rideth strong in loin pointed quite small in head will live to see hanged yet time be riding across straw of courtyard getting weary leg out of leather almost afraid to stand yet coarse grained hard faced man be forty year of age so of middle height stature be dressed in dark brown riding suit none better for exmoor mud fitting very differently from fashion of tailor across holster lay cloak made of red skin shining from sweating of horse a looked down on stiff bright head piece small quick eye black needly beard seemed to despise too much a thought for mere ignoramus country with skewer that may run more sparkling ' ' wish may go to place never meant for ' said new friend now wiping mouth with sleeve of brown riding coat 'if ever fell among such good folk be right sort now be of red deer running wild in part 'to be sure be sir ' answered 'where must get other 'right right be right son have heard that flavour be marvellous of came scared so in fog of morning hungered
