sharply 'and horse that suffers will not be thine wish to know when must start upon long travel to london town perceive that matter be of great despatch urgency ' be sure so be son see yearling turkey there mean with hop in walk who if know aught of fowl must roast well to morrow thy mother must have preparation be more than reasonable now have turkey killed to night for fatness make long for will have for dinner to morrow with perhaps one of brother few more collops of red deer flesh for supper then on friday morning with grace of god will set face to road upon majesty business ' 'nay good sir asked with trembling so eager be to see lorna 'if majesty business will keep till friday may not keep until monday have litter of sucking pig excellently choice white six week old come friday there be too many for sow one of needeth roasting think not must be pity to leave woman to carve ' bey son jack ' replied master stickles be in such quarter yet god forbid must be so unthankful to a to hurry away now think on friday be not day upon pious people love to commence enterprise will choose young pig to morrow at noon at time be wont to gambol will celebrate birthday by carving on friday after will gird loin set forth early on saturday ' now be little better to than if have set forth at once sunday being very first day upon must be honourable for to enter glen doone though tried possible mean with master jeremy stickles offering choice for dinner of beast be on farm durst not put off departure later than saturday nothing else love of of hospitality must have so persuaded to remain with till then therefore now only chance of seeing lorna before went lay in watching from cliff espying signal from however did in vain until eye be weary often must delude with hope of what ached for though lay hidden behind tree upon crest of stony fall waited so quiet that rabbit squirrel played around even keen eyed weasel took for trunk of wood be a one cast of colour changed white stone whose whiteness now be hateful to did wreath skirt of maiden break loneliness of vale chapter xxiv safe pas for king messenger journey to london seemed to in bygone day a hazardous dark adventure a must be forced on man mean of course poor man for to great nobleman with ever so many outrider attendant retainer risk be not so great unless highwayman knew of coming beforehand so combined against to poor man however risk be not so much from gentleman of road a from more ignoble footpad landlord of lesser hostel loose unguarded soldier over above pitfall quagmire of way so that be hard to settle at first outgoing whether man be wise to pray more for neck for head nowadays be very different not that highway men be scarce in reign of good queen anne for in truth thrive a well a ever albeit deserve not being le upright courteous that road be much improved growing use of stage waggon of will travel a much a forty mile in summer day have turned ancient idea of distance almost upside down doubt whether god be pleased with flying so fast away from however be not business doe lie in mouth to speak very strongly upon subject seeing how much have done towards making of road upon exmoor to return to story in truth lose that road too often must have taken ten king messenger to get away from plover barrow without one goodbye to lorna for sense of trust reliance majesty have reposed in now felt most bitterly how very arrangement seemed so wise indeed ingenious may by force of event become most fatal obstacle for lo be blocked entirely from going to see lorna whereas must have fixed so that a well might have power of signalling necessity be too late now to think of so made up mind at last to keep honour on side to king to maiden although might lose everything except heavy heart for indeed more heart than mine be heavy for when came to tug of parting mother be like so be annie to break down altogether bade be of good cheer smiled in briskest manner upon said must be back next week a one of majesty greatest captain told not to fear then upon smiled at idea of ever being afraid of dress might have on so kissed hand once more rode away very bravely bless heart must no more have done so than flown way to london if jeremy stickles have not be there not to take too much credit to myself in matter must confess that when be come to turn in road where moor begin whence see last of yard rick poultry round can by knowing place obtain glance of kitchen window under walnut tree went so hard with just here that even made pretence of stone in ancient smiler shoe to dismount to bend head awhile then knowing that have left behind must be watching to see last of might have false hope of coming back mounted again with possible courage rode after jeremy stickles jeremy seeing how much be down did best to keep up with joke tale light discourse until before have ridden league began to long to see thing be describing air weather thought of going to wondrous place added to fine company at least so jeremy said be of man who knew london made feel must be ungracious not to laugh little being very simple then laughed more little something quite considerable though free from consideration at strange thing master stickles told strange way of telling so became very excellent friend for be much pleased with laughing not wishing to thrust more forward than need be in narrative have scarcely thought becoming right to speak of own adornment now what with brave clothes have on better one still that be packed up in bag behind saddle be almost beyond to forbear saying that must have looked very pleasing many time wished going along lorna must only be here there watching behind furze bush looking at wondering how much clothes have cost for mother must have stint in matter have assembled at house immediately upon knowledge of what be to be about london man known to be good stitcher upon side of exmoor for three day have worked best without stint of beer cider according to constitution of result so declared be such a to create admiration defy competition in london to seemed that be quite right though jeremy stickles turned up nose feigned to be deaf in business now be that matter a please for point be not worth arguing certain be that appearance be better than have be before for being in best clothes one try to look to act so far a may be up to quality of not only for fear of soiling that enlarge man perception of value strike that sin arise partly from disdain of others mainly from contempt of self working despite of god men of mind may not be measured by such paltry rule a by dinner time arrived at porlock dined with old friend master pooke now growing rich portly for though have plenty of victual with be not to begin upon until chance of victualling among friend be left behind during first day have need to meddle with store at for a have be settled before left home lay that night at dunster in house of worthy tanner first cousin to mother who received very cordially undertook to return old smiler to stable at plover barrow after one day rest thence hired to bridgwater from bridgwater on to bristowe breaking journey between two although whole way be so new to perpetual source of conflict that remembrance still abides with a if be yesterday must not be so long in telling a be in travelling will wish farther because lorna be nothing there also because man in neighbourhood have done whole of since time feigns to think nothing of however one thing in common justice to person who have be traduced be bound to mention be that being two of of such magnitude never must have made journey without fight running for free pas dear annie by mean know not what have procured from master faggus when let be known by hap be own cousin of tom faggus honoured with society there be not house upon road be proud to entertain in spite of fellow traveller bearing red badge of king ' will keep close son jack ' said having stripped off with carving knife 'your flag be best to fly man who starved on way down same will feed fat going home ' therefore pursued way in excellent condition having thriven upon credit of very popular highwayman being surrounded with regret that have left profession sometimes begged to intercede that might help road again for landlord on road declared that now small ale be drunk much of spirit called for because farmer need not prime to meet only common rider be worth while to get drunk with afterwards master stickles undertook a officer of king justice to plead case with squire faggus a everybody called now to induce for general good to return to proper ministry be long weary journey although road be wondrous good on farther side of bristowe scarcely man need be bogged if keep eye well open save perhaps in berkshire in consequence of pas have vintner knowledge of only met two public rider one of whom made off straightway when saw companion pistol stout carbine bore other came to parley with proved most kind affable when knew in presence of cousin of squire faggus save gentleman ' cried lifting hat politely beany many happy day have worked road with such time will never be again commend to love prayer king name be king nature say that none will harm so made off down hill being perfect gentleman very good horse be riding night be falling very thick by time be come to tyburn here king officer decided that must be wise to halt because way be unsafe by night across field to charing village for part be nothing loth preferred to see london by daylight after be not worth seeing very hideous dirty place not at like of shop be very fine sign above finer still so that be never weary of standing still to look at in doing there be ease for before one must begin almost to make out meaning of of wayfarer must bustle scowl draw sword owner apprentice boy must rush out catch hold of cry 'buy buy buy what d 'ye lack what d lack buy buy buy ' at first mistook meaning of for so pronounce word upon exmoor answered with indignation be boy now man of one twenty year a for lacking lack naught from thee except what thou hast not good manner only thing pleased much be river thames hall church of westminster where there be brave thing to be seen braver still to think about whenever wandered in street what with noise people made number of coach running of footman swaggering of great courtier thrusting aside of everybody many many time longed to be back among sheep again for fear of losing temper be welcome to wall for a took care to tell for must stand without wall perhaps be more than must do though said with best intention meaning discourtesy of be vexed at one young lord being flushed with drink drew sword made at struck up with holly stick so that flew on roof of house then took by belt with one hand laid in kennel caused little disturbance none of rest saw fit to try how matter might be with now being year of lord more than nine year half since death of father beginning of history london be in great ferment about dispute between court of king city king rather perhaps party for said that majesty cared for little except to have plenty of money spend be quite resolved to be supreme in appointment of chief officer of corporation citizen maintained that under charter right lay entirely with upon writ be issued against for forfeiture of charter question be now being tried in court of majesty bench seemed to occupy attention of judge case have appeared so urgent be put off from time to time while court city contended so hot be conflict hate between that sheriff have be fined by king in pound former lord mayor have even be sentenced to pillory because must not swear falsely hence courtier citizen scarce must meet in street with patience without railing frequent blow now although heard so much of matter for nothing else be talked of seeming to more important even than churchwardenship of oare must not for life of tell side must take to for sense of position of confidence reposed in of father opinion lay heavily in one scale while reason heart went down plump against injustice seemed to win other scale even so father have be at breaking out of civil war when be le than age now even le skilled in politics mother told after when saw how be doubting vexed with for doing so that father used to thank god often that have not be called upon to take one side other might remain obscure quiet yet always considered to be good sound royalist now a stayed there only desirous to be heard to get away scarcely even guessing yet what be wanted of for even jeremy stickles knew not pretended not to know thing came to dreadful pas between king people who dared to have opinion for about middle of june judge gave sentence that city of london have forfeited charter that franchise must be taken into hand of king scarcely be judgment forth men hotly talking of when far worse thing befell news of great conspiracy be spread at corner that man in malting business have tried to take up brewer work lop king duke of york everybody be shocked at for king be not disliked so much a adviser everybody be more than shocked grieved indeed to heart with pain at hearing that lord william russell mr algernon sidney have be seized sent to tower of london upon charge of high treason having knowledge of great men of matter how far be true have not very much to say about of silence be not shared although ignorance may have be by hundred of people around commotion be astir such universal sense of wrong stern resolve to right that man grasped fellow hand led into vintner even although at time given to excess in temperance afraid of name of cordial be hard set do assure not to be drunk at interval without coarse discourtesy however that a betty muxworthy used to say when argued down ready to take mop for be here there have naught to do with great history be sorry for who have to write because be sure to have friend enemy in can not act a must towards without damage to own conscience a great event draw little one rattle of churn decides uncertainty of fly so movement of town eloquence passion have more than guessed at time to do with own little fortune for in first place be fixed perhaps from down right contumely because citizen loved so that lord russell must be tried at westminster at lincoln inn at court of old bailey within precinct of city kept hanging on much longer because although good nobleman be to be tried by court of common plea yet officer of king bench to whom daily applied be in counsel with fellow put off from day to day now have heard of law delay greatest of great poet knowing much of law a indeed of everything have specially mentioned when not expected among many ill of life never thought at year to have such bitter experience of evil seemed to that if lawyer failed to do duty ought to pay people for waiting upon instead of making pay for here be now in second month living at own charge in house of worthy fellmonger at sign of seal squirrel abutting upon strand road lead from temple bar to charing here did very well indeed having mattress of good skin dressing plenty to eat day of life butter be something to cry 'but thrice at according to conceit of school day milk must have come from cow driven to water however evil be light compared with heavy bill sent up to saturday afternoon knowing how mother have pinched to send nobly to london have told to spare for nothing live bravely with best of tear very nearly came into eye a thought while ate of so robbing at length being quite at end sign jeremy stickles be quit of went upon other business not what be kind good to when time pursuit allowed of chapter xxv great man attends to business having seen lord russell murdered in field of death of charles first many people hurried past chiefly of more tender sort revolting at butchery in ghastly face a turned back lest sight must be coming after great sorrow be to be seen horror pity anger in westminster hall found nobody not even crowd of crawling varlet who used to be craving evermore for employment for payment knocked at three door one after other of lobby going out of where have formerly seen officer people pressing in out for trouble took nothing except thump from echo at last old man told that lawyer be gone to see result of own work in field of lincoln inn however in few day time have better fortune for court be sitting full of business to clear off arrears of work before lawyer holiday a be waiting in hall for good occasion man with horsehair on head long blue bag in left hand touched gently on arm led into quiet place followed very gladly being confident that came to with message from justiciary after taking pain to be sure that none must overhear turned on suddenly asked 'now john how be dear mother 'worshipful sir answered after recovering from surprise at knowledge of affair kindly interest in 'it be two month now since have seen must to god that only knew how be faring now how business of farm go beir respect admire ' old gentleman replied with bow very low genteel 'few young court gallant of time be so reverent dutiful oh how did love mother ' here turned up eye to heaven in manner made feel for yet with kind of wonder be very sorry for sir ' answered most respectfully not meaning to trespass on grief yet wondering at mother age for seemed to be at least threescore 'but be court gallant sir be only farmer son learning how to farm little 'enough john quite enough ' cried ' can read in thy countenance honesty be written there shoulder man have oak desk before set at little distance spread with pen paper instead of writing however seemed to be laughing talking rather one in middle seemed to be telling good story others received with approval by reason of great peruke be hard to tell how old be one who be speaking seemed youngest although be chief of thick set burly bulky man with blotchy broad face great square jaw fierce eye full of blaze be one to be dreaded by gentle soul to be abhorred by noble between three lord judge few lawyer be gathering up bag paper pen so forth from narrow table in middle of room a if case have be disposed of other be called on before have time to look round twice stout fierce man espied shouted out with flashing stare ' 'how now countryman who art thou ' please worship ' answered loudly ' be john ridd of oare parish in shire of somerset brought to london two month back by special messenger whose name be jeremy stickles then bound over to be at hand ready when called upon to give evidence in matter unknown to touching peace of lord king well being of subject three time have met lord king hath said nothing about peace only held towards day save sunday have walked up down great hall of westminster business part of day expecting to be called upon yet one hath called upon now desire to ask worship whether may go home again 'well done john ' replied lordship while be panting with speech ' will go bail for thee john thou hast never made such long speech before thou art spunky briton thou couldst not have made now remember matter well will attend to although arose before time ' be newly chief justice 'but can not take now john there be fear of losing thee john more than tower of london grieve for majesty exchequer after keeping thee two month more ' lord crave approver bey lord lord ' whispered mr spank chief officer of evidence 'the thing hath be overlooked lord among such grave matter of treason will overlook thy head foul spank on spike from temple bar worth at least ten pound to 'be thou here again to morrow before other case be taken will see justice done to thee now be off boy thy name be ridd be well rid of thee ' be only too glad to go after so going back to lodging at once opened clothes sought for spot especially a being so long at hairy fellmonger finding none fell down thanked god for same vowed to start for oare to morrow with different mood be on tell thee jack men be liar be least one who press not too hard on for lying ' be quite dark to for never looked at thing like never must own liar not at least to other people even to although might to god sometimes when trouble be upon if come to man have right to be called 'liar ' for smoothing over thing unwitting through duty to neighbour 'five pound thou shalt have jack ' said jeremy stickles suddenly while be abroad with a to being liar not 'five pound will take chance of wringing from that great rogue spank ten must have made john for bad luck lately put back bit of paper lad will have acknowledgment john ridd nonsense with ' for be ready to kiss hand to think that man in meanest most suspicious place upon god earth must trust with five pound without even receipt for overcame so sobbed for after though big in body be child at heart be not five pound moved way of giving after so much bitter talk great trust in goodness chapter xxvii home again at last be beginning of wheat harvest when came to dunster town having walked way from london being somewhat footsore for though five pound be enough to keep in food lodging upon road leave many shilling to give to far poorer traveller must have be nothing for horse hire a knew too well by price jeremy stickles have paid upon way to london now never saw prettier town than dunster looked that evening for sooth to say have almost lost hope of reaching night although castle be long in view being once there trouble be gone at least a regarded wayfaring for mother cousin worthy tanner with whom have slept on way to london be in such indignation at plight in came back to afoot weary almost shoeless not to speak of upper thing that swore then by mercy of god that if scheme abrewing round against bloody papist must come to head shape show good chance of succeeding must risk thousand pound a though be penny told not to do because have heard otherwise be not at liberty to tell one tenth of what knew indeed have seen in london town of took heed because only nodded at must not make out for take old man at least middle aged one to nod wink with power on brain of other men however think made know that bad state in came to town great shame have wrought for among folk round card table at luttrell arm be not to be even there attributed to king charles second even to counsellor to own speed of travelling have beat post horse for being much distraught in mind desperate in body have made way from london to dunster in six day more may be one hundred seventy mile can not tell to furlong two especially a lost way more than dozen time at rate there in six day be most kindly received tanner have excellent daughter forget how many very pretty damsel well set up able to make good pastry though asked many question made sort of lord of offered to darn stocking in truth required fell asleep in midst of although must not acknowledge said 'poor cousin be weary ' led to blessed bed kissed round like swan down in morning exmoor hill thought of have frightened at end of day travel seemed more than bushel to a looked forth bedroom window thanked god for sight of even so have not to climb at least by own labour for most worthy uncle a oft call parent cousin finding impossible to keep for day owning indeed be right in hastening to mother vowed that walk must not even though lost saturday hide from minehead from watchett accordingly sent forth on very strongest nag have maiden came to wish god speed kissed hand at doorway made proud glad to think that after seeing so much of world having held own with be come once more among own people found kinder more warm hearted ay better looking too than almost have happened upon in mighty city of london how will tell thing felt to lay before one tenth of thing came home to in one half hour a sun be sinking in real way ought to sink touched horse with spur whip feeling that slow wit must go if sight came too fast over here be pool where washed sheep there be hollow oozed away where have shot three wild duck here be peat rick hid dinner when must not go home for there be bush with thyme growing round where annie have found great swarm of bee now be corner of dry stone wall where moor gave over in earnest partridge whisked from into corn land called that supper be ready looked at house rick a ran must wait for comfort till winter there saw let go annie be too much for nearly pulled off horse kissed very mouth of carbine knew must come oh john oh john have waited here saturday night saw for last mile more must not come round corner for fear must cry john then not cry when got now may cry a much a like need not try to stop john because be so happy must cry john what will mother think of will be so jealous of ' what mother thought can not tell indeed doubt if thought at for more than hour only managed to hold tight cry thank god now then with fear of taking if must be too grateful moreover thought be own doing ought to have credit of even came down very sharply upon john wife mr fry for saying that must not be too proud for of be lord doing however dear mother be ashamed of afterwards asked mr fry horse coming with young master mistress upon for annie must need get up behind there being only sheep to look at then smiler gave stare neigh with tail quite stiff with amazement then whether in joy through indignation flung up hind foot galloped straight home set dog wild with barking now methinks quite enough have be said concerning mighty return of young john ridd be known up at cosgate that evening feeling can not describe how can hope that one else will labour to imagine even of few who be able for very few can have travelled so far unless indeed whose trade be very unsettled people even of who have done so not one in hundred can have such home a have to come home to mother wept again with grief wrath so did annie also even little eliza be unsettled in loyalty talked about republic when told how have be left without money for travelling homeward expected to have to beg way farmer snowe must have heard of though must see be disappointed at failure of promotion declared present have for then kissed almost like annie vowed that thought very little of captain for lizzie present be best of mean of course except lorna carried in breast way hoping that might make love from having lain so long close to heart for have brought lizzie something dear precious heavy book be much beyond understanding whereas knew well that to others gift must be dear for mine own sake happier people must not be found than whole of be that evening chapter xxviii john have hope of lorna much a longed to know more about lorna though heart be yearning must not reconcile yet with duty to mother annie to leave on following day happened to be sunday for lo before breakfast be out of mouth there came men of farm wife even two crow boy dressed a if going to barnstaple fair to inquire how master john be whether be true that king have made one of body guard if so what be to be done with belt for championship of west county wrestling have held now for year more none be ready to to wear belt for honour of oare parish so long a ever god gave strength health to meet comer for have never be asked to be body guard if asked must never have done of cried that king must be mazed not london at rate be much better in virtue of coming home again for now have learned joy of quiet gratitude for good thing round love owe to others even who must be kind for indulgence to before journey have be too much a matter of course to having missed now knew that be gift might be lost moreover have pined so much in dust heat of great town for tree field running water sound of country life air annie get best of have long outgrown unwholesome feeling a to father death so have annie though lizzie who must have loved least still entertained evil will longing for punishment therefore be here annie inquired rather sternly being vexed with for having gone so very near to frighten nothing at said annie shortly indeed be truth enough for woman not dare to believe that woman be such liar a men say only that mean often see thing round corner know not be of indeed never have known woman though right enough in meaning purely perfectly true transparent except only lorna even so might not have loved if have be ugly how so ' said annie what business have here doing nothing at time of night leaving with trouble to entertain guest 'you seem not to to be doing john ' annie answered softly 'what business have here doing nothing at time of night ' be taken so aback with extreme impertinence of from mere young girl like annie turned round to march away have nothing more to say to jumped up caught by hand threw upon bosom with face wet with tear john will tell will tell only be angry john 'angry indeed said 'what right have to be angry with because have secret chit of girl think now that have right to secret 'and have none of own john of course have none of own going out at night ' 'we will not quarrel here poor annie answered with loftiness 'there be many thing upon mind girl can have notion of 'and so there be upon mine john oh john will tell everything if will look at kindly promise to forgive oh be so miserable ' now though be behaving so badly moved much towards especially a longed to know what have to tell therefore allowed to coax to kiss to lead away little a far a old yew tree for must not tell where be even in shadow there be very long before beginning meant for knew that must go on night if one encouraged though not well acquainted with woman understood sister else must be born fool except of course never professed to understand eliza 'yes will to there be nothing meaner than for man to sneak steal young maid heart without people knowing ' 'you be not doing anything of sort then dear john be ' 'only common highwayman answered without heeding ' man without acre of own liable to hang upon common other right of common over ' 'john said sister 'be doones privileged not to be hanged upon common land at be so thunderstruck that leaped in air like shot rabbit rushed a hard a must through gate across yard back into kitchen there asked farmer nicholas snowe to give tobacco to lend spare pipe did with grateful manner being now five fourth gone so smoked very first pipe that ever have entered lip till then beyond doubt did good spread heart at leisure meanwhile reaper be mostly gone to be up betimes in morning be led by wife have to lead wife according to capacity of man wife respectively betty be a lively a ever bustling about with one looking out for chance of groat better off might be free with over kneading pan next day dropped three sixpence out of pocket lizzie must not tell for life how much more might have be in now by time have almost finished smoking that pipe of tobacco wondering at for having so despised hitherto making up mind to have trial to morrow night began to occur to that although dear annie have behaved so very badly rudely almost taken breath away with suddenness of allusion yet be not kind of to leave out there at time of night alone in such distress of reaper going home might be gotten so far beyond fear of ghost a to venture into churchyard although must know great deal better than to insult sister of mine when sober there be telling what might do in present state of rejoicing moreover be only right must learn for lorna sake how far annie one else have penetrated secret therefore went forth at once bearing pipe in skilful manner a have seen farmer nicholas do marking with new kind of pleasure how ring wreath of smoke hovered fluttered in moonlight like lark upon carol poor annie be gone back again to father grave there sat upon turf sobbing very gently not wishing to trouble one so raised tenderly made much of consoled for must not scold there perhaps after be not to be further to lead away from own affair into mine concerning lorna although be clever enough of be not deep enough for there soon discovered that knew nothing not even name of darling only suspected from huckaback over from dulverton at time of year when clothing business be most active on account of harvest wage when new wheat be beginning to sample from early part up country for meddled a well in corn dealing when must not attend to properly by reason of occupation yet more surprising seemed to that must have brought granddaughter also instead of troop of dragoon without have vowed must never have much ado to hold mouth being like bucket be come to top of long black combe two mile more from plover barrow winding to southward stopped little nag short of crest got off looked ahead of from one although be in barren land at least cow have gotten trick have heard other people complain of john fry a said knew place well enough liked none more for did of people indeed neighbourhood of thomshill larksborough most of black barrow down lay under grave imputation of having be enchanted with very evil spell moreover be known though folk be loath to speak of even on summer morning that squire thom who have be murdered there century ago more have be seen by several shepherd even in middle day walking with severed head carried in left hand right arm lifted towards sun therefore be very bold in john a acknowledged to venture across moor alone even with fast pony under whisky by side must never have done so of be quite certain for sake of annie sweet face of golden guinea three maiden have subscribed to reward skill valour truth be that must not resist own great curiosity for carefully spying across moor from behind tuft of whortles at first must discover nothing having life motion except three four wild cattle roving in vain search for nourishment diseased sheep banished hither carrion crow keeping watch on when john be taking very last look being only too glad to go home again acknowledge baffled thought saw figure moving in farthest distance upon black barrow down scarcely thing to be sure of yet on account of want of colour a watched figure passed between naked cliff appeared to be man on horseback making way very carefully in fear of bog serpent for about there be adder ground large black serpent dwell in marsh can swim a well a crawl john knew that man who be riding there must be none uncle reuben for none of doones ever passed way shepherd be afraid of now seemed unkind place for unarmed man to venture through especially after armed one who might not like to be spied upon must have dark object in visiting such drear solitude nevertheless john fry so ached with unbearable curiosity to know what old man stranger rich man peaceable must possibly be after in mysterious manner moreover john so throbbed with hope to find wealthy secret that come what must of resolved to go to end of matter therefore only waited awhile for fear of being discovered till master huckaback turned to left entered little gully whence must not survey moor then john remounted crossed rough land stony place picked way among morass a fast a ever dared to go until in about hour drew nigh entrance of gully now behoved to be most wary for uncle ben might have stopped in there to rest horse having reached end of journey in case john have little doubt that must be pistolled nothing more ever heard of therefore made pony come to mouth of sideways leaned over peered in around rocky corner while little horse cropped at briar soon perceived that gully be empty so far at least a course be straight with hastened into though heart be not working easily when have traced winding hollow for mile more saw that forked one part led to left up steep red bank other to right being narrow slightly tending downwards yellow sand lay here there between starving grass examined narrowly for trace of master huckaback at last saw that beyond doubt man be pursuing have taken course led down hill down hill must follow john did with deep misgiving hearty wish that have never started upon so perilous errand for now knew not where be scarcely dared to ask having heard of horrible hole somewhere in neighbourhood called wizard slough therefore john rode down slope with sorrow great caution grew more a went onward pony reared against being scared although native of roughest moorland john have just made up mind that god meant for warning a passage seemed darker deeper when suddenly turned corner saw scene stopped for there be wizard slough a black a death bubbling with few scant yellow reed in ring around outside bright water grass of liveliest green be creeping tempting unwary foot to step plunge founder on marge be blue campanula sundew forget not such a child must resist on side hill fell back ground be broken with tuft of rush flag mare tail few rough alder tree overclogged with water not bird be seen heard rail water hen wag tail reed warbler of horrible quagmire worst upon exmoor john have heard from grandfather even from mother when wanted to keep quiet father have feared to speak of to being man of piety up to trick of evil one made john more desirous to have good look at now only with girth well up to turn away flee at speed if anything must happen now proved how well be to be wary wide awake even in lonesome place for at other side of slough few land yard beyond where ground be le noisome have observed felled tree lying over great hole in earth with stave of wood slab of stone yellow gravel around flag of reed around morass partly screened from eye must not make out meaning of except that meant good probably be witchcraft yet dolly seemed not to be harmed by for there be a large a life tied to stump not far beyond flipping fly away with tail while john be trembling within lest dolly must get scent of pony neigh reveal presence although must not see suddenly to great amazement something white arose out of hole under brown trunk of tree seeing blood went back within yet be not able to turn flee rooted face in among loose stone kept quivering shoulder back prayed to god to protect however white thing be not so very awful being nothing more than long coned night cap with tassel on top such a criminal wear at hanging time when john saw man face under man neck shoulder slowly rising out of pit must not doubt that be place where murderer come to life again according to exmoor story knew that man have be hanged last week that be ninth day after therefore must bear more thoroughly brave a have be neither did wait to see what became of gallows man climbed on horse with what speed might rode away at full gallop neither did dare go back by way came fearing to face black barrow down therefore struck up other track leading away towards cloven rock after riding hard for hour drinking whisky luckily fell in with shepherd who led on to public house somewhere near exeford here be so unmanned excitement being over nothing le than gallon of ale gammon of bacon brought to right mind again took good care to be home before dark having followed well known sheep track when john fry finished story at last after many exclamation from annie from lizzie much praise of gallantry yet little disappointment that have not stayed there little longer while be about so a to be able to tell more said to very sternly 'now john have dreamed man firmly believe that fell asleep at top of black combe after drinking whisky never went on moor at know what liar be john ' girl be exceedingly angry at laid hand before mouth waited for john to answer with eye fixed upon steadfastly 'bai for to denai ' said john looking at very honestly 'but what maight tull lai now awhiles zame a other men most of arl a spaks again here be lai maister jan wush to god wor boy maight slape naight better believe speak truth john ask pardon now not word to one about strange affair there be mischief brewing can see be place to attend to several thing come across now only will not tell ' be not at contented with must give better except to say when plagued greatly vowed to sleep at door night dear be foolish of too much of matter be known already be for own dear sake be bound to be cautious have opinion of own may be very wrong one will not ask to share with will make inquisitive ' annie pouted lizzie frowned ruth looked at with eye wide open other mark of regarding saw that if one of three for john fry be gone home with tremble must be trusted to keep secret that one be ruth huckaback chapter xxxii feeding of pig story told by john fry night conviction of truth made very uneasy especially a following upon warning of judge jeffreys hint received from jeremy stickles outburst of tanner at dunster a well a sundry tale rumour sign of secret understanding seen heard on market day at place of entertainment knew for certain that at taunton bridgwater even dulverton there be much disaffection towards king regret for day of puritan albeit have told truth pure simple truth when upon examination have assured lordship to best of knowledge there be nothing of sort with now be beginning to doubt whether might not have be mistaken especially when heard a did of arm being landed at lynmouth in dead of night of tramp of men having reached one ear from hill where famous echo be for must be plain to conspirator without example of doones for secret muster of men stowing of unlawful arm communication by beacon light scarcely fitter place must be found than wild of exmoor with deep ravine running far inland from unwatched mostly sheltered sea for channel from countisbury foreland up to minehead even farther though rocky gusty full of current be safe from great roller sweeping power of south west storm prevail with more than others make sad work on opposite coast even supposing probable that something against king charles second rather against roman adviser especially brother be now in preparation amongst be likely that master huckaback wealthy man careful one known moreover to lord chief justice must have anything to do with to must make answer uncle ben be so close man so avaricious so revengeful that be quite impossible to say what course might pursue without knowing chance of gain rise satisfaction to that hated papist knew full well though never spoke much about also that have followed march of oliver cromwell army more a suttler people said than a real soldier that must go long way risk great deal of money to have revenge on doones although name never passed lip during present visit how be likely to be a to doones side must probably take in coming movement if movement indeed must be so far a have religion at by birth be roman catholic so much knew from lorna indeed be well known around that priest have be fetched more than once to valley to soothe poor outlaw departure on other hand be not likely to entertain much affection for son of man who have banished confiscated property be not at impossible that desperate men such a be having nothing to lose estate to recover not being held by religion much must cast away regard for birth from have be cast out make common cause with protestant rising for chance of revenge replacement however mean to say that thing occurred to a clearly a have set down only be in general doubt very sad perplexity became aware of great man coming eisurely down valley have broad brimmed hat leather jerkin heavy jack boot to middle thigh what be worst of for on shoulder bore long carbine having nothing to meet withal staff desiring to avoid disturbance retired promptly into chasm keeping tree betwixt that might not descry watching from behind jut of rock where now have scraped neat little hole for purpose presently great man reappeared being now within fifty yard of light still good enough a drew nearer for to descry feature though be not judge of men face there be something in turned cold a though with kind of horror not that be ugly face nay rather seemed handsome one so far a mere form line might go full of strength vigour will steadfast resolution from short black hair above broad forehead tumult such a must call own even if god must allow in lieu of wild inheritance be quite certain that doones never can never will ' again when told how mother annie a well a longed to have at plover at least within utmost reach of amiable family be too plain to be denied seeing dejection at told bravely that must hope for better time if possible asked how long must wait for 'not day if have will ' answered very warmly at turned away confused must not look at for awhile 'but life ' went on to say fortune be so ill how long must wait for lorna ' 'till must get ' answered slyly with smile be brighter to than brightest wit must be 'and now continued bound john with very beautiful ring to when dare not wear carry always on heart will bind to dearest with very poorest plainest thing that described before in london have earned mother gratitude so far a ever chose to have seemed inclined to have for made farm house headquarters kept quite at beck call going out at time of evening coming quite at disposal also knew that never went out even slept in bedroom without heavy firearm well loaded sharp sword nigh hand that held great commission under royal signet requiring good subject to know meaning of being trusted a be by lord chief justice found scarcely supple enough gifted with due brain god for same answered while tapped head to signify own much larger allowance then made agreed that be comfort chapter xxxviii good turn for jeremy john fry have now six shilling week of regular permanent wage besides harvest shearing money a well a cottage rent free enough of garden ground to rear pot herb for wife family now wage appointed by justice at time of session be four sixpence week for summer shilling le for winter time must be fined perhaps imprisoned for giving more than sum so fixed therefore john fry be looked upon a richest man upon exmoor mean of course among labourer there be many joke about robbing a if be mint of king tom faggus promised to try hand if came across john on highway although have ceased from business be seeking royal pardon now be according to human nature be thing contradictory a must fain believe anyhow there be upon exmoor more information against for paying too much wage now have not mentioned of john fry from disrespect for memory be green honest amongst far le from desire to hurt feeling of grandchild will do justice once for to avow thus publicly that have known great many bigger rogue most of in number have referred with moderation to little flaw in worthy character foible a call when man be dead for reason only that against ever since have offended jeremy by threatening a before related in case of meddling with affair have more more allied with simple minded john a be pleased to call john fry be everything be 'run fetch horse john ' 'john be pistol primed well ' want in stable john about something very particular ' until except for rudeness of be longing to tell master stickles that ought to pay john wage john for part be not backward gave most wonderful air of secrecy importance till parish began to think that affair of nation be in hand scorned sight of dungfork be not likely that must last being only man in parish with knowledge of politics gave john fry to understand that must not presume to talk so freely a if be at least constable about constitution must be affair of might bring into trouble at only tossed nose a if have be in london at least three time for one vexed so promised thick end of plough whip if even name of knight of shire must pas lip for fortnight now did not suspect in stupid noddle that john fry must ever tell jeremy stickles about sight at wizard slough man in white nightcap because john have sworn on blade of knife not to breathe word to soul without full permission however appears that john related for certain consideration that have seen doubtless more have accrued to upon master stickles be much astonished at uncle reuben proceeding having always accounted most loyal keen wary subject learned upon recovering jeremy good grace came to pas in other way than by saving of life being bound to keep strictest watch upon seven rook nest yet not bearing to be idle to waste mother store contrived to keep work entirely at western corner of farm be nearest to glen doone whence must easily run to height commanding view coveted one day squire faggus have dropped in upon just in time for dinner very soon king messenger be a thick a need be tom have brought beloved mare to show off to annie mounted pretty sweetheart upon after giving winnie notice to be on very best behaviour squire be in great spirit having just accomplished purchase of land be worth ten time what gave for did by merry trick upon old sir roger bassett who never supposed to be in earnest a not possessing money whole thing be done on bumper of claret in tavern where met old knight having once pledged word lawyer must hold back from must only say that master faggus being attainted of felony be not capable grantee will soon cure that ' tom pardon have be ready for month month so soon a care to sue ' now be telling annie who listened very rosily believed word said that having be ruined in early innocence by mean of lawyer be only just fair turn for turn that having become match for by long practice upon highway must reinstate at expense in society now must go to london at once sue out pardon then must lovely darling annie etc etc thing have right to hear in be not wanted therefore strode away up lane to afternoon employment sadly comparing love with theirs now appeared so prosperous yet heartily glad for annie sake only remembering now then old proverb never come right ' worked very hard in copse of young ash with billhook shearing knife cutting out sapling where stooled too close together making spar to keep for thatching wall crook to drive into cob stile for close sheep hurdle handle for rake hoe two bill of larger straighter stuff lesser bound in faggot to come home on sledd to woodrick be not to be supposed that did work without many peep at seven rook nest proved lorna safety indeed whenever wanted change either from cleaving hewing too hard stooping too much at binding be up away to ridge of hill instead of standing doing nothing soon forgot about tom annie fell to thinking of lorna only how much must make of what must call child how must educate to do honour to rank yet time worked none worse by reason of meditation fresh cut spar be not so good a of little seasoning especially if sap be not gone down at time of cutting therefore always find needful to have plenty still in stock be very pleasant there in copse sloping to west a be sun descending brightly with rock bank to dwell upon stem of mottled dimpled wood with twig coming out like elbow hung clung together closely with mode of bending in a child do at danger overhead shrunken leaf quivered rustled ripely having many point like star rising falling delicately a finger play sad music along bed of slanting ground between stool of wood there be heap of dead brown leaf sheltered mat of lichen drift of spotted stick gone rotten tuft of rush here there full of fray feathering by hedge ran little stream thing must barely name flowing scarce more than pint in minute because of sunny weather yet have rill little crook cranny dark bravely bearded gallant rush through reeden pipe stem of flag be grounded here there divided thread from point of branching stick into mighty pool of rock a large a grown man hat almost napped with moss around side hung with corded grass along down tiny bank nodding into one even across main channel hung brown arcade of fern with gold tongue languishing with countless ear drop jerking with great quilled rib uprising long saw aflapping others cupped fanning over with grace of yielding even a hollow fountain spread by wind have lost way deeply beyond other pluming stooping glancing glistening weaving softest pillow lace coying to wind water when fleeting image danced by beauty moved god have made lovelier thing only take heed of be time to go home to supper now felt very friendly towards having be hard at work for hour with only voice of little rill hare pheasant for company sun be gone down behind black wood on farther cliff of bagworthy russet of tuft spear bed be becoming gray while greyness of sapling ash grew brown against sky hollow curve of little stream became black beneath grass fairy fan innumerable while outside hedge clover be crimping leaf in dewfall like cocked hat of wood sorrel when thanking god for scene because love have gifted with key to thing lovely prepared to follow example to rest from labour therefore wiped bill hook shearing knife very carefully for hate to leave tool dirty be doubting whether must try for glance at seven rook nest whether must be too dark for be now quarter of hour mayhap since have made chopping noise because have be assorting spar tying in bundle instead of plying bill hook gentle tinkle of stream be louder than doings to doubt owe life then without dreaming be in little jeopardy for just a be twisting bine of very last faggot before tucking cleft tongue under there came three men outside hedge where western light be yellow by must see that three of carried firearm men be not walking carelessly following down hedge trough a if to stalk enemy for moment struck cold to think be be looking for with swiftness of terror concluded that visit to glen doone be known now life be forfeit be most lucky thing for that heard clothes catch in bramble saw hat under rampart of ash be made by what call beplashing ' lucky for stood in goyal have dark coppice behind to have time to fly with sort of instinct threw flat in among thick fern held breath lay still a log for have seen light gleam on gun barrel knowing fault of neighbourhood must fain avoid swelling number then three men came to gap in hedge where have be in out so often stood up looked in over be very well for man to boast that in life have never be frightened belief that never must be so there may be men of nature will not dare to deny only have never known fright be now in be horrible bone seemed to creep inside when lying there helpless with only billet comb of fern to hide in dusk of early evening saw three face in gap what be worse three gun muzzle be at work here ' be deep voice of carver doone up charlie look about must have witness 'give hand behind ' said charlie same handsome young doone have seen that night 'this bank be too devilish steep for ' 'there be big young fellow upon farm ' carver doone muttered sulkily 'with whom have account to settle if ever come across hath cursed spite to because shot father be going to bring lumper upon only unction for in bullet patch remember claim to be confessor because hath insulted ' 'thou art welcome to job for ' said marwood a turned away kept along hedge row ' love to meet man sword to sword not to pop at from foxhole what answer be made must not hear for by time stout ashen hedge be between other gap to be found in until at very bottom where corner of copse be yet be not quit of danger now know chief part of already disaffection to king rather dislike to brother james fear of roman ascendancy have existed now for several year of late be spreading rapidly partly through downright arrogance of tory faction cruelty austerity of duke of york corruption of justice confiscation of ancient right charter partly through jealousy of french king potent voice in affair partly perhaps one might even say mainly through natural tide in political channel verily move a if have moon for mistress sooner be thing done fixed being set far in advance perhaps of be done before like new mole in sea immediately water retire lest must undo one say how fine be leaf other people to walk on then after awhile vague endless ocean having retired lain still without breeze murmur fret heave again with impulse with lash laid on in one great surge advance over rampart so there be at time speak of great surge in england not rolling yet seething one thousand chief justice million jeremy stickles must never be able to stop turn by stringing up men in front of more than rope of onion can repulse volcano worst of be that great movement took wrong channel at first not only missing legitimate line roaring out that back ditchway be true established course of against rash random current nearly ancient mariner of state be set not to allow brave ship to drift there though little boat might try for present there seemed to be pause with open onset people on shore expecting according to wish feel of own finger whence rush of wind must come might direct water now to reduce high figure of speech into own little numeral town of somersetshire town of devonshire be full of pushing eager people ready to swallow anything to make others swallow whether believed folly about black box stuff be not for to say only one thing know pretended to do so persuaded ignorant rustic taunton bridgwater minehead dulverton took lead of other town in utterance of discontent threat of what meant to do if ever papist dared to climb protestant throne of england on other hand tory leader be not a yet under apprehension of immediate outbreak feared to damage own cause by premature coercion for struggle be not very likely to begin in earnest during life of present king unless must a people hoped be so far emboldened a to make public profession of faith held if so tory policy be to watch not indeed permitting opponent to gather strength muster in armed force with order being well apprised of scheme intended movement to wait for bold overt act then to strike severely a tory watchman spy a whig must call jeremy stickles be now among duty be threefold first most ostensibly to see to levying of poundage in little haven of lynmouth farther up coast be now becoming place of resort for folk whom call smuggler be to say who land good without regard to king revenue a by law established indeed there have be no officer appointed to take toll until one have be sent to minehead not so very long before excise a well have be ordered in time of long parliament have be little heeded by people hereabouts second duty be though only doones have discovered to watch outlaw narrowly report of manner be scanty doings be too manifold reputation be execrable politics whether true to king pope otherwise jeremy stickles third business be entirely political to learn temper of people gentle family to watch movement of trained band must not always be trusted to discover collecting of arm drilling of men among to prevent if need be by open force importation of gunpowder of there have be rumour in word to observe forestall enemy now in providing for last mentioned service government have made great mistake doubtless through anxiety to escape public attention for disposable force at emissary command amounted to more than score of musketeer so divided along coast a scarcely to suffice for duty of sentinel held commission be true for employment of train band upon understanding that be not to call upon except a last resource for political object although might use against doones a private criminal if found needful supposing that must get beo see john said in conclusion have more work than tool to do with be heartily sorry ever accepted mixed meagre commission at bottom of lie be well convinced not only desire to keep thing quiet paltry jealousy of military people because be not colonel forsooth captain in majesty service must never do to trust with company of soldier yet must not send colonel captain for fear of stir in rustic mind only thing can do with chance of success be remember perhaps sheaf in destined to be burned stolen before have finished bread have baked among trouble there be however seemed to be one comfort tom faggus returned from london very proudly very happily with royal pardon in black white everybody admired more because one must read word of squire acknowledged cheerfully that must sooner take fifty purse than read single line of people indeed went so far a to say that parchment be made from sheep tom have stolen be why prevaricated so in giving character knowing something by time of lawyer be able to contradict affirming that wolf have more than sheep to do with matter for according to old saying three learned profession live by roguery on three part of man doctor maul body parson starves soul lawyer must be adroitest knave for have to ensnare mind therefore take careful delight in covering trap engine with spread of dead leaf word whereof know little more than way to spell now tom faggus although having wit to gallop away on strawberry mare with speed of terror from lawyer having paid with money too honest to stop yet fell into reckless adventure ere ever came home from lawyer must have saved although ought to have needed none beyond common thought for dear annie now be ever have be so vexed about story can not tell pleasantly a try to write in general in own word manner therefore will let john fry whom have robbed of story to be more entitled whom have robbed of many speech thought very excellent lest must grieve one with lack of education last lack ever felt by bye now with good leave will allow poor john to tell tale in own word style have perfect right to do having be first to tell for squire faggus kept close not trusting even annie with at least said so because man know much of sweetheart tongue until have borne child two only before john begin story must say in duty to in common honesty dare not write down few of word because be not convenient for dialect other cause can not find way of spelling many of word do repeat so that people not born on exmoor may know how pronounced even if must bring lip leg to proper attitude in speak advisedly having observed thousand time that manner man have of spreading leg bending knee stiffening even way will set heel make difference in tone time of casting voice aright power of coming home to always liked john story not for wit in because laughed at man rather than matter way held head be enough with chin fixed hard like certainty especially during biggest lie not sign of smile in lip nose power of not laughing eye not turning to anybody unless somebody have too much of a young girl always do went over brink of laughter thereupon be good to see john fry how looked gravely first at laughter a much a to ask 'what be now then if fool went laughing more a be sure to do upon dry inquiry john must look again to be sure of then at somebody else to learn whether laugh have company then if got grin mirth came out in glory with sudden break wiped lip be grave again now john being too much encouraged by girl of must never break came into house that december evening with inch of full of tale annie saw lizzie of course even in gloom of great evil perceived that john be loaded gun did not care to explode now nothing primed so hotly a if wanted to hear john fry have heard surest of sure way to be to pretend not to care for word of ' wor over to exeford in morning ' john began from chimney corner looking straight at annie 'for to zee little calve jan a cudd get thee to lave houze about meesus have got quare vancy vor un from wutt have heer 'd of brade now zit quite wull ' e miss luzzie 'wunt goo on vurder vaine little tayl will tull ee if so be thee zit quite wull a coom down hill zeed saight of volks astapping of ro udwai arl 'only horrible ferocity of miserable blacksmith 'that be nayther here there ' john continued with wrath at own interruption knawed whutt squire have be veared to lose own custom if squire tuk to shooin ' again shutt man must myzell a intervared wi trade laike lucky for thee said bill blacksmith a thee beebet so shart fat jan dree on wor gooin ' to shutt 'ee till zeed how fat thee waz jan now bill answered 'un wi ' girt cold swat upon shutt bill own waife niver drame of ' here john fry looked round kitchen for have never said anything of kind doubt now made part of discourse from thinking that mistress fry be come a generally did to fetch 'wull done then jan vry ' said woman who have entered quietly be only old molly 'wutt handsome manner thee hast gat jan to spake so well of thy waife god knoweth be never in hurry must zooner stop goo on most taimes 'wi ' pulled vittles out zat horsebarck atin ' of 'em oncommon good be wo have 'un taime just saith tim potter a keepeth bull there yet be zorry for 'un man must kape law must zo be can only learn now poor tom will swing a high a top of girt hash there 'just thee kitch 'un virst say maisure rope wi ' body to maisure by here be now saith bill blacksmith grinning coom to help what grave gentleman warship of pace at laste 'for gentleman on cue ball horse be coming slowly down hill on tother zide of watter looking at in friendly way with long papper standing forth lining of coat laike horse stapped to drink in watter gentleman spak to 'un kindly then coom raight on to ussen gentleman face wor so long so grave veared ' wor gooin ' to prache to 'coort o king bench saith one man checker play saith spishal commission doubt saith bill blacksmith backed by mayor of taunton justice of king peace good people to be found near here said gentleman lifting hat to very gracious in manner honour saith bill with hat off head there be sax zeven warship here arl on very wise 'uns squaire maunder there be zinnyer beo gentleman rode up to squire maunder raised cocked hat in manner took squire out of countenance for must not do like of beir said good worshipful sir be here to claim good advice valour for purpose of justice hold majesty commission to make to cease notorious rogue whose name be thomas faggus with offered commission squire maunder told truth that must not rade even word in print much le written karakters then other magistrate rode up put head together how to meet london gentleman without loss of importance there wor one of a must rade purty vair made out king mark upon bowed upon horse to gentleman laid copy of letter from justice of peace to bookseller circa ad now in possession 'plez to zen ak relatting to gustus paks ed of l d 'then waving of hat began bowing making of leg to wan anather sich a nayver wor zeed afore none of 'em arl for air brading cud coom anaigh gentleman with long grave face 'your warship have posted men right well saith with anather bow round surely that big rogue will have chance left among so many valiant musketeer have what see there friend rust in pan of gun that gun must never go off sure a be king commissioner see just a bad lo there third pardon gentleman have be so used to majesty ordnance yard fear that bold rogue must ride through of laugh at worship beard by george what will do squire maunder axed vear there be oil here 'discharge piece gentleman let men do same at least let try to discharge load again with fresh powder be fog of morning hath spoiled priming that rogue be not in sight yet god know must not be asleep with what will majesty say to if let slip once more 'excellent wondrous well said good sir squire maunder answered never must have thought of now bill blacksmith tell men to be ready to shoot up into air directly give word now be ready there bill 'all ready worship saith bill saluting like soldier 'then one two dree shutt cry squire maunder standing up in iron of stirrup 'thereupon blazed out noise of went round hill with girt thick cloud arising air smelling of powder before cloud be gone so much a ten yard on wind gentleman on cue bald horse shuts up face like pair of nut crack a wide a be long before out pull two girt pistol longside of zaddle clap'th one to squire maunder head tother to sir richard blewitt 'hand forth money warrant saith like clap of thunder gentleman have now wit to apprehend tom faggus maunder swore so that ought to be fined pulled out purse none slower for so did sir richard blewitt man see go to load gun will gi e 'un bullet to do with said tom for see be other looking quietly round upon of then robbed rest of warship a pleasant a might be saith now gentleman do duty serve warrant afore imprison with made give up warrant stuck in band of hat then made bow with 'good morning to warship now merry christmas of merrier for rich poor when gentleman see almsgiving lest deny yourselves pleasure will aid warship to save trouble of following when gun be loaded be strawberry mare gentleman only with little cream on gentleman in name of king thank 'all while be casting money among poor folk by handful then spak kaindly to red mare wor over back of hill in two zeconds best part of two maile away reckon afore ever gun wor loaded ' truth of story be well established by first rate tradition chapter xl two fool together that story of john fry instead of causing amusement gave great disquietude not only because showed that tom faggus must not resist sudden temptation delight of wildness also that greatly feared lest king pardon might be annulled kindness cancelled by reckless deed of sort be true a annie insisted continually even with tear to wear in argument that tom have not brought away anything except warrant be of use at after receipt of pardon have used violence except just to frighten people must be established even towards christmas time tom have right to give alms right left out of other people money dear annie appeared to believe that must saying that if rich continually chose to forget poor man who forced to remember so to do good to to others be public benefactor entitled to blessing knew so lizzie knew john fry being now out of hearing that be not sound argument for if came to that man might take king by throat make cast away among poor money wanted sadly for grace duchess beautiful countess of of lizzie of course knew nothing about majesty diversion be not fit for young maid thought now put form of argument a occurred to therefore said once for sister always listened when used deep voice from chest faggus hath done wrong herein wrong to to annie need have done be to show pardon magistrate must have rejoiced with might have led most godly life have be respected by everybody knowing how brave tom be thought that must have done a much now if be in love with maid ' put thus for sake of poor lizzie must so imperil life fortune in life along with for sake of poor diversion man first duty be to woman who be forced to hang upon ' 'oh john not that horrible word ' cried annie to great surprise serious interruption john word that ' burst forth cry terribly 'what word lizzie what doe wench mean ' asked in saddest vexation seeing good to ask annie at for carried on most dreadfully know stupid lout ' said lizzie completing wonderment by scorn of quicker intelligence know axe about with be forced to be content for lizzie took annie in such manner on purpose to vex a must see with head drooping down hair coming over tear sob rising falling to boot without order reason that seeing good for man to do since of be lorna even really can not help thinking for at least minute that woman be mistake for ever hence be for ever mistaken nevertheless must not see that of great thought idea applied at to lorna that be different being not woman enough to do anything bad yet enough of woman for man to adore now thing came to pas tested adoration pretty sharply inasmuch a must far liefer faced carver doone father nay even therefore with great misgiving of ill thought of darling sent watch home followed gwenny who led along very rapidly with short broad form gliding down hollow from have first appeared here at bottom like trunk of wood at little distance opened without key by stooping down pressing where threshold met jamb then ran in very nimbly be forced to be bent in two even so without comfort passage be close difficult a dark a black pitch be not long be a might in there be comfort came out soon at other end be at top of doone valley in chilly dusk air looked most untempting especially during state of mind under be labouring a crossed towards captain house met couple of great doones lounging by waterside gwenny said something to although stared very hard at let pas without hindrance be not too much to say that when little maid opened sir ensor door heart thumped quite a much with terror a with hope of lorna presence in moment fear be gone for lorna be trembling in arm courage rose to comfort darling feared beyond thing else lest must be offended with for what have said to grandfather for dragging into presence told almost falsehood first last that ever did tell to wit cared not that much showed tip of thumb a said for old sir ensor wrath so long a have granddaughter love now tried to think a said so a to save from being lie somehow other did not answer be vexed with way lorna took by hand a bravely a must led into little passage where must hear river moaning branch rustling here passed a long minute a fear ever cheated time of saying to myself continually that there be nothing to be frightened at yet growing more more afraid by reason of so reasoning at last lorna came back very pale a saw by candle carried whispered 'now be patient dearest never mind what say to attempt to burning took little heed of thing in though marked that window be open that heeded be old man very stern comely with death upon countenance yet not lying in bed set upright in chair with loose red cloak thrown over upon white hair fell pallid finger lay in ghastly fashion without sign of life movement of power kept up rigid calm relentless only in great black eye fixed upon solemnly power of body dwelt life of soul be burning must not look at very nicely being afeared of death in face most afeared to show to tell truth poor blue eye fell away from blackness of a if have be coffin plate therefore made low obeisance tried not to shiver only groaned that lorna thought good manner to leave two together ' said old man voice seemed to come from cavern of skeleton that great john ridd ' ridd be name honour ' be must answer 'and hope worship be better ' have sense enough to know what have be doing ' 'yes knew right well ' answered 'that have set mine eye far above rank ' 'be ignorant that lorna doone be born of oldest family remaining in north europe ' ' be ignorant of worship yet knew of high descent from doones of bagworthy ' old man eye like fire probed whether be jesting then perceiving how grave be thinking must not laugh a many people suppose of took on to make good deficiency with very bitter smile know of own low descent from ridds of oare ' answered being a yet unaccustomed to style of speech ridds of oare have be honest men twice a long a doones have be rogue ' must not answer for john ' sir ensor replied very quietly when expected fury 'if be so thy family be very oldest in europe now hearken to boy clown honest fool thou art hearken to old man word who have not many hour to live there be nothing in world to fear nothing to revere trust nothing even to have not felt that snow wind of sheep upon mountain sheep upon western farm cattle on upper barrow scarcely one in ten be saved do what must for be not through neglect now that wit be sharpened from pure impossibility of finding at great snow never ceased moment for three day night then when earth be filled topmost hedge be unseen tree broke down with weight wherever wind have not lightened brilliant sun broke forth showed loss of custom house be quite snowed up except where have purged way by dint of constant shovellings kitchen be a dark darker than cider cellar long line of furrowed scollop ran even up to chimney stack several window fell right inwards through weight of snow against few that stood bulged in bent like old bruised lanthorn be obliged to cook by candle light be a be must have blocked country so that sky have never ceased for more than two day at time for full three week thereafter to pour fresh pile of fleecy mantle have wind relaxed single day from shaking a rule snowed day cleared up at night froze intensely with star a bright a jewel earth spread out in lustrous twilight sound in air a sharp crackling a artillery then in morning snow again before sun must come to help mattered not what way wind be often often vane went round hoped for change of weather only change be that seemed if possible to grow colder indeed after week so wind must regularly love be sensible be seeking around for then told gwenny to hold tongue whatever did among not to trust to woman word told be liar a have found out long ago only thing to believe in be honest man when fall back breast can lift more know not whether be then more blessed harrowed by for in settle be lorna propped with pillow round clear hand spread sometimes to blazing fireplace in eye knowledge be of anything around neither in neck sense of leaning towards anything only lovely hand be entreating something to spare to love line of supplication quivered in sad white face go away except mother ' said very quietly so must be obeyed everybody knew then mother came to alone said frost be in brain have heard of before john ' will have out ' be must answer 'leave to altogether only sit there watch ' for felt lorna knew other soul that if not interfered with must soon come home to therefore sat gently by leaving nature a be to own good time will presently glance watched a at distance in doubt began to flutter to brighten to deepen into kindness then to beam with trust love then with gathering tear to falter in shame to turn away small entreating hand found way a if by instinct to great projecting palm trembled there rested there for little while lingered thus neither wishing to move away neither caring to look beyond presence of other alike so full of hope comfort true happiness if only world must let be then little sob disturbed tried to make believe that be only coughing lorna guessing who be jumped up so very rashly that almost set frock on fire from great ash log away ran to old oak chair where mother be by clock case pretending to be knitting took work from mother hand laid upon head kneeling humbly looking up 'god bless fair mistress ' said mother bending nearer then a lorna gaze prevailed bless sweet child so went to mother heart by very nearest road even a have come to mine mean road of pity smoothed by grace youth gentleness chapter xlv change long needed jeremy bargain oh if be not for annie must make fortune ' sir must not sell to not for twenty time five pound grandfather be so kind about think belonged to mother ' 'there be twenty five rose diamond in found out lorna be fond of money then sighed rather heavily for of fault seems to one of worst in woman even before sigh be finished have cause to condemn for lorna took necklace very quietly from hand of squire faggus who have not half done with admiring went up to mother with sweetest smile ever saw 'dear kind mother be so glad ' said in whisper coaxing out of sight of 'now will have wo dear will be so happy for thousandth part of kindness to jewel in world can match ' can not lay before grace with did air of seeking favour rather than conferring high bred fear of giving offence be of fear noblest mother knew not what to say of course must never dream of taking such gift a yet saw how sadly lorna must be disappointed therefore mother did from habit what almost always did called to help knowing that eye be full for anything noble move so quite a rashly a thing pitiful pretended not to hear mother to see wild cat in dairy therefore can not tell what mother said in reply to lorna for when came back quite eager to let love know how worshipped how deeply be ashamed of for meanly wronging in heart behold tom faggus have gotten again necklace have such charm for be delivering around especially to annie who be wondering at learning dissertation on precious stone sentiment about in hand said that work be very ancient undoubtedly very good cutting of line be true angle be in
