came to very next day trying to look cheerful begged if loved never mind how little to take charge of again a once have done before not even to let know in what place stored told that last request must not comply with for having be round neck so often be now sacred thing more than million pound must be therefore must dwell for present in neighbourhood of heart so must not be far from at smiled tom be thoroughly upright man according to own standard might rely upon always up to certain point mean to be there thereabouts sometimes thing be too many for tom especially with ardent spirit then judged perhaps too much with only for jury at rate must trust fully for candour for honesty in almost case in must have interest so got on very well together thought fool tried best not to think anything worse of scarcely be tom clean out of sight annie tear not dry yet for always made point of cry upon departure when in came master jeremy stickles splashed with mud from head to foot not in very best of humour though happy to get back again 'curse fellow cried with stamp sent water hissing from boot upon ember pretty plight may call for majesty commissioner to return to headquarters in annie dear ' for be always very affable with annie 'will help off with overall then turn pretty hand to gridiron not blessed morsel have touched for more than twenty four hour beurely then must be quite starving sir ' sister replied with greatest zeal for did love man with appetite glad be that fire be clear ' lizzie who happened to be there said with peculiar smile stickles must be used to for never come back without telling that ' 'hush cried annie quite shocked with 'how must like to be used to now betty be quick with thing for pork mutton deer meat sir have cured since autumn 'oh deer meat by mean jeremy stickles answered have tasted none since left though dreaming of often well be better than being chased over moor for one life john way from landacre bridge have ridden race for precious life at peril of limb neck three great doones galloping after good job for that be so big must have overtaken just go see to horse john be excellent lad deserves good turn day from will render to ' however left to do while made comfortable in truth horse required care be blown so that must hardly stand plastered with mud steaming so that stable be quite full with by time have put poor fellow to right master have finished dinner be in more pleasant humour having even offered to kiss annie out of pure gratitude a said annie answered with spirit gratitude must not be shown by increasing obligation jeremy made reply to that only way to be grateful then be to tell story so did at greater length than can here repeat for doe not bear particularly upon lorna fortune appears that a be riding towards from town of southmolton in devonshire found road very soft heavy flood out in direction met with other difficulty until came to landacre bridge have only single trooper with man not of militia of king army whom jeremy have brought from exeter a two descended towards bridge observed that kensford water river barle be pouring down in mighty flood from melting of snow so great indeed be torrent after united that only parapet of bridge must be seen above water road across bank being covered very deep on hither side trooper did not like look of proposed to ride back again round by way of simonsbath where stream be smaller stickles must not have so dashing into river swam horse for bridge gained with little trouble there found water not more than up to horse knee perhaps on crown of bridge turned horse to watch trooper passage to help with direction when suddenly saw fall headlong into torrent heard report of gun from behind felt shock to own body such a lifted out of saddle turning round beheld three men risen up from behind hedge on one side of onward road two of ready to load again one with gun unfired waiting to get good aim at then jeremy did gallant thing for doubt whether must have have presence of mind in danger saw that to swim horse back again must be almost certain death a affording target where even wound must be fatal therefore struck spur into nag rode through water straight at man who be pointing long gun at if horse have be carried off leg there must have be end of jeremy for other men be getting ready to have shot at luckily horse galloped right on without need for swimming being excited doubt by have seen heard of jeremy lay almost flat on neck so a to give little space for good aim with mane tossing wildly in front of now if young fellow with gun have brain a ready a flint be must have shot horse at once then have stickles at mercy instead of that let fly at man missed altogether being scared perhaps by pistol jeremy showed mouth of galloping by at full speed master stickles tried to leave mark behind for changed aim of pistol to biggest man who be loading gun cursing like ten cannon pistol missed fire doubt from flood have gurgled in over holster jeremy seeing three horse tethered at gate just up hill knew that have not yet escaped have more of danger behind tried other great pistol at one of horse tethered there so a to lessen if possible number of pursuer powder again failed durst not stop to cut bridle bearing men coming up hill so even made most of start thanking god that weight be light compared at least to what theirs be thing have noticed gave hope of escaping to wit that horse of doones although very handsome animal be suffering still from bitter effect of late long frost water trooper horse on other side shaking drenched flank neighing half way down hill saw three doones mounting hastily then knew that only chance lay in stoutness of steed horse be in pretty good good hard gallop heading away towards withycombe at first have thought of turning to right making off for withypool mile so down valley good sense told that one there must dare to protect against doones so resolved to go on way yet faster than have intended three villain came after with speed must muster making sure from badness of road that must stick fast ere long so be at mercy be jeremy chiefest fear for ground being soft thoroughly rotten after so much frost snow poor horse have terrible work of with time to pick way even more good luck than skill be needed to keep from foundering how jeremy prayed for exmoor fog such a have often sworn at might turn aside while pursuer went past fog came even storm to damp priming of gun be wood coppice nigh place to hide in only hill moor upon exmoor horse have broken through crust of moss sedge marishweed must hing wallow sink with black water spirting over jeremy struggling with might saw three villain now topping crest le than call upon courage reared forefoot out of slough with straining eyeball gazed at 'now ' said jeremy fine fellow ' lifting with bridle brave beast gathered roll of loin sprang from quagmired haunch one a to prove that own way be best neither be worst of for jeremy made doubt what if must only get militia to turn out in force might manage with help of own men to force stronghold of enemy truth be that officer knowing how hard must be to collect men at time of year in state of weather began with one accord to make possible excuse especially pressed point that bagworthy be not in county devonshire people affirming vehemently that lay in shire of somerset somersetshire folk averring even with imprecation that lay in devonshire now believe truth to be that boundary of two county a well a of oare brendon parish be defined by bagworthy river so that disputant on side be right wrong upon master stickles suggested a thought very sensibly that two county must unite equally contribute to extirpation of pest shamed injured alike hence arose difficulty for men of devon said must march when somerset have taken field son of somerset replied that indeed be quite ready what be cousin of devonshire doing so came to pas that king commissioner returned without army with promise of two hundred men when road must be more passable meanwhile what be to do abandoned a be to mercy of doones bent heard bone of arm break a clearly a ever heard twig snap with roar of pain fell on ground torch dropped there singed other man stood amazed at not having yet gained sight of till caught firebrand advance challenge carver doone to meet bore in mind that must be apt to shoot without ceremony what be utmost of human strength against power of powder moreover remembered promise to sweet lorna who must be left to defend if rogue got rid of while be hesitating thus for always continue to hesitate except in actual conflict blaze of fire lit up house brown smoke hung around six of men have let go at doones by jeremy stickles order a villain came swaggering down in moonlight ready for rape murder two of fell rest hung back to think at leisure what be be not used to sort of thing be neither just courteous being unable longer to contain a thought of lorna excitement at noise of firing came across yard expecting whether must shoot at however one shot at went up to carver doone whom knew by size in moonlight took by beard said 'do call man ' for moment be so astonished that must not answer none have ever dared suppose to look at in way saw that have met equal perhaps master then tried pistol at be too quick for 'now carver doone take warning ' said to very soberly 'you have shown fool by contempt of may not be match in craft be in manhood be despicable villain lie low in native muck with word laid flat upon back in straw yard by trick of inner heel must not have resisted though strength have be twice a great a mine unless be wrestler seeing down others ran though one of made shot at of got horse before men came up went away without among last be captain carver who arose while be feeling for have little wound strode away with train of curse enough to poison light of moon gained six very good horse by attempted rapine a well a two young prisoner whom have smitten by clover rick two dead doones be left behind whom a buried in churchyard without service over for part be most thankful have not killed for to have life of fellow man laid upon one conscience deserved death deserved not be to sense of right wrong heaviest of burden one wear most deeply inwards with dwelling of mind on view on of be inclined to pursue enemy try to capture more of jeremy stickles must not allow for said that advantage must be upon side if went hurrying after with only moon to guide who must tell what there might be band of ready to fall upon house burn seize woman if left unprotected when put case thus be glad enough to abide by decision one thing be quite certain that doones have never before received so rude shock so violent blow to supremacy since first have built up power become lord of exmoor knew carver doone must gnash mighty teeth of curse men around for blunder be in truth own of over confidence carelessness at same time rest must feel that thing have never happened while old sir ensor be alive that be caused by nothing short of gross mismanagement scarcely know who made greatest fuss about little wound mother annie lorna be heartily ashamed to be so treated like milksop most unluckily have be impossible to hide for ball have cut along temple just above eyebrow being fired so near at hand powder too have scarred therefore seemed great deal worse than really be sponging plastering sobbing moaning made quite ashamed to look master stickles in face however at last persuaded have intention of giving up ghost night then fell to thanked god with emphasis quite unknown in church hereupon master stickles said in free easy manner for one courted observation be luckiest of mortal in having mother sister sweetheart to make much of for part said be just a well off in not having to care for for now might go get shot stabbed knocked on head at pleasure without one being offended made bold upon to ask be become of wife for have heard speak of having one said that knew cared perhaps must be like day that lorna must hear such sentiment be very grievous to looked at with smile proved contempt for such idea lest anything still more unfit might be said dismissed question master stickles told afterwards when there be one with to have faith in woman might seem to be for assured that now possessed very large experience for so small matter being thoroughly acquainted with woman of class from lady of highest blood to bonarobas peasant wife that might be divided into three head more be to say a follows first very hot passionate who be only contemptible second cold indifferent who be simply odious third mixture of other two who have bad quality of a for reason none of have be like sealed book to if ever tried to open began at back of cover now did not like to hear such thing to appeared to be insolent a well a narrow minded for if came to why might not men a well a woman be divided into same three class be pronounced upon by woman a being even more devoid than gentle judge of reason moreover knew from own sense from greatest of great poet that there be always have be plenty of woman good gentle warm hearted loving lovable very keen moreover at seeing right be by reason otherwise upon whole prefer much to people of own sex a goodness of heart be more important than to show good reason for having so said to jeremy 'you have be ill treated perhaps master stickles by woman other ' have ' replied with oath 'and last on earth who must serve so woman who be wife woman whom never struck never wronged in way never even let know that like better yet when be at berwick last with regiment on guard there against vile moss trooper what doe woman do fly in face of authority of especial business by running away with biggest of moss trooper not that cared groat about wish fool well rid of insolence of thing be such that everybody laughed at back went to london losing far better safer job than through come let have onion master stickles view of matter be so entirely unromantic that scarcely wondered at mistress stickles for having run away from to adventurous moss trooper for nine woman out of ten must have kind of romance other to make life endurable when love have lost attractive element soft dew fog if such be love be apt to languish unless bloom be well replaced by budding hope of child now master stickles have wished to have child without waiting for warrant only saying something about 'captus in flagrante delicto if be way to spell stickles sent prisoner off bound looking miserable to jail at taunton be desirous to let go free if must promise amendment although have taken surely therefore have right to let go again master stickles said 'not so assured that be matter of public polity of course not knowing what meant must not contradict thought that surely private right ought to be respected for if throw man in wrestling expect to get stake if take man prisoner why ought in common justice to belong to have good right to let go if think proper to do so however master stickles said that be quite benighted knew nothing of constitution be very thing knew beyond man in parish nevertheless be not for to contradict commissioner therefore let prisoner go wished happy deliverance stickles replied with merry grin that if ever got must be jail deliverance bliss of dancing laid hand to throat in manner seemed to most uncourteous however foresight proved too correct for poor fellow be executed soon after next assize lorna have done very best to earn chance for even going down on knee to common jeremy pleading with great tear for however although much moved by vowed that durst hing else to set free be more than own life be worth for country knew by time two captive doones be roped to cider press at plover barrow annie bound broken arm of one whom have knocked down with club supported then washed rubbed with lard face of other poor fellow torch have injured fetched back collar bone to best of ability for before surgeon must arrive be off with well armed escort day be reinforced so strongly from enemy in thick of flood confusion several of others thought so too did not like fighting in water therefore be resolved to wait keep watch upon valley let flood go down again chapter l merry meeting always endeavour to be without becoming obscure two young people ah what gift be youth one can never be too thankful for will have rare advantage of commencing married life with subject of common interest to discus whenever weary of well say of one if can now by mean conceive possibility perfect justice meted out mutual goodwill resulting from sense of reciprocity understand sir why can not say what mean at once bey dear child prolong suspense curiosity be most powerful of feminine instinct therefore most delightful when not prematurely satisfied however if must have strong reality here be father slew dear john father dear john father slew yours having said thus much counsellor leaned back upon chair shaded calm white bearded eye from ray of tallow candle be man who liked to look dear answered dearly love what possibility must ever make give up dear upon that there be more forbearing kissed clasped whether be countess whether queen of england mine be at least in heart mine must be wholly being of same opinion nothing be said between 'now lorna ' said a hung on arm willing to trust anywhere 'come to little plant house hear moving story ' 'no story can move much dear wondered why did not say a much of father 'yes can bear anything although can not see have long forgotten must not bear to hear ill of 'there be ill to hear sweet child except of evil done to lorna be of ill starred race ' 'better that than wicked race answered with usual quickness leaping at conclusion 'tell be not doone will can not love more ' 'you be not doone lorna for at least can answer though know not what name be father father what mean be 'your father mine never met one father be killed by accident in pyrenean mountain mother by doones at least caused death carried away from coming a in one breath upon sensitive maiden be more than must bear at once a fool like must of course have known lay back on garden bench with black hair shed on oaken bark while colour went came only by quivering breath must one say that lived thought yet pressed hand with hers might tell of chapter lvi john becomes too popular flower have ever seen either in shifting of light shade in pearly morning may vie with fair young woman face when tender thought quick emotion vary enrich beautify thus lorna hearkened softly almost without word gesture yet with sigh glance telling pressure of hand how word be moving when at last tale be done turned away wept bitterly for sad fate of parent to surprise spoke not even word of wrath rancour seemed to take a fate 'lorna darling ' said at length for men be more impatient in trial of time than woman be 'do not even wish to know what proper name be 'how can matter to john ' answered with depth of grief made seem trifler can never matter now when there be none to share ' 'poor little soul ' be said in tone of purest pity to surprise turned upon caught in arm loved a have never done before 'dearest have ' cried only love having want other life be one with yours oh john how can treat so ' blushing through wet of weeping gloom of pondering must not hide eye folded dwelled on ' can not believe ' in pride of joy whispered into one little ear 'that must ever so love beauty a to give up world for ' 'must give up farm for john ' cried lorna leaping back looking with wondrous power of light at 'must give up mother sister home that have in world hope of life john ' 'of course must without two thought know know lorna 'it be true do behe answered in tone of deepest sadness 'and be power of love have made love so no good can come of good god face be set against selfishness a spoke in low tone gazed at clear line of face where curve be perfect not with love wonder only with strange new sense of awe 'darling ' said 'come nearer to give surety against for god sake never frighten with thought that must part ' 'does then so frighten ' whispered coming close to ' know dear have known long never frightens make sad very lonely till can remember 'till can remember what ' asked with long deep shudder for be so superstitious 'until do remember love that will soon come back to be own for ever be what always think of be what hope for ' although eye be so glorious beaming with eternity distant sort of beatitude be not much to liking wanted to have love on earth dear wife in own home child in good time if god must please to send then must be to exactly what father be to beside doubted much about being fit for heaven where plough be cattle unless sacrificed bull went thither therefore said 'now kiss lorna talk nonsense darling came so loving warm hearted that never said word stared thought 'how doe mean ' saw pain upon forehead wonder in eye leaving coach palace too back flew to in moment a simple a simplest milkmaid 'oh fearful from with utmost care namely that sergeant bloxham have taken upon to send direct to london by chancery officer full report of what have happened of illness of chief together with urgent prayer for full battalion of king troop plenary commander sergeant bloxham being senior of surviving soldier very worthy man in way trifle over zealous have succeeded to captaincy upon master disablement then with desire to serve country show education sat up most part of three night wrote very wonderful report by aid of stable lanthorn be very fine piece of work a three men to whom read only one at time pronounced being under seal of secrecy might have gone well with if author must only have held tongue when near ear of woman be beyond sense a seems although so good writer for having heard that lizzie be famous judge of literature a indeed told almost one must not contain must have opinion upon work lizzie sat on log of wood listened with ear up having made proviso that one else must be be so elegant yet so fervent that sergeant broke pipe in three fell in love with on spot now have led out of way a thing be always doing partly through own perverseness partly through kind desire to such pitch jeremy almost forgave became much milder after fever inflammation of wound diminished very rapidly however not knowing what might happen even how soon poor lorna might be taken from power falling into lawyer hand have cause to wish most heartily back among robber set forth one day for watchett taking advantage of visit of trooper from outpost who must make house quite safe rode alone being fully primed having misgiving for be said that even doones have begun to fear since cast culverin through door a above related must not believe from being still untouched although so large object in thickest of fire of gun cannon must bear charmed life proof against ball bullet however knew that carver doone be not likely man to hold superstitious opinion of have instinctive dread feeding licking up food happily snuffling over yet sparing time to be grateful showing taste perception other be to go gardening boldly in spring of year without misgiving about hoping utmost of least of offence to made reply a behoves man dealing with cross fractious people presently became better tempered sent little ruth for bottle of wine gave beautiful smile of thanks for forbearance a uncle ben despised farmer case have at least resolved to let know secret for two good reason first be that wear out to dwell upon alone second be can trust to fulfil promise moreover be next of kin except among womankind be just man want to help in enterprise ' 'and will help sir ' answered fearing conspiracy 'in anything be true loyal according to law of realm have ' cried old man laughing until eye ran over spreading out skinny hand upon shining breech hast gone same fool track a rest even a spy stickles went precious trooper landing of arm at glenthorne lynmouth wagon escorted across getting rid of water man might stop think might go on think in case there be none to say that be making fool of when came to foot of ravine over against great black slough there be sign of master huckaback of other living man except in silence therefore sat in niche of rock gazing at slough pondering old tradition about say that in ancient time mighty necromancer lived in wilderness of exmoor here by spell incantation built strong high palace eight sided like spider web standing on central steep so that man beast must cross moor without knowledge if wished to rob slay traveller to have wild ox stag for food have nothing more to do than sit at one of eight window point unholy book at moving creature at book be pointed must obey call come from distance if sighted once by wizard be bad condition of thing country groaned under exmoor although most honest place that man must wish to live in be beginning to get bad reputation through vile wizard man durst even go to steal sheep pony so much a deer for dinner lest must be brought to book by far bigger rogue than be went on for many year though prayed to god to abate at last when wizard be getting fat haughty upon high stomach mighty deliverance came to exmoor warning memory for one day sorcerer gazed from window facing southeast of compass yawned having killed so many men now be weary of 'ifackins ' cried such oath profane kept drunk for three day three night assuring whenever have gleam enough to ask for that daughter be a well a must be enjoying with child not wishing maid to see tipsy pressed matter further applied to bottle again drank health with pleasure however after three day of constitution rose against became quite sober with certain lowness of heart moreover sense of error first desire to right easiest with from day to death never touched strong drink again only being soon appointed captain of mine allowed man on pretext to bring cordial thither to stern hard rule stealthy secret management a much a to good luck place might be attributed that scarcely have dreamed about exmoor mine a for have ambition to become miner state to gold seeking have brought poor uncle ben be not at encouraging business be to till ground tend growth came of store fruit in heaven good time rather than to scoop burrow like weasel rat for yellow root of evil moreover be led from home between hay corn harvest when often have week to spare by call there be resisting unless gave up regard for wrestling for county now here many person may take amiss there always have be confusion people who ought to have known better have wrought into subject of quarrelling by birth be true can not be denied that be man of somerset nevertheless by breed be a well a by education son of devon also just a of two county vowed that glen doone be none of theirs belonged to other one so now with hot claim jangling leading even to blow sometimes asserted must swear to a became more famous that john ridd be of own producing bred of own true blood basely stolen by other now have not judged in way needful even becoming delicate to enter into wrestling adventure describe progress whole thing be so different from lorna gentle manner style of walking moreover must seem even to kind people to magnify so much at least attempt to do have scratched out written page through better taste sense neither will upon head make difference even now being simply betrayed into mentioning matter because bare truth requires in tale of lorna fortune for mighty giant have arisen in part of cornwall calf be twenty five inch round breadth of shoulder two foot quarter stature seven foot three quarter round chest be seventy inch hand foot across there be scale strong enough to judge of weight in market place now man must say backer boaster for giant be modest sent brave haughty challenge to meet in ring at bodmin town on first day of august else to return champion belt to by messenger be use to deny be greatly dashed scared at first for part be only when measured without clothes on sixty inch round breast round calf scarce twenty one only two foot across shoulder in height not six three quarter however mother must never believe that man must beat lorna being of same mind resolved to go try a must pay expense hundred pound if conquered so confident be cornishman now story be too well known for to go through again again child in devonshire know grandson will know song clever man made of after have treated to water to lemon little sugar drop of eau de vie enough have found giant quite a big a have described enough to terrify one trusting in practice study of art resolved to try back with when arm be round once giant be farthingale put into vice of blacksmith man have bone frame sank in be afraid of crushing lay on back might a well have be sent for match with hay mow however got hundred pound made up mind to spend farthing in present for mother lorna for annie be married by time long before went away a need scarcely be said perhaps if one follows week month wedding be quiet enough except for everybody good wish desire not to dwell upon because grieved in many way now have tried to hope very best for dear annie deeper blow than must have come even through awaited for after visit to cornwall with prize money about came on foot from okehampton to oare so a to save little sum towards time of marrying for lorna fortune must not have small great must not have only if there be denying must devote whole of to charitable us a master peter blundell have done perhaps future age must endeavour to be grateful lorna have settled question at least twice day on average time with more satisfaction now coming into kitchen with cash in breech pocket golden guinea with elephant on for stamp of guinea company found dear mother most heartily glad to see safe sound again for have dreaded that giant dreamed of never asked about money lizzie also be softer more gracious than usual especially when saw pour guinea like peppercorn into pudding basin by way hung about knew that something be gone wrong 'where be lorna ' asked at length after trying not to ask ' want to come see money never saw so much before 'alas said mother with heavy sigh will see great deal more fear deal more than be good for whether ever see again will depend upon nature john ' do mean have quarrelled why doe not lorna come to be never to know ' 'now john be not so impatient mother replied quite calmly for in truth be jealous of lorna 'you must wait now very well john if be till day week for coming of mother john yet mother be best friend who can ever fill place ' thinking of future absence mother turned away cried box iron singed blanket 'now said being wild by time have little sense will tell where be lorna ' lady lorna dugal ' said lizzie screwing up lip a if title be too grand 'be gone to london brother john not likely to come back again must try to get on without little something ' cried dare not write down here a be too good for such language lizzie lip provoked so bey lorna gone lorna gone without good bye to even be spite have sickened 'you be quite mistaken there ' replied can folk of low degree have spite liking towards people so far above lady lorna dugal be gone because must not help wept enough to break ten heart if heart be ever broken john ' 'darling lizzie how good be ' cried without noticing sneer 'tell about dear tell word said ' 'that will not take long said lizzie quite a unmoved by soft coaxing a by urgent cursing 'the lady spoke very little to one indeed to mother to gwenny carfax gwenny now to atone for seems by living in court of law under special surveillance a call believe of majesty court of chancery uncle be appointed guardian master must live beneath care until be twenty one year old to appears dreadful thing very unjust cruel for why must lose freedom through heritage of land gold offered to abandon if must only let go went down on knee to said wanted title not land rest must drag drop hand idle being quicker to take infection of dullness than of diligence harvest be heavy one even heavier than year before although of poorer quality therefore be forced to work a hard a horse must during daylight hour defer till night brooding upon misfortune darkness always found stiff with work weary le able to think than to dream may be of lorna now house be so dull perhaps from own way of thinking partly from reading of history for while from one point of view looked up at very demurely a commissioned by god for country good from sight disliked a ready to of annie knew that gift of cooking be not vouchsafed by god to sometimes must do best by intellect to win whereas be more to be won by intellect than be divine poetry amount of strong quick heart be needful understanding must second in one art a in other now fare be very choice for next three day more yet not turned out like annie must do thing well enough on fire must not put on table so even say 'no pleasing ' lizzie must jerk up one shoulder cry 'he have better have lorna to cook for ' while whole truth be that wanted not to be plagued about cookery just to have something good quiet then smoke think about lorna nevertheless time went on with one change gathered harvest in parson bowden thanked god for in church out of for tithe must be very goodly unmatched cold of previous winter general fear of scarcity own talk about ruin have sent price up to grand high pitch did best to keep there for nine englishman out of ten believe that bitter winter must breed sour summer explain away topmost price while according to experience more often must be otherwise except for public thinking so however have said too much if farmer read book will vow that wrote for nothing else except to rob family chapter lxii king must not be prayed for neighbourhood be surprised that doones have not ere now attacked probably made end of for lay almost at mercy now having only sergeant bloxham three men to protect captain stickles having be ordered southward with force except such a might be needful for collecting toll watching import at lynmouth thence to porlock sergeant having now imbibed taste for writing report though first great effort have done good only offended stickles reported weekly from plover barrow whenever must find messenger though fed not sergeant bloxham at own table with best have a in case of stickles who represented majesty yet treated so well that reported very highly of a loyal true hearted liege most devoted to lord king indeed must scarcely have done le when lizzie wrote great part of report furbished up rest to pitch of lustre that lord clarendon need scarce have be ashamed of though cost great deal of ale even of strong water for lizzie must have duty of critic to stand treat to author though be otherwise plague a giving maid such air of patronage such pretence to politics yet there be stopping without risk of mortal offence to writer reviewer mother also while disapproving lizzie long stay in saddle room on friday night saturday insisting that betty must be there be nevertheless a proud a need be that king must read eliza ' s writing at least so innocent soul believed looked forward to something great a fruit of history something great did come of though not a expected for report a many of a be ever opened stood in good stead next year when be accused of harbouring comforting guilty rebel now reason why doones did not attack be that be preparing to meet more powerful assault upon fortress being assured that repulse of king troop must not be looked over when brought before authority doubt be right for although conflict in government during summer autumn have delayed matter yet positive order have be issued that outlaw malefactor must at price be brought to justice when sudden death of king charles second threw thing into confusion mind into panic heard of first in church on sunday eighth day of february from cousin of john fry who have ridden over on purpose from porlock came in just before anthem splashed heated from ride so that one turned looked at wanted to create stir knowing how much must be made of took best way to do for let anthem go by very quietly rather must say very pleasingly for choir be exceeding proud of sang bass twice a loud a bull to beat clerk with clarionet then just a parson bowden with look of pride at minstrel be kneeling down to begin prayer for king most excellent majesty for never read litany except upon easter sunday up jump young sam fry shout forbid that there prai er ' 'what ' cried parson rising slowly looking for one to shut door 'have rebel in congregation for parson be growing short sighted now knew not sam fry at distance 'no ' replied sam not whit abashed by staring of parish rebel parson man who mislaiketh popery murder that there prai er be prai er for dead cried parson now recognising knowing to be john first cousin mean to say sam that gracious majesty be dead ' 'dead a sto un poisoned by papishers sam rubbed hand with enjoyment at effect have produced bemember where be sam ' said parson bowden solemnly 'when did most sad thing happen king be head of church sam fry when did leave 'day afore yesterday twelve o'clock war quick to hear of 'un 'ca be ' said minister tidings can never have come so soon anyhow will want more let pray for gracious majesty with proceeded a usual nobody cried 'amen for fear of being entangled with popery after giving forth text parson said few word out of book about many virtue of majesty denial devotion comparing pious mirth to dancing of patriarch david before ark of covenant added with severity that if flock must not join pastor who be much more likely to judge aright in praying for king least must do on returning home be to pray that king might not be dead a enemy have asserted now when service be over killed king brought to life at least fifty time in churchyard sam fry be mounted on high gravestone to tell one knew of knew more than have told in church a before repeated upon be much disappointed with inclined to disbelieve until happily remembered that majesty have died in great pain with blue spot on breast black spot across back in form of cross by reason of papist having poisoned when sam called to remembrance to imagination be overwhelmed at once with so many invitation to dinner that scarce knew of to accept decided in favour grieving much for loss of king however greatly might be a parson have declared be while telling to pray against for royal benefit resolved to ride to porlock directly after dinner make sure whether be dead not for be not by mean hard to suppose that sam fry being john first cousin might have inherited either from grandfather of gift have made john so famous for mendacity at porlock found that be too true woman of town be in great distress for king have always be popular with men on other hand be forecasting what must be likely to ensue be of number riding sadly home again although bound to king a churchwarden now dignity next to parson in rank be with a ought to be in good parish hereditary for who can stick to church like man whose father stuck to before who know little in great out must in troublous time come across though appointed at last by virtue of being best farmer in parish a well a by vice of mismanagement on part of mother nicholas snowe who have thoroughly muxed up everything being too quick headed yet while dwelled with pride upon fact that stood in king shoe a manager promoter of church of england knew that must miss majesty whose arm be above commandment a leader of thought in church handsome upon guinea nevertheless kept on thinking how death must act on here saw many way in first place trouble must break out have eight twenty rick counting grain straw hay moreover mother be growing weak about riot shooting burning gathered bed clothes around ear night when foot be tucked up prayed not to awake until morning in next place much rebellion though must not own in sense of verb to 'own ' be whispering plucking skirt making sign among terror of doones helped greatly a fruitful tree of lawlessness good excuse for everybody after rather before first of indeed if must state true order arose upon thought of lorna how thing must affect fate indeed must admit that have occurred to sometimes be happiness must not think of difference between world of to day world of day twelvemonth then be howling desolation earth blocked up with snow air with barb of ice a small a splintered needle yet spread across shading with silent fold colour stole away remembrance waned died beo have be with love ' thought with simple truth warmth maid have chosen glittering star instead of plain daylight that 'popish army a called be to be attacked very night with god assistance beaten however by time have be taught to pay little attention to rumour having sought vainly for tom faggus among poor rustic warrior took to hostel went to bed being a weary a weary can be falling asleep immediately took heed of nothing although town be alive light have come glancing a lay down shout making echo round room did be to bolt door not inch must budge unless house even bed be on fire so for several hour lay in depth of deepest slumber without even dream on surface until be roused awakened at last by pushing pulling pinching plucking of hair out by root at length being able to open mine eye saw old landlady with candle heavily wondering at 'ca let alone ' grumbled have paid for bed mistress wo get up for one ' 'must to god young man answered shaking a hard a ever 'that popish soldier may sleep night only half a strong a thou dost fie on thee fie on thee get up go fight can hear battle who be snoring set out to see worst of sleepy hostler scratched poll must not tell way to take what odds to who be king pope so long a paid way got bit of bacon on sunday must please to remember have quality must pay half quality price so gave double fee a became good farmer be glad to be quit of kickums a saw by turn of eye while going out at archway be done by lanthorn light although moon be high bold in northern heaven flag ribbon of jostling pattern such a often have in autumn in july very rarely of master dryden have spoken somewhere in courtly manner of think so little because by fashion preferred to shakespeare can not remember passage be credit to therefore be guided mainly by sound of gun trumpet in riding out of narrow way into open marsh thus might have found road in spite of spread of water glaze of moonshine that a followed sound far from hedge causeway fog like chestnut tree in blossom touched with moonlight met now fog be thing understand can do with well enough where know country here have never be before be nothing to exmoor fog not to be compared with time one must see moon can not do in fog even sun for week together yet gleam of water always make fog more difficult like curtain on mirror none can tell boundary here have broad water patch in out inlaid on land like mother of pearl in brown shittim wood to wild duck born bred there must almost be puzzle to find own nest amongst what chance then have kickums unused to marsh mere time when thought that must be right now at last by track passage approaching conflict with sound of waxing nearer suddenly break of water must be laid before with moon looking mildly over northern light behind dancing down line of fog be awful thing say to day remember to hear sound of raging fight yell of raving slayer howl of poor men stricken hard shattered from wrath to wailing then suddenly dead low hush a of soul departing spirit kneeling over through vapour of earth white breath of water beneath pale round moon bowing a drift went by rush pause of fear passed lingered on path at last when almost despaired of escaping from tangle of spongy bank of hazy creek reed fringe horse heard neigh of fellow horse be only too glad to answer upon other having lost rider came up pricked ear at gazed through fog very steadfastly therefore encouraged with soft genial whistle kickums did best to tempt with snort of inquiry however nothing must suit that nag except to enjoy new freedom capered away with tail set on high stirrup iron clashing under therefore a might know way appeared to have be in battle followed very carefully led to little hamlet called a found afterwards west zuyland zealand so named perhaps from situation amid inland sea here king troop have be quite lately fire be still burning men have be summoned away by night attack of rebel hence procured for guide young man who knew district thoroughly who led by many intricate way to rear of rebel army came upon broad open moor striped with sullen water course shagged with sedge yellow iris in drier part with bilberry for by time be four o'clock summer sun rising wanly showed ghastly scene must have never be there often in lonely hour even now haunt must far more that piteous thing have never be done in england flying men flung back from dream of victory honour only glad to have luck of life limb to fly with mud bedraggled foul with slime reeking with sweat blood must not stop to wipe cursing with pumped out lung stick hindered gory puddle slipped step scarcely able to leap over corse have dragged to die to see how corse lay a fair a death in sleep with smile of placid valour of noble manhood hovering yet on silent lip have bloodless hand put upwards white a wax firm a death clasped a on monument in prayer for dear one left behind in high thanksgiving of men there be nothing in broad blue eye to fear others be of different sort simple fellow unused to pain accustomed to bill hook perhaps rasp of knuckle in quick set hedge making to do at breakfast over thumb cut in sharpening scythe expecting wife to make more to do yet here lay poor chap dead dead after deal of pain with little mind to bear soul have never thought of gone god alone know whither to mercy may trust upon thing can not dwell none trow must ask only if plain man saw what saw morning if god have blessed with heart be in most of must have sickened of desire to be great among mankind seeing riding to front where work of death went on among men of true english pluck when moved farther move fugitive called out to in dozen dialect to make utter fool of myself for great gun be come fight be over rest be slaughter 'arl oop wi moonmo '' shouted one big fellow miner of mendip hill whose weapon be pickaxe oose to vaight na moor wend thee hame yoong mon agin ' upon stopped horse desiring not to be shot for nothing eager to aid poor sick people who tried to lift arm to did to best of power though void of skill in business more inclined to weep with than to check weeping while be giving drop of cordial from flask to one poor fellow who sat up while life be ebbing with slow insistence urged when broken voice must come to tell wife whose name knew not something about apple tree golden guinea stored in to divide among six child in midst of felt warm lip laid against cheek quite softly then little push behold be horse leaning over arose in haste there stood winnie looking at with beseeching eye enough to melt heart of stone then seeing attention fixed turned head glanced back sadly toward place of battle gave little wistful neigh then looked full in face again a much a to say 'do understand ' while scraped with one hoof impatiently if ever horse tried hard to speak be winnie at moment went to side patted be not what wanted then offered to leap into empty saddle did that seem good to for ran away toward part of field at have be glancing back then turned round shook mane entreating to follow upon learned from dying man where to find apple tree promised to add guinea to one in store for child so commending to god mounted own horse again to winnie great delight professed at service with ringing silvery neigh such a other horse of ever knew must equal at once proclaimed triumph told master meant to tell if death must not have closed ear that be coming to aid bringing one who might be trusted of higher race kill cannon bullet fired low ploughing marsh slowly met poor winnie front to front being a quick a thought lowered nose to sniff at might be message from master for made mournful noise luckily for winnie life rise of wet ground took ball even under very nose there cut splashy groove missing off hindfoot by inch scattering black mud over frightened much more than winnie of be quite certain because though be firm enough when come to real tussle heart of fellow warms up tell that must go through with yet never did approve of making cold pie of death therefore with reckless cannon brazen mouthed bellowing two furlong off might be more more merrier must have given that year hay crop for bit of hill thicket of oak almost even badger earth people will call coward for especially when have made up mind that life be not worth having without sign of lorna nevertheless can not help be feeling set down because made mark on at glen doone have fought even against cannon with spirit fury now saw nothing to fight about rather in poor doubled corpse good reason for not fighting so in cold blood riding on yet ashamed that man must shrink where horse went bravely cast bitter blame upon reckless way of winnie nearly be scattered now of noble countryman armed with scythe pickaxe blacksmith hammer fold pitcher who have stood ground for hour against blazing musketry from men whom must not get at by reason of water dyke then against deadly cannon dragged by bishop horse to slaughter own sheep of sturdy englishman noble in want of sense scarce one out of four remained for coward to shoot down 'cross rhaine shouted out 'cross rhaine coom within rache ' other mongrel briton with mongrel at head found pleasanter to shoot men who must not shoot in answer than to meet chance of mischief from strong arm stronger heart last scene of piteous play be acting just a rode up broad daylight upstanding sun winnowing fog from eastern hill spreading moor with freshness all along dyke shone glistened on willow trunk touched bank with hoary gray ala bank be touched more deeply with gory red strewn with fallen trunk more woeful than wreck of tree while howling cursing yelling loathsome reek of carnage drowned scent of new mown hay carol of lark then cavalry of king with horse at full speed dashed from side upon helpless mob of countryman few pike feebly levelled met shot pikemen drew sword helter skelter leaped into shattered scattering mass right left hacked hewed must hear snapping of scythe beneath see flash of sweeping sword how must end be plain enough even to one like who have never beheld battle before winnie led away to left a must not help people stop slaughter found cannon bullet coming very rudely nigh be only too glad to follow chapter lxv falling among lamb faithful creature whom began to admire a if be own be little thing for man to say of man horse stopped in front of low black shed such a call 'linhay here uttered little greeting in subdued softened voice hoping to obtain answer such a master be wont to give in cheery manner receiving reply entered who must scarce keep up with poor kickums being weary leaped from back followed there found sniffing gently with great emotion at body of tom faggus corpse poor tom appeared to be if ever there be one in world turned away felt unable to keep altogether from weeping mare must not understand else must not believe reached long neck forth felt with under lip passing over skin a softly a mother must do to infant then looked up at again a much a to say be all right ' upon took courage handled poor tom being young have feared at first to do groaned very feebly a raised up there be wound great savage one whether from pike thrust musket ball gaping welling in right side from piece seemed to be torn away bound up with of linen so far a knew how just to stanch flow of blood until must get doctor then gave little weak brandy water drank with greatest eagerness made sign to for more of not knowing how far be right to give cordial under circumstance handed unmixed water time thinking that be too far gone to perceive difference herein wrong tom faggus for shook head cheek looked at winnie knew must have nose in clammy hand though thought not good for of with stay of arm sat upright faintly looked about a if at end of violent dream too much for power of mind then managed to whisper 'be winnie hurt sound a roach answered 'then so be ' said 'put upon back john die together surprised a be at fatalism for so appeared to of have often shown symptom before took for mere levity now knew not what to do for seemed to murderous thing to set man on horseback where must surely bleed to death even if must keep saddle told with many break pause that unless obeyed order must tear off bandage accept further aid from while be yet hesitating storm of horse at full gallop went by tearing swearing bearing away country before only little pollard hedge kept from blood shot eye 'now be time said cousin tom so far a must make out word on heel be safe john if have only winnie under winnie die together ' seeing strong bent of mind stronger than pain of death even did what that name of lord chief justice jeffreys be spoken more than once with emphasis deference 'then leave in hand captain stickles said kirke at last so that might hear though news be good for smile of from norseman mother be of very noblest race lord of lorne higher even than great argyle who have lately made sad mistake paid for most sadly father be descended from king dugal who fought against alexander great master ridd none of promiscuous blood such a run in vein of modern peerage 'why must trouble about master ramsack ' replied 'let go own way let look up to whether come by hook crook ' therefore to river thames with speed hurried keeping best clothes on indued for sake of lorna into quiet stream leaped swam a far a london bridge ate nobler dinner afterwards chapter lxvii lorna still be lorna although man may be a simple a flower of field knowing when scarcely why close to bitter wind feeling why scarcely when open to genial sun yet without questing much into capsule of to do be misery may have general notion how happens to be getting on felt to be getting on better than at time since last wheat harvest a took lane to kensington upon monday evening for although time be given in lorna letter be not inclined to wait more than decency required though went watched house decency must not allow to knock on sunday evening especially when found at corner that lordship be at home lane field between charing cross village of kensington be be at time more than reasonably infested with footpad with highwayman however stature holly club kept fellow from doing more than casting sheep eye at for be still broad daylight view of distant village chelsea battersea tyburn others a well a few large house among ham towards river made seem le lonely therefore sang song in broadest exmoor dialect caused little amazement in mind of who met when came to earl brandir house natural modesty forbade to appear at door for guest therefore went to entrance for servant retainer here to great surprise who must come let in little gwenny carfax whose very existence have almost escaped recollection mistress doubt have seen coming sent to save trouble when offered to kiss gwenny in joy comfort to see farm house face again looked ashamed turned away must hardly speak to followed to little room furnished very daintily there ordered to wait in most ungracious manner 'well thought 'if mistress maid be alike in temper better have be for to abide at master ramsack ' almost ere thought be done light quick step knew a well a 'watch dog knew mine breast began to tremble like trembling of arch ere keystone be put in almost ere hoped for fear hope be so entangled that hindered one velvet hanging of doorway parted with little doubt then good face put on lorna in perfect beauty stood before crimson fold dress be pure white cheek be rosy pink lip be scarlet like maiden with skill sense checking violent impulse stayed there for one moment only just to be admired then like woman came to seeing how alarmed be hand offered took raised to lip with fear a thing too good for 'be that ' whispered then eye gleamed up at in instant be weeping on breast 'darling lorna lady lorna ' cried in astonishment yet unable to keep closer to closer beurely though love so be not a must be ' 'yes be john yes be nothing else must ever be oh why have behaved so ' be behaving ' replied 'to very best of ability there be other man in world must hold so without kissing ' 'then why do john ' asked lorna looking up at with flash of old fun now matter proverbially be not for discussion repetition enough that said nothing more than 'oh john how glad be lorna lorna ' for about five minute then darling drew back proudly with blushing cheek tear bright eye began to cross examine beaster john ridd will tell truth whole truth nothing truth have be in chancery sir can detect story now why have never for more than twelvemonth taken smallest notice of old friend mistress lorna doone ' although spoke in lightsome manner a if made difference saw that quick heart be moving flash of eye controlled beimply for cause answered old friend true love took not smallest heed of knew where to find ' 'what ' cried lorna nothing more being overcome with wondering much inclined to fall away for assistance told over over again that not single syllable of message from tidings of welfare have reached one of since letter left behind except by soldier gossip 'oh poor dear john ' said lorna sighing at thought of misery wonderfully good of thinking of a must have done not to marry little plain thing perhaps must say that lovely creature for have never seen mistress ruth forget name something like towel huckaback be worthy maid answered with dignity alone of world except indeed poor annie have kept confidence in told not to dread rank trust heart lady lorna ' ruth be best friend ' answered be worthy of dear john now remember one thing dear if god must part a may be by nothing short of death try to marry little ruth when cease to remember now for head traitor have often suspected look in face wish fearful thing can not repeat ' with word moved implement such a have not seen before made ringing noise at serious distance before have ceased wondering for if such thing go on might ring church bell while sitting in back kitchen little gwenny carfax came with grave sullen face 'gwenny began lorna in tone of high rank dignity 'go fetch letter gave at various time for despatch to mistress ridd ' can fetch when be gone be use for to tell lie 'now gwenny can look at ' asked very sternly for matter be joke to after year unhappiness ' want to look at must look at young man for although did offer to kiss ' saw spite impudence of last remark so did although must not quite refrain from smiling 'now gwenny not to speak of ' said lorna very demurely 'if thought honest to keep letter be honest to keep money at cornish maiden broke into rage of honesty ' putt money by for 'ee 'ee will have farden of ' so flung out of room gwenny ' said lorna very softly following under door hanging be not honest to keep money be not honest to keep letter must have be worth more than gold to who be so kind to will know whole gwenny unless tell truth ' will tell truth strange maiden answered talking to herself at least a much a to mistress while went out of sight hearing then be so glad at having own lorna once again cleared of contempt for true to through of must have forgiven gwenny for treason even forgery ' trusted so much ' said lorna in old ill fortuned way 'and look how have deceived be why love john setting other thing aside because never told falsehood never must know ' 'well be not so sure of think must tell lie to have darling own 'yes perhaps might be right to other people besides two must not do to john never must do to know ' before quite perceived way to bottom of distinction although beyond doubt valid one gwenny came back with leathern bag tossed upon table not word did vouchsafe to stood there looking injured 'go get letter john ' said lorna very gravely 'or at least mother letter made of message to a for gwenny will go before lord justice jeffreys knew that lorna meant not thought that girl deserved frightening a indeed did mistook courage of child of cornwall stepped upon little round thing in nature of stool such a never have seen before thus delivered sentiment 'and may take if please before great lord jeffreys have done more than duty though did crookedly told heap of lie for sake pretty gratitude get beuch gratitude have shown ' replied lorna master ridd for kindness goodness to who be that went down at peril of life brought father to when have lost for month month who be answer gwenny ' jan ridd ' said handmaid very sulkily 'what made treat so little gwenny asked for lorna must not ask lest reply must vex 'because 'ee be'est below so shanna ' have poor farmering chap not even if be carnishman land birth who be 'd like to know ' 'gwenny may go ' said lorna reddening with quiet anger remember that come not near for next three day be only way to punish continued to when maid be gone in storm of sobbing weeping for next three day will scarcely touch morsel of food scarcely do thing cry make up mind to one thing john if mean to take for better for worse will have to take gwenny with ' must take with fifty gwennies said 'although one of hated believe little maid doe in bottom of heart ' one can possibly hate john ' answered very softly be better pleased with than if have called most noble glorious man in kingdom after spoke of ourselves way people must regard supposing that when lorna came to be own free mistress a must do in course of time be to throw rank aside refuse title caring not fig for folk who cared le than fig stalk for must shape mind to native bent to perfect happiness be not place to say much lest must appear to use improper selfish influence of course to men of common sense to everybody of middle age who must know best what be good for youth thought lorna entertained must be enough to prove madness not that must not keep well comfortably with nice clothes plenty of flower fruit landscape knowledge of neighbour affair kind interest in own still must not be a if be owner of county haughty title able to lead first men of age by mind face money therefore be quite resolved not to have word to say while young queen of wealth beauty of nobleman desire made mind up how to act for purest happiness to do justice be not first thing be thinking of test of judgment be only 'how will love be happiest 'now john cried for be so quick that always have thought beforehand 'why will be backward a if cared not for do dream that be doubting mind have be made up good john that must be husband for well will not say how long lest must laugh at folly believe be ever since came with stocking off loach right early for to make up mind know that made up yours john of course knew have great effect on now after age of loving will trifle sever ' told that be trifle most important thing to abandon wealth honour brilliance of high life be despised by one for such abundant folly moreover must appear knave for taking advantage of youth boundless generosity ruining a men must say noble maid by selfishness told outright having worked up by own conversation that be bound to consult guardian without knowledge must come no more to see flash of pride at last word made look like empress be about to explain better put forth hand stopped ' think that condition must rather have proceeded from be mistaken master ridd in supposing must think of receiving in secret be different thing in glen doone where except be thief when be simple child oppressed with constant fear be quite right in threatening to visit thus more think might have waited for invitation sir 'and be quite right lady lorna in pointing out presumption be fault must ever be found in speech of mine to ' said so humbly not with bitterness for knew have gone too far made so polite bow that forgave in moment begged other pardon 'now will allow just to explain own view of matter john ' said once more darling 'it may be very foolish view will never change please not to interrupt dear until have heard to end in first place be quite certain that can be happy without other then what stand between worldly position nothing else have more education than have john ridd nay not so much birth ancestry be not one whit more pure than yours although may be better known descent from ancient freeholder for five twenty generation of good honest men although bear coat of arm be better than lineage of nine proud english nobleman out of ten meet with in manner though mighty strength hatred of meanness sometimes break out in violence of must try to cure dear in manner if kindness gentleness modesty be true thing wanted be immeasurably above of court gallant who indeed have very little a for difference of religion doones even in mother for matter lorna smiled in slyest manner went on again see have proved point there be nothing between worldly position if can defend against doones for trow may trust worldly john no longer must be hard for to tell state of mind in lived for long time after put away from torment thought of future care sight of difficulty to myself appeared mean that became luckiest of lucky fellow since world began thought not of harvest even of men who must get wage without having earned of mother anxiety worry about john fry great fatness be growing upon how must cry fifty time in day if john must only come home how different everything must look although there be soldier now quartered at plover barrow being busied in harassing country hanging people where rebellion have thriven most mother having received from message containing place of abode contrived to send by pack horse a fine maund a need be of provision money other comfort therein found addressed to colonel jeremiah stickles in lizzie best handwriting half side of dried deer flesh in rejoiced so greatly also for lorna fine green goose with little salt towards tail new laid egg inside a well a bottle of brandied cherry seven may have be eight pound of fresh homemade butter moreover to myself there be letter full of good advice excellently well expressed must have be of greatest value if have cared to read read about farm affair man who have offered to betty for five pound in stocking a well a antic of sally snowe how have almost thrown at parson bowden head old enough to be grandfather because on sunday after hanging of countisbury man have preached beautiful sermon about christian love lizzie with sharp eye found to be work of good bishop ken also read that doones be quiet parish round about having united to feed well through harvest time so after day hard work farmer might go to bed at night plan have be found to answer well to save much trouble on side so that everybody wondered have not be done before lizzie thought that doones must hardly be expected much longer to put up with probably must not have done so now for little adversity to wit that famous colonel kirke have in most outrageous manner hanged le than six of who be captured among rebel for said that men of rank breeding above of religion must have known better than to join plough boy carter pickaxemen against lord king holiness pope hanging of so many doones caused indignation among people who be used to seemed for while to check rest from spirit of enterprise moreover found from same letter be pinned upon knuckle of leg of mutton for fear of being lost in straw that good tom faggus be at home again nearly cured of dreadful wound intended to go to war no more only to mind family grieved more than anything ever must have imagined that duty to family strong power of conscience so totally forbade to come up see after for now design be to lead new life be in charity with men many better men than have be hanged saw cause to doubt by grace of god hoped to cheat gallows there be further news of moment in very clever letter except that price of horse shoe be gone up again though already twopence farthing that betty have broken lover head with stocking full of money then in corner be written that distinguished man of war worshipful scholar master bloxham be now promoted to take toll catch
