of le true moment to a must not know of first be one moved happened pretty much a follows though hardly like to tell because advanced to such height a myself be giddy at friend resented greatly save of own family even now be sometimes bitter in spite of humility now be matter of history because king be concerned in being so strongly misunderstood especially in own neighbourhood will overcome so far a can diffidence in telling good earl brandir be man of noblest charity true charity begin at home so did be afraid of losing way if went abroad so good nobleman kept money in handsome pewter box with coat of arm upon double lid lock moreover there be heavy chain fixed to staple in wall so that none might carry off pewter with gold inside of lorna told box be full for have seen go to often thought that must be nice for to begin world with told that must not allow mind to dwell upon thing of sort being wholly against last commandment set up in church at oare now one evening towards september when day be drawing in looking back at house to see whether lorna be looking after espied by little glimpse a be pair of villainous fellow about whom there must be mistake watching from thicket corner hundred yard so behind good earl dwelling 'there be mischief afoot ' thought to myself being thoroughly conversant with theft from knowledge of doones will be moon to night when may expect watch found that moon watch must be looked for until morning moon of course before watch more likely to be punctual therefore resolved to wait see what two villain did save if be possible earl of brandir pewter box inasmuch a bad men be almost sure to have seen leaving house looking back striking out on london road marched along at merry pace until must not discern then fetched compass round refreshed at certain inn entitled cross bone button here remained until be very nearly a dark a pitch house being full of footpad cutthroat thought right to leave one two came after in hope of designing stratagem dropped in darkness knowing neighbourhood well took up position two hour before midnight among shrub at eastern end of lord brandir mansion hence although might not see must scarcely fail to hear if unlawful entrance at back front be made from own observation thought likely that attack must be in rear so indeed came to pas for when light be quenched house be quiet low wily whistle from clump of tree close by then three figure passed between whitewashed wall came to window opened into part of servant basement window be carefully raised by one inside house after little whispering something sounded like kiss three men entered 'oh villain said to myself 'this be worse than doone job because there be treachery in ' without waiting to consider subject from moral point of view crept along wall entered very quietly after being rather uneasy about life because bore fire arm have nothing more than holly staff for even violent combat to be matter of deep regret a followed vile men inward nevertheless be resolved that lorna must not be robbed again through at least through annie have lost that brilliant necklace then be only birthright therefore behoved doubly to preserve pewter box must belong to in end unless thief got hold of went along very delicately a man who have learned to wrestle can do although may weigh twenty stone following carefully light brought by traitorous maid shaking in loose dishonest hand saw lead men into little place called pantry there gave cordial must hear boasting not to be too long over be much inclined to be followed from drinking bout by aid of light bore a far a earl brandir bedroom knew because lorna have shown to that might admire tapestry have said that horse must ever be shod a horse be shod therein unless have foot of frog a well a frog to foot lorna have be vexed at a taste high art always be at small accurate knowledge so have brought out again before have time to admire thing now keeping well away in dark yet nearer than be necessary to own dear lorna room saw fellow try door of good earl brandir knowing from maid of course that lordship must hear nothing except name of alan tried lock pushed at even set knee upright scottish nobleman may be trusted to secure door at night so be forced to break open at guilty maid woman ran away three rogue for rogue be charity may deny burst into earl brandir room with light crowbar fire arm thought to myself that be hard upon honest nobleman if further mischief must be saved must try to save when came to door of room being in shadow beheld two bad men trying vainly to break open pewter box third with pistol muzzle laid to night cap of lordship with foul face yet fouler word man be demanding key of box other men must by mean open drag from chain tell ' said aged earl beginning to understand at last what rogue be up for ' will give key to belongs to boy alan one else will have farthing ' may count moment lord key be in old cramped hand one two at three shoot ' saw that old man be abroad not with fear with great wonder regret of deafness saw that rather must be shot than let men go rob son buried now laid to bleach in tangle of wood three might be four year agone still alive to father hereupon heart be moved resolved to interfere thief with pistol began to count a crossed floor very quietly while old earl fearfully gazed at muzzle clenched still tighter wrinkled hand villain with hair over eye great horse pistol levelled cried 'three pulled trigger luckily at very moment struck up barrel with staff so that shot pierced tester then with spin thwack brought good holly down upon rascal head in manner stretched upon floor meanwhile other two robber have taken alarm rushed at one with pistol one with hanger forced to be very lively fearing pistol most flung heavy velvet curtain of bed across that might not see where to aim at then stooping very quickly caught up senseless robber set up for shield target whereupon be shot immediately without having pain of knowing happy thing be for now other two be at mercy being men below average strength hanger except in most skilful hand a well a firm strong one have chance to powerful man armed with stout cudgel thoroughly practised in single stick so took two rogue bound together leaving under charge of butler worthy shrewd scotchman went in search of constable whom after few hour found be so drunk what must take roped men to prison in morning two men be brought before justice of peace now wonderful luck appeared for merit of having defeated caught must never have raised one step in state in public consideration if have only be common robber even notorious murderer when fellow be recognised by one in court a protestant witness out of employment companion understrappers to oates bedloe carstairs hand in glove with dangerfield turberville dugdale in word very men against whom majesty king bore bitterest rancour whom have hitherto failed to catch when be laid before public with emphasis admiration at least dozen men came up whom have never seen before prayed to accept congratulation to be sure to remember for be of neglected merit required more than piece of luck answered very modestly according to worth a stated by who of course must judge best magistrate made many compliment ten time more than deserved took good care to have copied that majesty might see ere case be thoroughly heard poor fellow be committed more than score of generous men have offered to lend hundred pound wherewith to buy new court suit when called before majesty now may seem very strange to who live in better purer age say at least that do so yet who be to condemn father for teaching better manner at own expense with point virtuous man be bound to deal quite tenderly making allowance for corruption not being too sure of to tell truth although have seen so little of world a that astonished in matter be not so much that paid court a found out so soon expediency of doing in course of same afternoon be sent for by majesty have summoned first good earl brandir received tale from not without exaggeration although lord be scotchman chief thing majesty cared to know be that beyond possible doubt be very precious fellow from perjury turned to robbery being fully assured at last of majesty have rubbed hand ordered boot of stricter pattern have invented to be brought at once that might have in best possible order oiled expressed fear that there be man in london quite competent to work nevertheless must try one two rather than wait for pleasure till torturer came from edinburgh next thing did be to send for in great alarm flurry put on best clothes hired fashionable hairdresser drank gallon of ale because hand be shaking then forth set with holly staff wishing well out of be shown at once before desired into majesty presence there stood most humbly made best bow must think of a must not advance farther for saw that queen be present frightened tenfold majesty in most gracious manner came down room to encourage a remained with head bent down told to stand up look at have seen thee before young man said 'thy form be not one to be forgotten where be thou art most likely to know ' beay please most gracious majesty king ' answered finding voice in manner surprised 'it be in royal chapel ' now meant harm whatever by ought to have said 'ante chapel ' must not remember word feared to keep king looking at ' be well pleased ' said majesty with smile almost made dark stubborn face look pleasant find that greatest subject greatest mean in bodily form be also good catholic thou needest not say otherwise time will be right soon when men will be proud of one true faith here stopped having gone rather far gleam of heavy eye be such that durst not contradict 'this be that great johann reed ' said majesty coming forward because king be in meditation whom have so much heard from dear dear lorna ah be not of black countree be of breet italie have tried to write a said want better scholar to express mode of speech john ridd ' said king recovering from thought about true church thinking that wife be not to take lead upon 'thou hast done great service to realm to religion be good to save earl brandir loyal catholic nobleman be great service to catch two of vilest bloodhound ever laid on by heretic to make shoot one be rare be rare lad now ask anything in reason thou canst carry honour on thy club like hercules what be thy chief ambition lad ' 'well said after thinking little meaning to make most of for so queen eye conveyed to bey mother always used to think that having be schooled at tiverton with thirty mark year to pay be worthy of coat of arm be what longs for ' ' good lad very good lad ' said king looked at queen a if almost in joke what be thy condition in life ' ' be freeholder ' answered in confusion since time of king alfred ridd be with in isle of athelney hold farm by gift from at least people say so have have three very good harvest running might support coat of arm for want not ' 'thou shalt have coat lad ' said king smiling at own humour 'but must be large one to fit thee more than shalt thou have john ridd being of such loyal breed having done such service while wondered what meant called to of people in waiting at farther end of room brought little sword such a annie must skewer turkey with then signified to to kneel did after dusting board for sake of best breech then gave little tap very nicely upon shoulder before knew what be up to said 'arise sir john ridd ' astonished amazed to such extent of loss of mind that when got up looked about thought what snowes must think of said to king without form of speech be very much obliged what be to do with ' chapter lxix not to be put up with coat of arm devised for by royal herald be of great size rich colour full of bright imaginings did honour to consult first to take notice of advice for begged that there might be good annals of family told of course about king alfred upon settled that one quarter must be three cake on bar with lion regardant done upon field of gold also told that very likely there have be ridd in battle fought not very far from plover barrow by earl of devon against dane when hubba chief be killed sacred standard taken a of dane be said to be buried even upon land of ours call graf if such be even to day 'barrows ' herald quite agreed with that ridd might have be there thereabouts if be there be almost certain to have done best being in sight of hearth home be plain that must have have good leg to be at same time there in athelney good leg be argument for good arm supposing man of sort to have done utmost a manner of ridds be be next to certain that must have captured standard moreover name of farm be pure proof plover being wild bird just same a raven be upon chain of reasoning without weak misgiving charged growing escutcheon with black raven on ground of red next thing mentioned possessing absolute certainty to wit that pig with two head have be born upon farm not more than two hundred year agone although died within week third quarter be made at once by two headed boar with noble tusk sable upon silver be very fierce fine so pressed for peaceful corner in lower dexter obtained wheat sheaf set upright gold upon field of green here be inclined to pause admire effect for even de whichehalse must not show bearing so magnificent herald said that looked mere sign board without good motto under motto must have name in offered first 'ridd non ridendus ' said 'for god sake gentleman let forget latin ' then proposed 'ridd readeth riddle begged not to set down such lie for ridd ever have made made out such thing a riddle since exmoor began thirdly gave 'ridd never be ridden fearing to make further objection let inscribe in bronze upon blue herald thought that king must pay for noble achievement majesty although graciously pleased with ingenuity declined in most decided manner to pay farthing towards a have now money left herald became a blue a azure a red a gules until majesty queen came forward very kindly said that if majesty gave coat of arm be not to pay for therefore did so quite handsomely felt goodwill towards in consequence now being in hurry so far at least a be in nature to hurry to get to end of narrative be likely must have dwelled so long upon coat of arm for good reason good reason be that lorna took greatest pride in thought at rate said that quite threw into shade eclipsed own ancient glory half in fun half in earnest called beir john ' so continually that at last be almost angry with until eye be bedewed with tear then be angry with beginning to be short of money growing anxious about farm longing also to show noble escutcheon to mother took advantage of lady lorna interest with queen to obtain acquittance full discharge from even nominal custody have be intended to keep in waiting until return of lord jeffreys from awful circuit of shamble through name be still used by mother to frighten child into bed right glad be for even london shrank with horror at news to escape man so bloodthirsty savage even to friend among whom be reckoned malignant earl brandir be greatly pleased with not only for having saved life for saving valued more wealth laid by for lord alan introduced to many great people who quite kindly encouraged promised to help in way when heard how king have spoken a for furrier must never have enough of society worthy man praying commendation demanded of one thing only to speak of a found a have found many sunday furbishing up old fur for new with glaze to conceal moth ravage begged to reconsider point not to demand such accuracy said 'well well trade have trick especially trick of business must take if be true friend according to own description be glad enough to do because saved so much trouble have money to spend with still requested use of name begged to do best with a never have kept banker 'john ridd cuff beir john mantle 'holly staff cape put into window a winter be coming on ay sold for everybody be burning with gossip about must have made good man fortune since excess of price over value be true test of success in life to come away from stuff grief man in london when brisk air of autumn cleared way to ludgate hill clever 'prentices ran out sniffed at fed upon having little else to eat when horse from country be goodly sight to see with rasp of winter bristle rising through among soft summer coat when new straw began to come in golden with harvest gloss smelling most divinely at strange livery stable where nag be put quite tail to tail when london folk be asking about white frost from recollection of childhood then say such yearning seized for moory crag for dewy blade even grunting of sheep when sun go down that nothing new wisp of samson must have held in london town lorna be moved with equal longing towards country country way spoke quite a much of glistening dew a did of smell of oven here let mention although two be quite distinct different that dew bread of exmoor may be sought whether high low never found elsewhere dew be so crisp pure pearly in such abundance bread be so sweet so kind homely can eat loaf then now while be walking daily in out great crowd of men few of whom have freedom from care of money many of whom be even morbid with worse pest called 'politics must not be quit of thinking how jostle one god have made earth quite large with spread of land large enough for to live on without fighting also mighty spread of water laying hand on sand cliff with solemn voice in storm time in gentle weather moving men to thought of equity a well be full of food being two third of world reserved for devouring knowledge by time son of men have fed away dry land yet before land have acknowledged touch of man upon one in hundred acre before one mile in ten thousand of exhaustless ocean have ever felt plunge of hook combing of haul net lo crawl in flock together upon hot ground sting even a black grub crowd upon harried nettle surely be too much given to follow track of other however for moralist never set up never will while common sense abides with man must be very wretched in pure dearth of morality like fisherman where fish be most of have enough to do to attend to own moral enough resolved to go a lorna must not come with be even worse than stopping nearly everybody vowed that be great fool indeed to neglect so rudely be proper word said pushing of fortune answered that to push be rude left to people who have room thought that fortune must be heavy if must not move without pushing lorna cried when came away gave great satisfaction sent whole trunkful of thing for mother annie even lizzie seemed to think though said not that made own occasion for going might have stayed on till winter whereas knew well that mother must think one on farm same that here have be in london lagging taking pleasure looking at shop upon pretence of king business leaving harvest to reap not to mention spending of money while time there be nothing whatever except own love of adventure sport to keep from coming home again knew that coat of arm title must turn bit of grumbling into fine admiration so fell out to greater extent than even desired for parish round about united in sumptuous dinner at mother melldrum inn for now good lady be dead name face set on sign post to be invited so that be a good a summons if health be better next day be not from want of good wish more than from stint of liquor be needle to say that real gentry for long time treated new honour with contempt ridicule gradually a found be not such fool a to claim equality with went about farm work threw man at wrestling touched hat to magistrate just same a ever gentleman of highest blood of think great deal more than of gold around neighbourhood actually expressed desire to make acquaintance when in manner quite straightforward wholly free from bitterness thanked for appeared to highest honour yet offered declined to go into company because must make uncomfortable a well in different way did what nearly englishman do when thing be right sensible shook hand with said that must not deny that there be reason in view of matter although must be loser be handsome thing to say must wait until be little older more aware of own value now reminds how be that english gentleman be so far in front of foreign nobleman prince have seen at time little of one of other making more than due allowance for difficulty of language difference of training upon whole balance be in favour of people because have two weight solid even in scale of manner outweighing light complaisance to wit inborn love of justice power of abiding people may be surprised that men with love of justice whether inborn otherwise must continue to abide arrogance rapacity tyranny of doones for now a winter passed doones be not keeping at home a in honour be bound to do twenty sheep week one fat ox two stout red deer for wholesome change of diet a well a threescore bushel of flour two hogshead half of cider hundredweight of candle not to mention other thing of almost variety got by insisting upon surely might have sufficed to keep people in place with outburst of wantonness nevertheless be not so have made complaint about something too much ewe mutton think be in spite of pledge given have ridden forth carried away two maiden of neighbourhood now two maiden be known because have served beer at ale house many men who have looked at over pint quart vessel especially a be comely girl thought that be very hard for to go in way perhaps unwilling mother although have taken money doones be always full of declared that be robbery though increased for while custom must soon fall off again who must have two girl now clever a be good before have finished meditating upon loose outrage for so at least must call though people accustomed to law may take different view of have news of thing far worse turned heart of woman sick will tell in most careful language so a to give offence to none if skill of word may help following story be strictly true true be that country people rose to man at dastard cruelty did what government failed to do ed mistress margery badcock healthy upright young woman with good rich colour one of finest hen roost anywhere round neighbourhood be nursing child about six of clock looking out for husband now child be too old to be nursed a everybody told for must run say two yard alone perhaps four five by holding to handle have way of looking round spreading leg laughing with brave little body well fetched up after desperate journey to end of table mother said nothing must equal nevertheless must come to be nursed a regular a clock almost inasmuch a be first father mother made much of for god only knew whether must ever compass such one christopher badcock be tenant farmer in parish of martinhoe renting fifty acre of land with right of common attached to at particular time being now month of february fine open weather be hard at work ploughing preparing for spring corn therefore wife be not surprised although dusk be falling that farmer christopher must be at work in 'blind man holiday ' a call be surprised nay astonished when by light of kitchen fire brightened up for husband saw six seven great armed men burst into room upon screamed so that maid in back kitchen heard be afraid to come to help two of strongest fiercest men at once seized poor young margery though fought for child home be infant herself in hand in spite of tear shriek struggle tore babe from mother arm cast on lime ash floor then bore away to horse for by time be senseless telling others to sack house rode off with prize to valley from description of one of two who carried off poor woman knew beyond doubt that be carver doone other doones being left behind grieved perhaps in respect set to with will to scour house to bring away be good to eat being little vexed herein for badcocks be not rich couple finding no more than bacon egg cheese little item nothing to drink water in word taste being offended came back to kitchen stamped there be baby lying by evil luck child began to squeal about mother having be petted hitherto wont to get wanted by raising voice about murdering of father how balance hang between god know better than thou thou low miscreant carver doone have worked up a always do in manner of heavy men growing hot like ill washered wheel upon though have be to interest to keep quiet during last attack under commander stickles for sake of secret gold mine yet now be in position to give full vent to feeling for partner when fully assured of value of digging have obtained from crown licence to adventure in search of mineral by payment of heavy fine yearly royalty therefore have now no longer cause for secrecy neither for dread of outlaw having so added to force a to be match for although uncle ben be not man to keep miner idle hour more than might be helped promised that when have fixed moment for assault on valley score of must come to aid headed by simon carfax armed with gun always kept for protection of gold now whether be uncle ben whether be tom faggus even own self for three of claimed sole honour be more than entire three of having pipe schnapps water in chimney corner however world always judge according to reputation vowed that so fine stroke of war must only come from highwayman so tom faggus got honour strong drink other thing more especially fond of gold when must get pure fine therefore be agreed that in way must tempt for knew that looked with ridicule upon rustic preparation after repulsing king dwelling of doones inhabited with luxury luscious taste licentiousness not even one be left made potash in river may seem violent unholy revenge upon who led heart of have in latter year doubted how will be judged not of men for god only know error of man judgment by great god front of whose forehead be mercy chapter lxxii counsellor carver from great confusion for nothing can be broken up whether lawful unlawful without vast amount of dust many people grumbling mourning for good old time when world be happiness man gentleman sun far brighter than since brassy idol upon shone be broken from loss of ancient landmark a unrobbed men began to call clearance of murderer returned on following day almost a full of anxiety a be of triumph in first place what must possibly do with woman child thrown on hand a one might say with none to protect care for again how must answer to justice of peace perhaps even to lord jeffreys for having without even warrant taken law into own hand abated nuisance so forcibly then what be to be done with spoil be of great value though diamond necklace came not to public light for saw mighty host of claimant already leaping up for booty man who have ever be robbed expected usury on loss lord of manor demanded whole so did king commissioner of revenue at porlock so did men who have fought battle while even parson bowden powell who have parish in threatened with just wrath of church unless have tithe of whole of now be not a ought to be seemed a if by burning nest of robber have hatched egg until being made sole guardian of captured treasure by reason of known honesty hit upon plan gave very little satisfaction yet carried advantage that grumbler argued against one for most part came to blow renewed goodwill to a being abused by adversary plan be more than not to pay farthing to lord of manor parson even king commissioner after making good of recent proven loss where men must not afford to lose to pay residue might be worth fifty thousand pound into exchequer at westminster then let claimant file what will pleased in chancery now be very noble device for mere name of chancery high repute of fee therein low repute of lawyer comfortable knowledge that woolsack be golden fleece absorbing gold for ever if standard be pure consideration of thing staved off at once lord of manor little farmer even whom most feared videlicet parson king commissioner be compelled to profess contented although of be most aggrieved for picking must have be goodly moreover by plan made although never thought of that mighty friend worth enemy whom loss of money moved first man now in kingdom by virtue perhaps of energy rather than of excellence be great lord jeffreys appointed head of equity a well a law of realm for kindness in hanging five hundred people without mere brief of trial nine out of ten of people be innocent be true proved merit of lord chief justice so much greater for hanging a showing what might be expected of when truly got hold of guilty man now king have seen force of argument not being without gratitude for high seasoned dish of cruelty have promoted only man in england combining gift of butcher cook nevertheless do beg to believe of think that after following so long must believe did not even know at time of lord jeffreys high promotion not that knowledge of must have led to act otherwise in matter for object be to pay into office not to official neither if have known fact must have seen bearing upon receipt of money for king exchequer be meseemeth of common law while chancery be of equity well named for many chance true result of thing be lord jeffreys being now head of law almost head of kingdom got possession of money be kindly pleased with met second difficulty for law having won laughed over spoil must have injured own title by impugning legality next with regard to woman child be long in state of perplexity did very best at farm so did many others to provide for until bagworthy for a came home from brook at dusk with fly rod over shoulder doones fell upon murdered then sacked house burned now have made honest people timid about going past warren at night for of lorna when became of full age mistress of property be still under guardianship must pay heavy fine to crown devote fixed portion of estate to promotion of holy catholic faith in manner to be dictated truth if have not be for little maid lorna must have died at once a in arm lay for dead from dastard murderous cruelty moment left ruth came forward took command of one in right of firmness readiness made bear home at once upon door of pulpit with cushion under drooping head with own little hand cut off a tenderly a pear be peeled bridal dress so steeped stained then with dainty transparent finger larger than pencil probed vile wound in side fetched reeking bullet forth then with coldest water stanched flowing of life blood while darling lay insensible white a death needed nothing maiden shroud ruth still sponged poor side forehead watched long eyelash flat upon marble cheek laid pure face on faint heart bade fetch spanish wine then parted pearly teeth feebly clenched on hovering breath poured in wine from christening spoon raised graceful neck breast stroked delicate throat waited then poured in little more annie while looked on with horror amazement counting second rate nurse a against theory quiet lifting of ruth hand one glance from dark bright eye told annie just to stand away not intercept air so at very moment when rest have settled that ruth be simple idiot must not harm dead much little flutter in throat followed by short low sigh made pause look hope for hour however day lay at very verge of death kept alive by nothing care skill tenderness perpetual watchfulness of ruth luckily annie be not there very often so a to meddle for kind clever nurse a be must have done more harm than good broken rib be set by doctor who chanced to be at wedding be allotted to annie care great inflammation ensuing be quite enough to content doctor have pronounced poor lorna dead wherefore ruth refused most firmly to have aught to do with took whole case on herself with god help bore through now whether be light brightness of lorna nature freedom from anxiety for knew not of hurt a people said birthright among wound violence manner of not drinking beer leave doctor to determine who pronounced dead anyhow one thing be certain sure a star of hope above lorna recovered long ere did for grief be on still of having lost love lover at moment be mine with power of fate upon black cauldron of wizard death boiling in heated brain have faith in tale told believed that lorna be in churchyard while rogue be lying to for with strength of blood like mine power of heart behind broken bone must burn mine went hard with fire of pain being of such size thickness be ashamed of for breaking by reason of pistol ball mere hug of man fetched down in conceit of strength so be careful afterwards be lesson to made very humble illness being thing a yet altogether unknown to not that cried small skulked feared death foretold shaking head about mortification green appearance only that seemed quite fit to go to heaven lorna for in sick distracted mind stirred with many tossings like bead in spread of frog spawn carried by current hung black central essence of future life life without lorna tadpole life stupid head body many men may like such life anchorite fakir high priest so on to mind be not native thing god meant for dearest mother be show with cry with fretting doones a thought be born to destroy scarce have come to liveliness though sprinkled with tear now then after great bereavement ten year time to dwell on when lo here be husband son pet child of own good john murdered like father well way of god be wonderful so be so be so ever will be let debate a will way be much same only second hand from expected something from even in worst of time knowing that have done best be not edifying talk a nonconformist parson say when can get more to drink therefore let only tell what became of lorna one day be sitting in bedroom for must not get downstairs there be one strong enough to carry even if must have allowed though cost sore trouble weariness have put on sunday clothes out of respect for doctor who be coming to bleed again a always did twice week struck that have seemed hurt in mind because wore worst clothes to be bled in for lie in bed must not after six o'clock even be great laziness looked at right hand whose grasp have be like of blacksmith vice seemed to myself impossible that must be john ridd great frame of hand be there a well a muscle standing forth like guttering of candle broad blue vein going up back crossing finger a for colour even lorna must scarcely have be whiter a for strength little ensie doone might have come held fast laughed a tried in vain to lift basin set for bleeding then thought of lovely thing going on out of door just now concerning drowsy song of bee came to must be among thyme by sound of great content therefore rose must be in blossom woodbine clove gilly flower cherry on wall must be turning red yellow sally must be on brook wheat must be callow with quavering bloom early meadow swathed with hay yet here be helpless creature quite unfit to stir among gifted with sight scent of change move love lead heart from month to month along quiet path of life what be worse have hope of caring ever for more presently little knock sounded through gloomy room supposing to be doctor tried to rise make bow to surprise be little ruth who have never once come to visit since be placed under doctor hand ruth be dressed so gaily with rosette flower what not be sorry for bad manner thought be come to conquer now that lorna be done with ruth ran towards with sparkling eye being rather short of sight then suddenly stopped saw entire amazement in face 'can receive visitor cousin ridd why never told of cried ' knew that be weak dear john not that be dying be that basin for ' have intention of dying ruth like not to talk about that basin if must know be for doctor purpose ' do mean bleeding poor weak cousin be possible that doe that still ' week for last six week dear nothing else have kept alive ' 'nothing else have killed nearly there ' set little boot across basin crushed 'not drop will have from be annie such fool a lizzie like zany at book killing brother between ' be surprised to see ruth excited character being so calm quiet tried to soothe with feeble hand a now knelt before 'dear cousin doctor must know best annie say so day what have be brought up for 'brought up for slaying murdering twenty doctor killed king charles in spite of woman will leave to john have little will of own be not afraid of doctor will leave to dear john have saved lorna life now will save yours be far far easier business ' 'you have saved lorna life what do mean by talking so ' 'only what say cousin john though perhaps overprize work at rate say so ' understand ' said falling back with bewilderment 'all woman be such liar 'have ever known tell lie ' ruth in great indignation more feigned doubt than real 'your mother may tell story now then when feel right so may both sister so can not do john ridd more than can do ' if ever there be virtuous truth in eye of woman be now in ruth huckaback brain began very slowly to move heart being almost torpid from perpetual loss of blood ' understand ' be must say for very long time understand if show lorna have feared to do for sake of now lorna be well enough if think that be cousin john surely will understand when see wife ' following to very utmost of mind heart felt that said be truth yet must not make out in last few word there be such power of sadness rising through cover of gaiety said to half in dream 'ruth be very beautiful ' before have time to listen much for approach of footstep ruth came back behind lorna coy a if of bridegroom hanging back with beauty ruth banged door ran away lorna stood before did not stand for instant when saw what be like at risk of thick bandage upsetting dozen medicine bottle scattering leech right left managed to get into arm although must not hold laid panting warm young breast on place where meant to bleed set pale face up must not look at having greater faith in kissing felt life come back warm felt trust in woman flow felt joy of living now power of doing be not moment to describe who feel can never tell of rush of lorna tear challenge of bride lip throbbing of wife heart now at last at home on mine made feel that world be good not thing to be weary of little more have to tell doctor be turned out at once slowly came back former strength with darling wife good victual a for lorna never tired of sitting watching eat eat such be heart that never tire of being with here there among beautiful place talking with arm around so far at least a can go though half of mine may go round of many fear trouble danger discouragement worst of bitter parting used to have somehow there be need for farming harder than becomes man of weight lorna have great store of money though never draw out except for poor neighbor unless find sumptuous dress out of own perquisite always look upon a wondrous gift from kiss much when put on walk like noble woman be yet may never behold again for get back to simple clothes love better in believe that give grandeur away keep other half for child a for poor tom faggus one know bitter adventure when pardon be recalled because of journey to sedgemoor not child in country doubt know far more than do of tom most desperate doings law have ruined once said then have be too much for law now that quiet life be object here base thing came after such be dread of evil spirit that being caught upon barnstaple bridge with soldier at end of yet doubtful about approaching set strawberry mare sweet winnie at left hand parapet with whisper into dove coloured ear without moment doubt leaped into foaming tide swam landed according to order also flight from public house where trap be set for winnie came broke down door put two men under trod on be a well known a ballad be reported for awhile poor tom have be caught at last by mean of fondness for liquor be hanged before taunton jail luckily knew better with good wife wonderful horse country attached to kept law at wholesome distance until became too much for master new king arose upon tom sued pardon afresh jeremy stickles who suited time be glad to help in getting a well a compensation thereafter good respectable tom lived godly though not always sober life brought up child to honesty a first of qualification dear mother be a happy a possibly need be with having cause for jealousy a others arose around everybody be well pleased when lizzy came in one day tossed bookshelf over declared that must have captain bloxham nobody must prevent for that alone of men have ever met with knew good writing when saw must spell word when told a have now succeeded to captain stickle position stickles going up tree have power of collecting of keeping what liked there be nothing to be said against hoped that must pay out sent little ensie to blundell school at own cost charge having changed name for fear of what anyone might do to called ensie jones got commission after many scrape of spirit did great thing in low country look upon a father without leave will not lay claim to heritage title of doones clearly belong to ruth huckaback be not married yet although upon uncle reuben death came into property except indeed pound uncle ben in driest manner bequeathed 'to sir john ridd worshipful knight for greasing of testator boot left almost mint of money not from mine from shop good use of usury for mine have brought in just what cost when vein of gold ended suddenly leaving concerned much older fear much poorer one utterly ruined a be case with most of ruth be true mine a upon death bed found know man even worthy of though be not very young love a love lorna be firm conviction that in end will win mean to dance again except at dear ruth wedding if floor be strong enough of lorna of lifelong darling of more more loved wife will not talk for be not seemly that man must exalt pride year by year beauty grows with growth of goodness kindness true happiness above with loving for change make joke of play with laugh at then when slow nature marvel back come to earnest thing if wish to pay out for something very dreadful a may happen once twice when become too gladsome bring to forgotten sadness to for cure of by two word 'lorna doone '
